DOC.HEAD: Amusement Parks Wage Battle of Primal Screams With Scary Roller Coasters
DOC.TEXT: It's the battle of the monster roller coasters, white-knucklers designed to scare you silly, and it's just in time for youngsters on spring vacation to buy a thrill. But at $17-plus, these thrills aren't cheap. Thirty miles from downtown Los Angeles, in opposite directions, the Knott's Berry Farm and Six Flags Magic Mountain amusement parks are fighting to outdo each other by unleashing multimillion-dollar fright machines. Knott's, to the southeast in Buena Park, promises its new $5 million Boomerang coaster will elicit ``the primal scream.'' Magic Mountain at Valencia, to the northwest, says its $8 million Viper coaster provides ``the most frightening ride on earth.'' They are the latest in the nation's decade-long competition to see who can build the biggest, fastest and scariest amusement park attraction. The battle sometimes ends up in court. In Allentown, Pa., the Dorney Park amusement park recently filed a lawsuit in federal court to stop Six Flags Over Texas from claiming it has the nation's tallest wooden roller coaster. Advertisements claim the $5.5 million Texas Giant coaster is the highest at 143 feet, compared with 95 feet for Dorney's Hercules coaster. But Dorney Park insists Hercules is 157 feet, because it drops over a cliff, and the Texas Giant 137 feet. ``Coaster enthusiasts go all over the country looking for moments of negative gravity,'' said Paul Ruben, editor of Roller Coaster! magazine. He planned to be on hand today when Viper opens to the public. ``Viper is a megacoaster that precisely defines the next step in roller coaster evolution. Viper is, quite simply, the ultimate scream machine,'' said Magic Mountain president Joseph Schillaci. Viper sends cars racing 70 mph over a course that reaches 188 feet high and includes seven loops during a 2{-minute run. Padded over-the-shoulder locking harnesses keep passengers inside and ``fail-safe air brakes'' on the track are computer controlled to assure proper ride speed. Asked about the safety of Boomerang, which also has padded shoulder harnesses, Knott's spokesman Stuart Zanville said structural experts employed by the amusement parks examine thrill rides daily. There are no checks by government agencies, although the Occupational Safety and Health Administration does inspect carnival rides. ``We've never had a ride-related fatality. Every ride is inspected every single day by our safety inspectors,'' Zanville said. Magic Mountain markets the Viper as the world's tallest looping roller coaster. The nation's tallest roller coaster is the 205-foot-high Magnum XL 200 at the Cedar Point amusement park in Sandusky, Ohio, but it doesn't loop. But the president of the 2,000-member American Coaster Enthusiasts group says pacing, steepness and the severity of turns are more important factors than size. ``You could have a ride 50 feet tall and it could scare the beejeebees out of you,'' said Randy Geisler, the Chicago-based association's leader. Knott's Berry Farm understandably agrees with Geisler _ Boomerang pales in size compared to Viper. Boomerang cars make the outbound and return trips on the same 875-foot-long track. Riders are first pulled backward to the top of a 125-foot tower, then released to hurtle through three vertical loops before ascending another tower for the ride back. It lasts 90 seconds. ``During the ride, you have the sensation that you actually have fallen off the track. With ours, it's not the height or the speed, it's how you feel when you get off,'' said Zanville. There are similar rides at Six Flags Over Texas near Dallas and Canada's Wonderland theme park in Toronto. Roller coaster popularity peaked in the 1920s with more than 1,500 in operation in the United States. By 1978, only 147 were left in North America. But there will be 203 coasters in operation by the end of this year, with 17 new, moved or renovated ones opening.

DOC.HEAD: Balmain Names Scotsman As New Designer For Ready-to-Wear
DOC.TEXT: The house of Balmain has presented its new designer for its ``Ivoire'' line of luxury ready-to-wear, Alistair Blair of Scotland. He is well-known in Great Britain, having designed for Jaeger and under his own label. ``His sketches won me over,'' said Alain Chevalier, who as Balmain's resident has overseen a major financial restructuring this year. Chevalier said he based his choice, announced Friday, on Blair's creativity and experience, which includes nine years in Paris with couture houses like Dior, Givenchy, Chloe and Karl Lagerfeld. This is the latest in various French fashion companies' bids to boost fashion excitement and sales with new designers. The trend started in 1983, when Karl Lagerfeld made a splash at Chanel, reviving the old name with his creative ideas. Last summer, Gianfranco Ferre took over as Dior's head designer. The house of Lanvin is looking for original couture creativity from Claude Montana. And Nina Ricci's ready-to-wear got a fresh approach with another Englishman, Philip Waghorne. Erik Mortensen, Balmain's Danish-born designer, will keep his post as head of haute couture, which he has occupied since Pierre Balmain's death in 1982. His last ``Ivoire'' collection Wednesday was a low-keyed presentation of a few beautifully made outfits. Among the suits a standout was the black faille number with hot orange satin lapels turned back with a big button. In the sparkly evening wear, the hostess gown of gold guipure lace over a spangled stripe skirt had charm worthy of the new New York preference for taste over glitz. There also were remarkable black knits, pieced in swooping arcs, buttoned up with gold and sporting tulip-split skirts. Now fashion buffs will be watching for Blair's October debut. ``I've given up my own label in England,'' said Blair, a Francophile who grew up near Glasgow and trained at St. Martin's School of Art. ``I feel Paris is indeed the fashion capital, the place to be for any designer,'' he said. He wouldn't reveal his plans, but his recent work shows a bright, bouncy approach without being too way-out for a couture customer. Blair will move to Paris for his new job but will continue to design for Jaeger and Ballantyne cashmeres. His first Balmain assignment is a trip to the United States next week to win American prestige-store buyers. As yet, Balmain has little representation in U.S. shops. Chevalier also announced plans for luxury ready-to-wear expansion in the Far East, with stores coming up soon in Hong Kong, Bangkok and Singapore. The Balmain label still has a classic image, but no matter what creations Blair comes up with, the prices will remain in the medium-expensive category _ about $1,000 for a suit retail. Chevalier also announced there would be a less expensive sub-Ivoire line based on Blair's creations, as yet unnamed. Most big names exploit less expensive lines, such as Saint Laurent's ``Variation.'' It is about a third less than the regular luxury ready-to-wear.

DOC.HEAD: Cordon Bleu To Recreate La Fayette's 1774 Wedding Dinner
DOC.TEXT: The famed Paris cooking school Le Cordon Bleu is organizing a dinner in Washington to re-create the 1774 wedding feast of the Marquis de La Fayette, the Frenchman who helped the Americans win their revolution. The black-tie affair is planned for Wednesday, April 11, the date on which La Fayette was married, at the residence of French Ambassador Jacques Andreani, the cooking school announced Friday. Patrick Martin, a chef who teaches at Le Cordon Bleu, is overseeing the preparation of the dinner. The menu will be selected from the original 200 dishes served when La Fayette, then 16, married Adrienne de Noailles. La Fayette ignored France's neutrality during the American Revolution and traveled to the United States, where he fought alongside the Americans. He gained the rank of major general and became a close friend of George Washington. Le Cordon Bleu was founded in 1895 as a cooking school for the cooks of wealthy French families.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Says It Will Use Military to Guard Borders
DOC.TEXT: The government intends to deploy the armed forces to halt the arrival of tens of thousands of illegal immigrants. The five-party governing coalition announced Friday that navy ships will patrol Italy's coasts, and army soldiers will be posted along the country's northeastern border. Italy has about 4,800 miles of coast and 600 miles of borderland. The government said the armed forces will work in collaboration with the police. In recent years, an estimated 100,000 illegal immigrants, mostly from Third World countries, have arrived in Italy each year, officials say. Estimates of the total number of illegal immigrants vary from 500,000 to 1.5 million. Italy has had difficulty absorbing the arrivals because of job and housing shortages, as well as inadequate public health and education services. There has been a recent wave of violence against immigrants, particularly in the popular tourist city of Florence.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Sour, Employees Sweet On UAL Buyout Plan
LaserPhotos CX1
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street is still waiting for assurance that the UAL Corp.'s $4.38 billion buyout will go through, but the company's employees say they're willing to accept the tough concessions that are part of the deal. The unions making the purchase have neither financing commitments nor a new management team, and some investors and analysts say they won't take the new deal seriously until those issues are nailed down. ``The question is, who is going to manage this thing and take it to the banks?'' said analyst Jack Hunter of Howe Barnes Investments Inc. in Chicago. Hunter said he believed the deal ultimately would go through, but another airlines analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity said the deal's chances were ``50-50 at best.'' Directors of UAL, the parent of United Airlines, announced an agreement in principle Friday to sell the nation's second-largest carrier to its 71,000 employees for cash and securities equal to $201 a share, which would create the country's largest worker-owned company. The stock market reflected investor skepticism the deal will be done. After a strong opening, UAL closed $2 lower at $163.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. The possibility the unions will dump UAL chairman and chief executive Stephen Wolf was seen by some observers as the biggest threat to a successful conclusion of the deal. Wolf is perceived as a capable airline manager despite his abrasive relations with the unions. Frederick Dubinsky, chairman of the United chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association, told a news conference in New York that Wolf would be replaced. ``It's our intention to put together a top-notch senior management team ... and that will include a new CEO,'' he said. But later in the day, union group spokesman Hank Krakowski said the group had made no such decision. ``Our position is we're not including or precluding anyone from any management team at this point,'' Krakowski said. The union group includes United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants unions, which together represent about two-thirds of UAL's employees. UAL will spin off to shareholders its entire 50 percent stake in Covia, which is co-owned by a consortium of five other airlines and operates an automated reservations system called Apollo. The agreement calls for employees to give up $2 billion in concessions over five years. The unions would sign five-year contracts with no-strike clauses. Other concessions include wage cuts of up to 7.69 percent for flight attendants and machinists and up to 11 percent for pilots. UAL's 25,700 non-union employees will negotiate their work conditions with the union group, said their lawyer, Stephen Fraidin. Under the agreement, the pilots would own 37.9 percent of UAL; machinists would own 35.7 percent, non-union employees about 14.3 percent and flight attendants about 12 percent, the unions said. The largest employee-owned company currently is Publix Inc., a supermarket chain based in Lakeland, Fla., with 50,000 employees, said Corey Rosen, executive director of the National Center for Employee Ownership in Oakland, Calif. Some UAL Corp. employees said they were prepared to accept the concessions that go along with the agreement. Frederick Dubinsky, head of United's pilot union, referred to the concessions as ``sweat equity'' and said there ``is no other decent alternative.'' ``I would be willing to give up money, myself,'' said Donna, a flight attendant interviewed at O'Hare International Airport who would not give her full name. ``Ten percent would be too much, 5 percent would hurt, but I would be willing to take it.'' ``We would never say no to job concessions,'' said another flight attendant from Denver. ``But you have to look at the whole benefits package, not just wages,'' she said. A 25-year United pilot from Washington D.C. said wage cuts should not go beyond about 10 percent, but added, ``Paywise, we will do everything we can to save the airline.''

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Quake in San Francisco Area Recalls Big World Series Temblor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with magnitude of latest quake set at 4.5, aftershock, reaction. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `Tracy Hein...
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake jolted the San Francisco Bay Area on Friday night, causing minor damage and jarring nerves during a baseball game that recalled the World Series contest stopped by last year's kller quake. The quake, which struck at 7:39 p.m. PDT, registered 4.5 on the Richter scale, according to a preliminary reading from the state Office of Emergency Services. That is considered strong enough to cause moderate damage in the immediate area. One of an afternoon-long series of tremors, it was centered near Danville, about 20 miles southeast of San Francisco and inland from San Francisco Bay. At Candlestick Park, where an exhibition ballgame between the San Francisco Giants and Oakland Athletics had just gotten underway, players and spectators seemed to momentarily stunned. ``Everybody sort of sat up and said, `No, that didn't happen. Did someone jump hard?''' said Bob Egelko, an Associated Press reporter who was covering the game. ``It looked like the players hesitated.'' The tremors were an eerie reminder of the devastating 7.1-magnitude quake that struck Northern California on Oct. 17, minutes before the start of the third game of the World Series between the Giants and the A's at Candlestick. That quake killed 67 people and did millions of dollars in property damage. Though the quake was felt over a wide area, there weren't any immediate reports of serious damage, said Chuck Young of the Office of Emergency Services. ``We queried all of the affected counties and they said the only real problem has been a slow dial tone on the phone,'' Young said. The 4.5-magnitude quake was followed at 7:51 p.m. with a tremor of magnitude 3.5, Young said. Several temblors centered in the Danville area shook San Francisco and its eastern suburbs through the afternoon, the biggest of magnitude 3.9 at 3:41 p.m. and of magnitude 3.5 at 1:55 p.m. Those were preliminary measurements by the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park. The afternoon quakes knocked objects from market shelves in several communities, and startled some shoppers into running from the stores. ``It was like the first one, a sharp, fast jolt and I felt a real tiny one after,'' said Sue Nicoles, administrative clerk at Heather Farms Community Center in Walnut Creek said of the largest temblor. ``I jumped right out of my chair, but it didn't last long enough for me to get under my desk, which would have been my next move,'' she said. An apparently unrelated quake of magnitude 4.1 shook a sparsely populated stretch of desert 450 miles to the southeast, near Indio at 6:07 p.m. Friday, said scientists at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. Authorities said there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. Tracy Hein of the Contra Costa County Office of Emergency Services in Danville described the afternoon temblor as ``a little joy ride, I'll tell you. It was more like a truck hitting the building.'' Customers at the Lucky supermarket in Walnut Creek ran out when cans and boxes tumbled from the shelves, said store manager Gary Earl. There wasn't any serious damage, he said. Bay Area Rapid Transit trains, which connect San Francisco with the suburbs across the bay, were halted for about five minutes as a precaution during the afternoon quake, said transit district spokesman Sy Mouber. The Richter scale is a gauge of energy released by an earthquake. Every increase of one number means the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of the magnitude 2 is the smallest normally felt by humans, a quake of 3.5 can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage.

DOC.HEAD: Redoubt Erupts Again; Pattern Set
DOC.TEXT: A new Redoubt eruption confirmed the pattern that geologists have observed in the seismic activity around the volcano over the past four months. Increasing tremors at the volcano's base heralded a moderate blast Friday from the 10,197-foot volcano about 110 miles southwest of Anchorage, said geologist Michael Doukas. The same earthquake pattern preceded moderate eruptions on March 23 and March 29. The latest eruption, at 5:23 p.m. ADT (9:23 p.m. EDT), sent ash 30,000 feet into the sky. It lasted eight minutes, according to a seismometer on Mount Spur, about 30 miles north of Redoubt. Previous eruptions have disrupted flights because the ash can ruin airplane engines. But the ash from Friday's blast was split by wind sheer and drifted in two directions, Doukas said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Eddie Murphy is sending a Michigan couple with 19 children on an all-expense-paid vacation to the Bahamas _ without the kids. ``It's like the honeymoon we never had,'' Diane Veasey, 35, said Friday. ``But I never dreamed of one like this.'' Murphy learned of the couple through an article in Jet magazine, said his publicist, Terrie Williams. Mrs. Veasey and her husband, Earl, the pastor of Hickory Grove Baptist Church in Flint, have been married 20 years and have 19 children from age 7 months through 20 years. ``Everybody asks if we planned to have a lot of kids way back in the beginning and I tell them no, we were just blessed,'' Mrs. Veasey said. The article said Veasey hoped one day to treat his wife to an exotic vacation. Murphy ``contacted the family and offered them first-class tickets to Nassau, the Bahamas, hotel, food and spending money,'' Williams said. ``His only stipulation is is if they conceive another child, they have to name it Eddie or some variation thereof.''

Actor Anthony Quinn says the owner of a Honolulu art gallery was the driving force behind his successful career as a painter. Quinn's videotaped testimony was played to jurors earlier this week on behalf of Center Art Gallery, which is accused of 79 counts of mail and wire fraud. The charges stem mainly from sales of art attributed to Salvador Dali. Two of the counts relate to art created by Quinn and comic Red Skelton. The indictment accuses Center Art of telling customers that Quinn supervised the production of his serigraphs. Quinn, 74, testified that he corrected preliminary prints in the production process but said he did not visit the California printing shop where they were made. Quinn said the limited-edition reproductions of his paintings sold by the gallery were made by him. He said he has been averaging about $400,000 a year from his art and credited gallery owner William Mett with helping him.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: k.d. is cq
DOC.TEXT: Grammy-winning singer k.d. Lang knows her androgynous appearance doesn't fit the usual mold of country music stars. In an interview for broadcast today on cable television, Lang says her appearance and manner ``became unprecedented for a woman in country to look and act.'' ``Their role is specifically set out,'' she said. ``Unfortunately everyone in country music today pretty much abides by those rules. And if they don't, they don't get played on the radio and they don't get (Country Music Association) nominations.'' Lang, who won a Grammy award in February, said she still admires country star Dolly Parton, whose appareance to some is the essence of femininity. ``To me, Dolly Parton is fine .. She created this thing and she's doing it,'' Lang said. Among Lang's hits are ``Crying,'' a duet with the late Roy Orbison, and ``Luck in my Eye.''

Willie Nelson, Jackson Browne and Bonnie Raitt were on tap for today's nationally televised Farm Aid concert to raise money for the American farmer. The concert, which has been dormant for the last two years, was organized by Nelson, John Mellencamp and Neil Young. About 60 acts were slated to perform, including Grammy winners Raitt, Don Henley and Lyle Lovett. The sellout crowd of 45,000 also was to hear Browne, Dwight Yoakum, K.T. Oslin, Lou Reed, Guns N' Roses, John Denver and a Soviet band called Gorky Park. The Nashville Network, a cable channel, was telecasting the full 12 hours live.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version of following also moved on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Aging Hall of Famer James ``Cool Papa'' Bell is missing baseball memorabilia worth an estimated $252,000, and police believe it might have been lost in a scam. Capt. Jack Titone said two men made several trips to Bell's home on Cool Papa Bell Avenue last month and through a combination of slick talk and intimidation, made off with uniforms, gloves, balls, bats, photos and other items. ``They took what they wanted,'' Titone said. Bell, 86, takes heart medication and is blind in one eye due to glaucoma. He said he was not up to resisting. ``He's a very sick man,'' said Bell's wife, Clarabelle, 81. Bell played 27 seasons in the Negro Leagues in the 1920s, 1930s and 1940s. He was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 1974.

You know how ``Mister Rogers'' would describe himself, don't you? Sure, I knew you did. The star of public television's ``Mister Rogers' Neighborhood'' said Friday he would consider himself a combination of ``Albert Schweitzer and Arsenio Hall.'' In his speech Friday at a National Press Club lunch, Rogers urged people to be better listeners, to ``try to understand what they've heard and then respond with all the creativity and care that their life has allowed them to develop.'' Rogers told the journalists and their children that he was concerned that much of what children see on television is ``very scary.'' He said parents should always sit with their children to interpret ``the horrendous stuff'' they see on TV news programs.

Singer Janis Ian and humorist Minnie Pearl will be honorary co-chairwomen of the 1990 AIDS walk. Ian will walk during the April 21 fund-raising event, spokesman Scott Stem said Friday. Miss Pearl will attend the opening but will not walk because of her heart condition. Miss Pearl has performed on the Grand Ole Opry since 1940. Ian's hit records include ``When the Party's Over'' and ``At Seventeen.''

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Cooking Video: Next Best Thing to Mama's Matzoh Balls
LaserPhoto PX2
DOC.TEXT: You don't have to celebrate Passover to love ``My First Jewish Cooking Video,'' says Mother Wonderful, creator of the cooking instructions blended with nostalgia, tradition and commentary. ``And what gives any family more pleasure than sitting down together to share a delicious Sabbath dinner?'' says Mother Wonderful _ whose real name is Myra Chanin _ as she introduces the 75-minute procession of cooks with their favorite secret recipes. And as the old ads for rye bread said, you don't have to be Jewish to enjoy it. ``The video gives non-Jewish people a feeling of that connection between food and love. This is the food and the tradition that produced a generation of doctors, lawyers and CPAs,'' Mrs. Chanin said. Actually, the video came out months ago, but Mrs. Chanin held off publicizing it too much at first. ``I wanted to make sure Jewish people liked it,'' she said. ``I didn't want them all hating the video when I went out promoting it. Those little old ladies, they're worse than muggers!'' Every recipe is kosher for Passover, except the challah, a braided, leavened bread. The video offers recipes for gefilte fish, horseradish, chicken soup, matzoh balls, latke, baked chicken and vegetable kugel. For dessert there are tasty meringue and raspberry sorbet. The video crew took no chances about making a slip that would violate Jewish dietary laws, Mrs. Chanin said. ``We had a kosher maven there for all the taping,'' she said. ``Anyone kosher who wants to use it, they can.'' Mrs. Chanin thinks the traditional meals are making a comeback. ``The reason people are very taken with the old foods is they really miss the sense of community that existed with them. There was tremendous feeling in those dinners _ love, competition, all those things.'' Mrs. Chanin, who's quick with one-liners, said she didn't really learn to cook until she left home and decided good cooking was part of the way to win a husband. ``We all say the way to a man's heart is through his stomach, because we know it's not through his brains,'' she said. ``Yes, the way to a man's heart is through his stomach, or somewhere around there.'' Her own mother did wonderful things with food, Mrs. Chanin said. ``I still find that the dishes I cook today that really knock people out are her recipes,'' she said. Mrs. Chanin immortalized her mother with a lighthearted book: ``Jewish Penicillin or Mother Wonderful's Profusely Illustrated Guide to the Proper Preparation of Chicken Soup.'' It shows her mother matching wits with a butcher, persuading him to give her some extra feet for her soup pot to help the flavor; cleaning and re-rinsing everything. ``My mother always wanted me to write something like `War and Peace,''' Mrs. Chanin said. `I'm sure she never expected to be immortalized by a book that showed her holding a dead chicken by its feet.''

DOC.HEAD: Three of Four Crow Tribal Leaders Convicted of Conspiracy and Bank Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Three leaders of the Crow Indian tribe were convicted of fraudulently convincing two banks to approve loans that one of the leaders has not repaid. A fourth defendant was acquitted. A U.S. District Court jury Friday convicted tribal Chairman Richard Real Bird, Theodore Hogan and Willie Stewart Jr. on charges of conspiracy, bank fraud and lying on a loan application. Robert S. Howe was acquitted of the same charges. U.S. District Judge David Ezra let the three tribal leaders remain free on bond until sentencing July 17. Each faces up to 12 years in prison and fines up to $25,000. The charges were part of a grand jury indictment that named 26 tribal leaders on a total of 37 counts. Thirteen more trials _ about half of which probably will include Real Bird _ are scheduled throughout the summer. Assistant U.S. Attorney Carl Rostad had charged that the defendants misled the Little Horn State Bank in Hardin and First Citizens Bank in Billings into approving loans in 1986 for Hogan, who was deeply in debt. Rostad said the defendants told the banks the tribe would pay Hogan $296,500 for land they knew already had been foreclosed on. The banks have not been paid, Rostad said, and Hogan's land, which is near the Custer Battlefield National Monument in southeastern Montana, eventually was sold to a non-tribal member. Real Bird testified that the Bureau of Indian Affiars is holding $38 million in coal taxes for the tribe. He said the defendants, acting on the approval of a BIA employee, believed that money would be available to pay Hogan, who then could repay the loans. ``We've said the defendants' wrongs were not affected by whatever the BIA did or didn't do,'' Rostad said. ``Apparently, the jury thought so as well.'' But Real Bird's lawyer, Rodney Shepherd, said, ``This as much of a travesty as when the white man took everything from these people except their pride. ``Now, I guess they're trying to take that, too.''

DOC.HEAD: IRS Chief Says Agency Committed to Taxpayer Rights; Some Skeptical
DOC.TEXT: Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. says the Internal Revenue Service is firmly committed to safeguarding taxpayers' rights, but critics say the word has not filtered down to some agents in the field. David Keating, executive vice president of the National Taxpayers Union, told a Senate Finance subcommittee Friday that the situation could get worse as budget shortages increase pressure on the IRS to boost collections. ``As marching orders filter through the bureaucracy, each management layer tends to rewrite the orders stronger, to ensure that the field troops fully understand the new mission,'' Keating said. ``The result may well be that IRS employees could take a much tougher stand with taxpayers, causing more violations of the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.'' Goldberg, testifying at a hearing on how the taxpayer protection law is being implemented, acknowledged that his agency's 120,000 employees make mistakes. But overall, he said, the new law is working; ``We are indeed making a great deal of progress.'' ``Whether a taxpayer is due a refund, owes the government taxes, is being audited, or is asking us a question, that individual deserves to be treated fairly and with respect,'' Goldberg said. ``That is the fundamental right taxpayers should expect and they should receive nothing less.'' The Taxpayer Bill of Rights was enacted in 1988 in response to complaints about the behavior of some IRS employees and what Congress viewed as a tendency to intimidate citizens. The law, for example, requires the IRS to spell out clearly any demand for taxes due; prohibits the agency from rewarding employees on the basis of how much tax they collect, and makes it more difficult for the IRS to seize a person's property for nonpayment of taxes. Kay M. Council of High Point, N.C., told the subcommittee that after a long battle with the IRS, her husband killed himself so she could use his $250,000 insurance policy to continue the fight. ``Alex is dead because of the IRS's arrogance and incompetence,'' she contended. The Councils' problem grew out of a $70,000 tax-shelter deduction they claimed on their 1979 tax return and which the IRS rejected. After Alex Council's death in 1988, a federal court ruled that the couple owed no back taxes because the IRS's notice of deficiency had been sent four months after the statute of limitations had expired. Keating, of the National Taxpayers Union, said it is unlikely that the Bill of Rights would have helped the Councils. Although the legislation allows a taxpayer to sue for damages if the IRS acts recklessly or intentionally breaks a law, it does not permit a suit for careless actions. ``Was the IRS treatment of the Council family careless and negligent? Absolutely,'' Keating said. ``Was it reckless or intentional? It might have been, but that is a very difficult standard to prove.'' The U.S. Chamber of Commerce said the new law ``appears to have had a major positive impact on the relationship between taxpayers and the IRS.'' ``While we get plenty of telephone calls complaining about compliance burdens, complexity and substantive tax provisions, telephone calls from chamber small-business members facing immediate and unwarranted levy on (seizing) their house or business or similar serious problems have declined noticeably,'' said David R. Burton, manager of the chamber's tax policy center. Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., chairman of the subcommittee and chief author of the Taxpayer Bill of Rights, said the recent complaint of an Arkansas businessman probably sums up how most Americans view the IRS. ``It's not that I have a problem with paying the IRS every shiny nickel I owe the government, and it's not that I begrudge them getting tough with me if I don't pay,'' the businessman said. ``What I resent is when they bury me in computer letters, don't even acknowledge my explanations, then grab my bank account and ruin my credit, and only then decide they were wrong after all.'' IRS Commissioner Goldberg said much the same thing: ``We need as an agency to learn to ... stand in the other guy's shoes.''

DOC.HEAD: President to Sign Executive Order Protecting Chinese Students
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he will sign an executive order that he earlier promised _ and in fact claimed to have issued _ protecting Chinese students from deportation. Aides said Bush will release the order, probably early next week, incorporating provisions of an informal directive he had issued on dealing with Chinese who feared for their safety if sent home when their visas expired. Many had supported the now-suppressed democracy movement. The president said his order also will ``extend the deferral of enforced departure for Chinese nationals, which is currently scheduled to expire on June 5 of this year, through Jan. 1, 1994.'' Reacting to criticism that he has failed to issue the executive order he promised last year, Bush said Friday: ``I did say I was going to have an executive order. What we had was an executive directive from the president'' that had ``precisely the same legal effect as an executive order.'' The president had promised the executive order when he vetoed congressional legislation Nov. 30 that was designed to protect the students from deportation. He viewed the legislation as an infringement on presidential powers, but pledged at the time that, in the face of harsh reprisals by the Beijing government against democracy advocates, no Chinese student would be forced to go home against his or her will. The president has since said that he issued an executive order. But instead it was a directive, and ``to allay any concerns'' Bush said Friday he will now put it in the form of an executive order. ``We don't want to take a chance on people being mistreated, brutalized,'' he said in a question-and-answer session to the American Society of Newspaper Editors that also focused on his upcoming summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. On another topic, Bush said he will soon announce a policy banning offshore oil drilling in some environmentally sensitive areas and redefining sea lanes for tankers in others, such as the Florida Everglades. The president last year ordered a task force to study offshore drilling, with an eye to environmental protection. He has yet to announce the findings of the study or any policy moves. Bush, a former Texas oilman, said he opposes a permanent ban on offshore drilling ``because then I would be compelled to ask the question where do we get the energy to keep this country going. I don't think there should be a ban.'' However, he added, ``there will definitely be bans on certain environmentally sensitive areas.'' Touching on other matters, Bush said: _He ``knew nothing about'' the meeting between former President Carter and Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat this week. He said Carter was ``not acting with the blessing of, nor disapproval of, or anything else of the administration,'' but ``certainly a former president should be free to do his thing.'' _He is not linking aid to Israel to U.S. hopes that Israel works out a negotiating format for peace with Palestinians. _He hoped a compromise budget plan could be drafted to reduce the huge federal deficit, but he noted that one congressional deadline had already been missed and another was fast approaching.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Mujahedeen Turn Surrender Ceremony into Pitched Battle
DOC.TEXT: A ceremony for the surrender of 10,000 Afghan guerrillas turned into a surprise attack in which rebels shot to death at least two Afghan generals, according to news reports and sources. Rebel sources said Friday's attack near the western Afghan city of Herat was planned five months ago. It apparently was in revenge for a similar deadly trick by government forces 11 years ago. The exact number of casualties was not known. Western diplomats in Pakistan said on condition of anonymity they had reports that up to five Afghan generals were killed or wounded in the 15-minute gun battle and in hand-to-hand combat with knives and pistols. They also said civilians, including children, died in the fighting on the plains outside Herat, about 400 miles west of the Afghan capital of Kabul. Government-run Radio Kabul said ``numerous'' people were killed, including Lt. Gen. Jalal Razaminda, a second unidentified general, civilians and nine guerrillas. The guerrillas had said they would give up their weapons and support the national reconcilation policy of Soviet-backed President Najib. The government uses the term ``national reconcilation'' to signify agreement by local guerrilla groups to switch sides and either stop fighting or help the Marxist government in the war it has fought with rebels since seizing power in a 1978 coup. The government says tens of thousands of rebels have laid down their weapons in the past year. But this time, said the Jamait-i-Islami guerrilla organization, it was all a trick to trap government forces. Jamiat-i-islami is considered the most militarily efficient of the seven Afghan guerrilla groups and the dominant one in the Herat area. The rebels are supported by the United States and Saudi Arabia and operate from bases in Pakistan. They call themselves mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors. Rebel sources in the southeastern Pakistani town of Quetta, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said rebels slowly began infiltrating the Herat area in November and recently notified the government that they wanted to give up the fight. According to Radio Kabul, 2,200 armed guerrillas and 8,000 unarmed rebels gathered on the plains about 25 miles from Herat for the surrender ceremony. But the guerrillas _ with weapons ranging from side arms to recoilless cannons, missiles and rocket launchers _ fired at government officials and soldiers instead of laying down their arms. Western diplomats and rebel laders said the guerrillas fired the first shot when the provincial governor, Fazle Haq Khaliq Yaar, embraced an unidentified guerrilla commander dressed in a white robe and turban. They said the governor's guards immediately returned fire and the ceremony became a pitched battle, with huge exchanges of gunfire. The diplomats said several civilians, including children, were killed in the cross-fire, which stopped when two Afghan army tanks moved in with bursts of fire. Kabul radio's version of the fighting was: ``A small group of extremists attacked the welcoming ceremony with heavy fire. In the resulting battle between Afghan troops and extremists, numerous people were martyred.'' An Afghan national TV photographer was reported shot in the head and badly wounded. Herat was the first region in Afghanistan to rise against the Soviet Union in early 1979 before the Red Army stepped in to bolster the Marxist government. At least 2,000 Afghans were reported to have died when government forces pretended to join the insurrection against growing Soviet influence and killed protesters. The Soviet Union withdrew its troops in February 1989 but still sends huge quantities of supplies and weapons to the Kabul government.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Lauds Accord, But Says Implementation Will be True Test
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is praising Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu for exhibiting political courage in championing a major trade agreement, but warning that the true test will come in implementation of the pact. Bush lauded Kaifu for the success he achieved in the month since the two leaders met in California to discuss trade tensions arising from this country's huge $49 billion deficit with Japan. ``For the first time, Japan has committed to removing a broad array of structural barriers that constrain trade and impede imports,'' Bush said in an appearance Friday before the American Society of Newspaper Editors. But he said actual results would be what counted. ``Neither the Japanese consumer nor the American people will be convinced that progress is at hand until they see concrete results,'' Bush said. After four days of marathon negotiations, the United States and Japan reached agreement late Thursday on a set of proposals aimed at correcting broad-based structural barriers to trade in both countries. Japan promised to take a series of steps to make it easier for Americans and other foreigners to do business in Japan. U.S. negotiators pledged to boost America's ability to compete internationally by improving the education system, increasing savings and reducing the federal budget deficit. But U.S. trade specialists expressed doubts Friday over how far the Japanese will go in implementing the accord, especially in light of strong political resistance to some of the measures in Tokyo. A major Japanese retailers' group vowed to fight a key provision of the pact designed to relax restrictions on establishment of large retail stores in the country. Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., who was a top trade negotiator in the Reagan administration, said the latest agreement bore many similarities to other accords dating back to 1984 and earlier that had failed to open Japan's markets. ``These talks are always presented as a final solution to the problem,'' he said. ``We keep claiming victory, victory and nothing much happens.'' In a sign that Kaifu faces major political obstacles in implementing the agreement, Japan's Federation of Specialty Stores Associations charged that a key provision relaxing restrictions on opening large stores would hurt small shop owners. The 50,000-member association of small retailers vowed to ``do our best to prevent the decisions from being enforced.'' U.S. negotiators viewed shortening of the time for opening large stores as a major victory because it would open the way for large American and other foreign retailers to set up operations. One of the beneficiaries is expected to be the Toys ``R'' Us chain. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said she believed the pessimists predicting failure for the new trade accord would be proven wrong because of a new climate of public opinion in Japan. She cited polls that found Japanese consumers upset by high prices and lack of competition. Mrs. Hills said the administration intends to keep lobbying for results as negotiators work to prepare a final report on structural trade barriers that is due in July. Even after that time, she said, the administration will keep monitoring progress to make sure that the commitments made by Japan are being met. ``This is a good first step. It constitutes a clear blueprint of reform that will facilitate market opening,'' Mrs. Hills said at a news briefing. ``Obviously, we want results and if they don't occur, we would be disappointed.'' She refused to speculate about whether the administration will target Japan as an unfair trader in a second round of negotiations. The administration must decide on that issue by April 30. Many in Congress viewed the increased willingness of Japan to negotiate agreements as an attempt to escape being targeted again, but Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., urged Bush in a letter to once again target Japan in order to keep up the pressure. ``I believe strongly that a failure to designate Japan will seriously jeopardize the credibility of U.S. trade policy,'' Danforth wrote.

DOC.HEAD: `Phantom Head' Headed Back into Space
DOC.TEXT: It's known by NASA as the ``Phantom Head,'' a human skull filled with sensors to measure the dose of space radiation that astronauts receive. The skull goes into space aboard the shuttle Discovery for the third and probably last time Tuesday. Its keeper in orbit, astronaut Kathryn Sullivan, hopes the trip will put an end to all jokes about the ``phantom passenger.'' ``It's not a passenger. It's a device, actually a very sophisticated one and one that has considerable potential to provide some very significant data to all of the people within NASA who are trying to measure crew health,'' she said. The head is crammed with instruments that bring its weight to more than 20 pounds, and covered with a black plastic material simulating human skin. It contains as many as 600 tiny measuring devices called dosimeters. As in the two previous missions, the skull will be mounted to a wall in the shuttle middeck near the lower end of an astronaut sleeping bag. It will be kept in a fire-retardant bag. ``It's not like it's hooked there staring at people,'' said NASA spokesman Brian Welch. The skull will help scientists determine how much radiation penetrates the astronauts heads when they are in space. Such data may be crucial for planning extended space station missions and lengthy stays on the moon and Mars. ``It would be medically irresponsible to commit crews to some of the high-flown ideas we have without understanding their safety,'' Sullivan said. The skull is one of 11 devices inside Discovery that will monitor various kinds of radiation in space. Although the radiation-monitoring devices do not rival the sophisticiation of Discovery's primary payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, they are equally important to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said Gautam Badhwar, the Johnson Space Center physicist in charge of the experiment. ``Hubble has a very fundamental importance in terms of astronomy and how we understand the solar system and the universe around us, whereas the radiation experiments are much more local,'' he said. ``They are designed for the safety of the astronauts for both today and for future flights.'' The skull first went into space on a Defense Department flight in August, but its existence was not acknowleged until after a second secret military mission, that of the Atlantis, ended March 4. The space agency plans to send an entire human torso into space but not until the current data is analyzed further, Badhwar said. Data collected from the Atlantis mission still is being studied, Badhwar said. But results from the skull's first venture into space indicate there is twice as much neutron radiation in an orbiting shuttle than NASA had expected at high energy levels. The extra radiation poses no danger to astronauts, Badhwar said. Welch said NASA decided to send the skull, or DSO469 as it's formally known, on Discovery's five-day flight because the shuttle will ascend to 380 miles, the highest a shuttle has ever gone.

DOC.HEAD: Arms Control Accords Remain Elusive After Shevardnadze Visit
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union head for a superpower summit in seven weeks still divided on major nuclear arms control issues but hoping that more talks next month will produce the ``hard decisions'' needed to weld agreement. Secretary of State James A. Baker III did use three days of meetings with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze this week to deliver repeated warnings of the consequences of employing Moscow's military weight to crush Lithuania's fervor for independence. And both nations took a new look at how a unified Germany will fit into the European community, making no effort to disguise fundamental differences on how that fit eventually will be made. Baker and Shevardnadze acted to lower expectations that President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev actually will be able to sign a treaty sharply reducing intercontinental nuclear weapons when they meet here beginning May 30. But the two did hold out hope that all or most major issues may be resolved by then, leaving the actual signing of a treaty to await a celebration summit later in the year. Baker, speaking to reporters before a backdrop of 14 American and Soviet flags, said he and Shevardnadze failed to resolve differences over air-launched and sea-launched cruise missiles, two obstacles for agreement on a Strategic Arms Reduction treaty. ``That is a disappointment,'' he said. Shevardnadze, holding a separate news conference in the same State Department auditorium, said: ``I would not hide from you the fact that ... we have encountered certain difficulties, certain problems'' in concluding a strategic arms treaty. ``This is a time of hard choices, the hard choices that one has to make in the concluding stages of the talks,'' the foreign minister said. He said the problem is compounded by the need to write a treaty that will be ratified by the newly independent Soviet parliament acting in much the same way as the U.S. Senate considers international accords. But Shevardnadze predicted: ``In the end there will be real certainty that we will have a solid agreement, a durable agreement.'' Baker and Shevardnadze will hold another round of talks in the Soviet Union on May 16-19 to try to settle the nuclear-weapons issues. ``It's still our hope that major issues will be resolved by the summit, but that's got to take a lot of work,'' Baker said. He also said divisions remain on key elements of an agreement to reduce conventional, non-nuclear military forces in Europe, especially on how to deal with aircraft. Bush met with Shevardnadze for about two hours and joined Baker in warning that crushing the independence drive in Lithuania would chill superpower relations. ``I don't think we are telling them what to do; we're telling them what not to do _ and that is, don't use force,'' the president told the American Society of Newspaper Editors later. Baker said he raised the issue of Lithuania with Shevardnadze on each of the three days, delivering ``very serious and candid'' warnings. But he said there does seem to be hope for a peaceful resolution in Shevardnadze's repeated commitment to peaceful dialogue and both sides' apparent interest in some sort of referendum on the issue. Baker also said the furor may be dampened by the decision of Lithuanian leaders to draw back from a headlong rush to independence by indicating that a more gradual step-by-step process might be acceptable. Shevardnadze said, ``We have a clear conscience'' on Lithuania and that he does not believe the controversy should damage U.S.-Soviet relations. Baker said Moscow had dropped its insistence that a reunified Germany be neutral, recognizing that ``is perhaps not the best route to go.'' But both he and Shevardnadze made clear that sharp disagreement remains over U.S. insistence that a unified German nation retain West Germany's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``We have to look for a solution, a solution that would be acceptable'' to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, Shevardnadze said. He did not offer any specifics, beyond a suggestion that perhaps the merged country could be part both of NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Baker displayed no enthusiasm for the idea.

DOC.HEAD: Many States Experiencing Budget Crunch, Survey Finds
DOC.TEXT: States are getting poorer, forcing governors to respond with budget cuts, a freeze on new programs and calls for higher taxes, a survey says. Twenty states have either proposed or already cut spending in budgets previously enacted, compared with eight this time a year ago, the study by two associations said Friday. The report blamed worsening state finances on increased spending for Medicaid, education, prisons and transportation _ problems it traced in part to federal requirements or spending cutbacks. The fiscal survey of the states is taken twice yearly by the National Governors' Association and the National Association of State Budget Officers. The financial outlook for states has become so bleak, the report said, that governors are even willing to propose taxes in an election year. ``Large tax proposals are not commonly enacted in years corresponding with gubernatorial elections,'' the report said. ``Fiscal 1991 is such a year. Thirty-six governors' races will be decided in November 1990.'' While 21 governors have proposed tax increases, New Jersey and New York would account for more than 50 percent of the $4.9 billion raised if the new revenues were enacted, the survey found. Most governors have proposed 1991 spending increases of 5 percent to 10 percent, the report said. ``This range of increases suggests that states will be continuing current programs, but not adding new initiatives,'' said Gerald H. Miller, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers. Total state year-end balances, which registered a record high of $12.6 billion last year, are projected to drop to $8.3 billion by the end of 1990, the survey found. The study said the ``most significant personal income tax proposals'' were made in Kentucky, New York and Oklahoma. Eight states have proposed sales tax increases, with New Jersey seeking to raise more than $1 billion by boosting the rate from 6 percent to 7 percent, and by removing some exemptions. Rate boosts also are under consideration in New Mexico and Oklahoma. Five states have asked for business tax increases, with the largest hike proposed in New York. Nine states want cigarette tax increases, led by Florida's plan to raise $259 million in new revenue. Four states want higher motor fuel taxes, with Ohio and Washington proposing the largest increases. Four states seek to increase taxes on alcohol.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Airlines Gets OK to Sell Foreign Routes to American
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines has government permission to sell its key international routes to American Airlines under a plan that Eastern officials say is key to the future of the troubled carrier. The Transportation Department on Friday tentatively approved the transfer of Eastern's South and Central American routes, along with a Miami-Madrid route, to American. It also approved sale of a Continental Airlines Miami-London route to American as part of the same package. Eastern and Continental both are owned by Texas Air Corp. But the department stalled a proposal to turn over Eastern's only remaining Canadian route, from Miami and Tampa, Fla., to Toronto. It said further study would determine whether that could go to American or another carrier. The $349 million sale is central to Eastern's plans to rebuild under the direction of a bankruptcy court from the effects of a year-old Machinists union strike. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland last month approved the proposed sale of Eastern's Latin American routes and related assets. The Transportation Department approval is temporary, and would not become final until after a 10-day period to allow for objections to the deal and responses from the airlines. While the government awards routes to carriers on the basis of public interest and must approve all transfers of service, it allows the airlines to treat their routes as assets that can be bought and sold. In approving the joint application by Eastern, Continental and American, the department said the transfer was in the public interest and did not conflict with ``important international aviation policy objectives.'' It noted that the carriers maintained that the transfer of the routes was essential to the viability of Eastern and that American's acquisition would continue the service. The order also said the government determined that the transfer would not reduce competition and ``indeed will, in many respects, improve it.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows Documentary on Custody Case to Air
DOC.TEXT: A cable telecast of a documentary about an international child custody battle went on as scheduled, only minutes after a federal appeals court overturned a ban on the broadcast. A three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals on Friday night vacated an order that Dr. Eric Foretich had obtained hours earlier in U.S. District Court barring broadcast of ``Hilary in Hiding,'' a British Broadcasting Corp. documentary about his 7-year-old daughter, Hilary. The program was aired Friday night on the Lifetime cable network, whose executives had appealed the ruling of District Judge Stanley Sporkin. The documentary chronicled the girl's odyssey with her maternal grandparents that took her from northern Virginia to England to New Zealand during her father's attempts to have unsupervised visits with her. Foretich's lawyer, Elaine Mittleman, argued that the program contained a segment that included footage of the girl during therapy sessions. She said that showing the scenes would have violated the child's constitutionally guaranteed right to privacy. The girl's mother, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, sent the child into hiding after a District of Columbia Superior Court judge ordered her to allow Foretich unsupervised visits with the girl. Morgan claimed that her former husband had sexually assaulted the child, a charge that Foretich denies. Morgan spent almost two years in jail for contempt.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agency Investigates Greyhound Shootings
DOC.TEXT: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms says it is investigating the two dozen shootings that have occurred in the five-week-old Greyhound strike. ``We believe the public safety is at stake in the random shootings directed toward passenger-occupied Greyhound buses. The potential for disaster is considerable,'' Stephen Higgins, the bureau's director, said Friday. The agency also will conduct an arson investigation into a fire at a Greyhound garage in Boston Wednesday night that caused $250,000 in damage, Higgins said. The agency ``has no involvement nor interest in the strike,'' he said. Special agents in each of the bureau's 22 district offices will serve as ``coordinators'' with the bus company on the investigations. In a statement, Higgins urged anyone with information to call the company's hotline for reporting suspects. Nick Nichols, a spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, said the union welcomed the government's involvement. Richard Cook, head of the bureau's firearms division, said agents had been working with Greyhound officials on the shootings but had not gotten involved at the company's request. ``We're investigating it because it's a violation of the gun control act. We would be investigating it if there weren't a strike and independent of anything Greyhound asked for,'' Cook said. FBI agents are involved only on a limited basis in some cases, said spokesman Mike Kortan. Also Friday, union president Jim La Sala wrote Greyhound's board of directors, asking board members to pressure company officials to resume negotiations. About 6,300 Greyhound drivers and 3,000 maintenance and other workers walked out March 2 over wages and job security. Talks between Greyhound Lines Inc. and the union have been stalled since March 18, and the company said it won't return to the bargaining table until a week goes by without any acts of violence. There have been nearly 30 shootings and more than 100 bomb threats, the company said. The union contends there have been more than 60 incidents of violence against striking workers. One striker was crushed to death by a bus in Redding, Calif., on March 2. Greyhound, the nation's only nationwide bus system, has been operating on a reduced schedule with replacement drivers and union members who crossed the picket line.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Lagged in Notifying Cheney of Off-Target Bomb
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force waited months before notifying Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that one of two F-117A Stealth jet fighter-bombers used in the Panama invasion dropped a bomb ``way off target,'' his spokesman says. Meanwhile, Cheney repeatedly touted the ``pinpoint accuracy'' of the futuristic F-117A planes despite the incident during the Dec. 20 attack. Cheney's spokesman, Pete Williams, also was kept ignorant of the error until after he disclosed new information about the long-classified aircraft at a Pentagon press briefing Tuesday. In the days following the U.S. invasion, Pentagon officials said the high-tech planes were used for the first time in combat _ dropping 2,000-pound bombs near a Panamanian Defense Forces barracks in order to stun and confuse the troops as U.S. paratroopers landed in a nearby airfield. But Williams confirmed Friday that one of the planes actually dropped its bomb some distance away, due to an apparent pilot error. ``The pilots were told to drop their bombs no closer than 50 meters'' from two separate PDF barracks buildings, Williams said. But due to a last-minute misunderstanding between the pilots, the second F-117A dropped its bomb on a hillside some distance away, Williams said. ``The first bomb hit 55 meters from one of the barracks, but the second bomb was way off target,'' Williams said. Williams also acknowledged that despite weeks of preparation for his F-117A briefing on Tuesday _ in which he disclosed long-classified details about the radar-evading fighter-bomber _ ``I didn't know'' about the bombing mistake. ``It was news to us,'' Williams said on Friday about the disclosure in The New York Times and the trade publication Aerospace Daily, that one of the F-117As had missed its intended target by over 300 yards. Williams said neither he, nor Cheney, knew about the pilot's error until after they were questioned about an off-target bomb crater by New York Times correspondent Michael Gordon, who had a photograph of it. Asked when the Air Force informed him and Cheney, Williams said they were not told about the mistake until Tuesday afternoon, after the F-117A briefing took place. ``We all know now. We all found out about the same time,'' he said. Air Force spokeswoman Capt. Susan Strednansky explained the lapse by saying that there was ``apparently some confusion regarding the exact impact of the bomb coming up the chain of command.'' She said Air Force officials were looking into the matter to try to explain the confusion. She said there was no attempt by Air Force military or civilian leaders to keep anything from Cheney. Williams said it now appears that the problem centered on a misunderstanding between the lead pilot in the two-aircraft bombing formation and the second pilot, known as the wingman. As the planes closed in the on barracks, the lead pilot was supposed to drop a bomb on a field near a barracks on the left, while the wingman was supposed to drop a bomb on a field near a barracks located to the right of it. Because of a change in wind direction, however, the lead pilot told his wingman to exchange targets with him, Williams said. However, the lead pilot didn't do as he said he would, and for some unexplained reason dropped his bomb on his original target. The wingman then adjusted his target even further to the left, believing that the lead pilot had followed the changed plans. But that meant the wingman hit a hillside some distance away instead of his original target, located to the right of the target hit by the lead pilot, Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Says Tests Show Fisheries Not Threatened by Oil Spill
DOC.TEXT: Last year's Exxon Valdez oil spill is unlikely to cause long-term harm to fish and other organisms in Prince William Sound, Exxon Corp. said in a report. Toxins from the nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil spilled in March 1989 were in proportions low enough not to threaten fish, plankton and sea mammals, according to the report Friday. ``The tainting problem is just not there. It's good news to the fishermen,'' Jerry M. Neff of Battelle, the Ohio-based company that conducted the study commissioned by Exxon. State officials said they were skeptical. ``It's an example of taking a part of the environment and saying `Well, this little part is clean and therefore doesn't it follow there isn't any damage and there shouldn't be any concern?''' said Joe Ferguson, a spokesman for the Departmant of Environmental Conservation. The Exxon Valdez oil tanker went aground on Bligh Reef near Valdez on March 24, 1989. In the months following the disaster, oil coated hundreds of miles of shoreline and killed countless birds, otters and other sea mammals. The study involved 2,300 water samples taken from locations throughout Prince William Sound, starting one week after the spill and extending through October, according to the report accompanying it. Samples mostly came from shallow areas of the water column _ the portion of water between the ocean bottom and 3 to 9 feet below the water's surface, Neff said. Scientists found that the level of toxins from the crude oil _ including benzene and xylene _ fell rapidly in the weeks and months after the spill and were not sufficient to affect fish, plants or animals. The report did not attempt to assess contamination or its effects at the ocean bottom or at the surface. ``We are encouraged by the results of this report and hope that those people most intimately linked with the water quality of Prince William Sound are equally encouraged,'' said Exxon spokesman Karsten Rodvik. But Ferguson said the report showed Exxon was more interested in public relations than in sharing data about contamination from the spill. The report was designed ``to diminish and lessen peoples' perception of what might be wrong,'' he said. The report said thin sheens of weathered crude found on the surface of the water in some spots pose no threat to either fish or animals below or on the surface. But state scientists who have analyzed the effects of the spill and who had seen the Battelle report said shoreline contamination, and not the water column, is the real problem, Ferguson said. Jack Lamb, vice president of Cordova District Fishermen's United, said the study would ``ease a lot of the concerns.'' But the report said pollution was highest last April and May, when the fry were leaving streams and estuaries and feeding on plankton as they headed for the open ocean. ``We're still going to have concerns about how that affected the outgoing fry,'' Lamb said.

DOC.HEAD: Intelligence Officials Say Chemical Plant Fire Was A Fake
DOC.TEXT: U.S. authorities now believe a fire at a Libyan chemical plant was a hoax since satellite photographs show that burn marks were painted on the building, The Washington Post reports. ``It clearly was an attempt at deception,'' an unidentified senior intelligence official told the newspaper in a story published in today's editions. ``It's not particularly well done.'' The United States accused Libya of producing poison gas at the plant. The Libyans, who said the plant produced medicine, accused the United States and other countries of being responsible for setting it on fire in early March. By the end of last month, U.S. officials were saying that the damage at the plant was not as extensive as previously believed. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said then that the possibility of a fake fire could not be ruled out. Nevertheless, intelligence officials cited by the Post said they did not think the plant near Rabta would be returning to production soon. ``They're not going to do anything while the rest of the world is looking,'' an official told the newspaper. ``It's going to remain static as long as the heat's on.''

DOC.HEAD: FDA to Issue Aspirin Warnings for Pregnant Women
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration says new warnings will be required on over-the-counter aspirin products advising women in the last three months of pregnancy not to use the products unless directed by a physician. Aspirin late in pregnancy can affect fetal circulation and uterine contractions and cause excessive bleeding during delivery, an FDA spokeswoman said Friday. A third-trimester pregnancy warning is already required on non-prescription ibuprofen products. Acting FDA Commissioner James Benson detailed the agency's plans in a March 29 letter to Thomas Warriner, under secretary of the California Health and Welfare Agency. Benson said he was aware of the state's interest in preparing a similar warning under Proposition 65, California's anti-toxics law, and wanted officials there to know FDA's plans. Benson said the warning would likely be similar to the ibuprofen warning, which says: ``It is especially important not to use ibuprofen during the last three months of pregnancy unless specifically directed to do so by your doctor because it may cause problems in the unborn child or complications during delivery.'' The warning would take effect immediately and companies would have one year to make the label changes, he said. Aspirin labels already advise pregnant women and nursing mothers to get the advice of a health professional before using the product.
DOC.HEAD: Suspended Sentences Ordered in Pentagon Document Case
DOC.TEXT: Two RCA Corp. employees who pleaded guilty to obtaining and transporting classified Pentagon budget documents have been sentenced to two years imprisonment, with all but a few months suspended. U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris in Alexandria, Va., handed down the sentences to Ronald B. Stevens and Leonard C. Kampf on Friday. Stevens and Kampf had pleaded guilty Feb. 5, the same day RCA Corp. pleaded guilty and paid $2.5 million to cover criminal and civil liabilities. The cases stemmed from an investigation into trafficking in classified documents by major Defense Department contractors. Stevens, a manager of marketing services at RCA's Aerospace and Defense Division in Cherry Hill, N.J., was sentenced to two years imprisonment with all but two months suspended, and 100 hours of community service. He also was placed on one year of supervised probation and fined $3,000. Kampf, who was employed as manager of marketing information and communications in RCA's Government Systems Division in Cherry Hill until his retirement in 1984, was sentenced to two years imprisonment, with all but four months suspended, and 100 hours of community service. In addition, he was placed on one year of supervised probation and fined $5,000. The two had faced up to 10 years in prison.
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Formally Filing Complaint Against Stangeland
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota Democrats are formally asking the House to investigate allegations that Rep. Arlan Stangeland, R-Minn., improperly charged Congress for hundreds of phone calls to and from the home of a woman lobbyist. The complaint being filed with the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct also accuses Stangeland of exchanging favors with a former congressman who now works as a lobbyist. The allegations were made public in newspaper articles last January. Stangeland, who is seeking re-election, has denied any impropriety. ``I don't think the questions have been answered,'' Ruth Stanoch, chairwoman of the Minnesota Democratic Party, said Friday. ``They're still lingering right now.'' Stangeland has said he welcomed the ethics investigation even though he believed it was unnecessary. Stangeland says that his relationship with Eve Jarvis, who now works for the House of Representatives, was professional, although he acknowledged making 341 calls to or from her home during five months in 1986 and 1987. Ms. Jarvis has refused to talk to reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Nepal at a Glance
With PM-Nepal, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Nepal:

THE PEOPLE _ Hindus comprise 90 percent of Nepal's 17 million people; 5 percent are Moslem and 3 percent are Buddhist. Nepalese law forbids Hindus to convert to Christianity. Foreign Christians have occasionally been expelled after being accused of proselytizing, while some Nepalese Christians have been jailed after being convicted of trying to convert Hindus. King Birendra is accorded god-like status by many of his subjects, especially in the impoverished countryside. The literacy rate is 25 percent. Life expectancy is 52. Eleven percent of all babies die before the age of one year.

THE GOVERNMENT _ Nepal is a monarchy with a legislature, called the Rashtriya Panchayat, or National Assembly. The king appoints one-fifth of the assembly's members. The rest are elected on a nonpartisan basis, but political observers say the king approves the candidates. Political parties have been outlawed, except for a brief experiment with Western-style democracy from 1959 to 1961. King Birendra, 44, who studied at Eton College in England and Harvard University, ascended to the throne in 1972 upon the death of his father, King Mahendra.

THE ECONOMY _ The per capita annual income of $150 is among the lowest in the world. The main foreign exchange earnings come from tourism, which includes trekking and mountain climbing, and from export of carpets, an industry dominated by Tibetan refugees.

THE GEOGRAPHY _ Nepal ranges from the semitropical Terai plain in the south to the snow-covered Himalayan Mountains. Its geographic area of 56,827 square miles is about the size of the state of Wisconsin. The country is wedged between Asia's two biggest powers: India to the east, south and west; China to the north.

HISTORY _ Hindu-Buddhist culture was flourishing in the Katmandu valley by the 4th century A.D. By medieval times, many small principalities had emerged. One of the most dominant was that of the Gurkhas, whose soldiers still serve in the armies of India and Britain and in United Nations peacekeeping forces. Nepal is proud of never having been colonized, although it was a nominal British protectorate from 1816 to 1923. The present Shaha dynasty dates to the 17th century, although from 1846 to 1951 real power rested with the Rana family, which installed a system of hereditary prime ministers whose descendants are still active. In the early 1950s, Nepal started opening up to the outside world, emerging from an isolation nurtured by its rulers and fostered by geography. Initially, India was the major trading part, but in the past two years Nepal has sought other commercial ties, especially with China.

DOC.HEAD: Psychiatrist: List Suffered from Personality Disorder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note Liss in 13th graf is cq; L'E. is cq in last graf
DOC.TEXT: A personality disorder prevented John E. List from seeing solutions to his problems and like a tightly stretched rubberband, he snapped _ and massacred his family, a psychiatrist testified. List, a devout Lutheran, was a man ``who was being bombarded with stresses that he was taught to contain,'' Dr. Sheldon I. Miller said Friday, the fifth day of List's trial. ``He believed that in doing what he did, his family was allowed to join God.'' List has admitted killing his wife, Helen, 46; mother, Alma, 85; and three children in their Westfield mansion on Nov. 9, 1971. He was arrested in June in Virginia, where he had been living under a different name. List's defense is that he is innocent by reason of mental disease or defect. List was afflicted with an ``obsessive-compulsive'' disorder that made him a perfectionist preoccupied with details, excessively devoted to work inflexible in his morality and unable to express emotion, Miller testified in List's defense. He grew up ``emotionally impoverished,'' virtually friendless and imbued with religion under an authoritarian father who taught that anything less than complete self-sufficiency was ``not manly and inappropriate,'' Miller said. But List saw he could no longer support his family and could arrive at only two options: welfare, which was impossible because of his background, and killing his family. If the jury finds that because of List's mental state he did not act premeditatively, willfully deliberately or with malice, List could be convicted of second-degree murder or manslaughter rather than first degree murder, with which he is charged. Earlier Friday, the jury heard evidence that Helen List suffered an advanced case of syphilis she had contracted from a previous husband and had managed to hide from doctors until 1969. The disease, which she apparently contracted in the 1940s, had caused atrophy of her brain and caused blindness in her right eye, said Dr. Henry R. Liss, a neurologist. Doctors who examined her observed her hallucinating, speaking to an imaginary person and making facial grimaces and lip-smacking sounds, but didn't realize that syphilis caused her ailments. She was psychotic, schizophrenic, defensive and showed a ``slight tinge of paranoia,'' Liss said, referring to medical records of different hospital stays.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Fear Higher Death Toll in Hotel Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Olimpia cq in 20th graf
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: Authorities feared they would find more bodies as they searched the rubble of a residential hotel where fire killed at least three residents and forced others to jump from windows. Twenty were injured. Fire officials today reported at least 14 people missing after the pre-dawn fire Friday at the three-story, 102-room Fontana Hotel north of Miami Beach's trendy art deco district. They didn't know how many died in the fire. ``This has the possibility of being a tragedy of large proportions,'' said Assistant Fire Chief John Reed. ``We do expect the number of dead to rise.'' ``I know there are more people in there. There is an old man I know didn't get out. Oh God, this is unreal,'' said Lynda Holloway, 41, who lived at the residential hotel about a year. Many of the nearly 100 residents were retirees. Some fled leaving behind medication, hearing aids and dentures. Reed said officials would decide today whether to pick through the ruins with body-sniffing dogs or first raze unstable sections with heavy equipment. A special fire assessment team from the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms was to help local and state officials determine the extent of damage and cause of the fire, which quickly engulfed the lobby and the eastern half of the 39-year-old hotel. Mayor Alex Daoud, who opened his house to survivors unable to find other shelter, said the intensity of the 3 a.m. fire makes it appear suspicious. Reed said only that it may take days before the fire's cause is established. ``We're going to move slowly and look at everything,'' he said. Residents _ many of them elderly _ jumped from windows or spilled out of doorways as fire raced down the hallways. Most escaped with only the clothes they were wearing. ``I just sold my business last Sunday and moved all my things into that room,'' said Enid Davis, a Jamaican-born beautician who was at the shelter. ``I lost _ I just don't want to think about it. I don't have a place to go. I don't even have a dime.'' Residents received food and aid at an American Red Cross emergency shelter. Owners of other hotels opened their rooms to those made homeless. Twenty people, ranging in age from 7 months to 90, were treated for cuts and smoke inhalation. Most were released from hospitals by Friday afternoon. Joe Marcello, 26, was forced to jump from his second-story window. ``There was a point there I really thought I was going to die,'' he said. The hotel had smoke alarms but no sprinklers, authorities said. Under state law, sprinkler systems aren't required in hotels three stories or taller until 1991. ``Over the last 50 years, there has never been a mutiple-death fire in a building with a complete sprinkler system,'' noted John Nelson, chief of fire prevention for Florida's fire marshal's office. Ann Karmiller, 87, said she walked down from the third floor by hanging onto the banister, fleeing so quickly that she left with nothing but her nightgown, forgetting her dentures, hearing aid and cane. One of the owners, Olimpia Mihai, helped guide residents through the murky hallways. ``She grabbed my hand and helped me out,'' said Jewel Mirsky, 76. ``It was all black. We felt the steps very haltingly. I heard the noise and the siren went off like mad. The smoke was very bitter.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Terrell County sought recognition, and know its reputation, like peanut butter, is being spread far and wide.
