Eurie LeGate, executive director of the Chamber of Commerce, says he was looking for a ``large scale operation'' to ``put our place on the map.'' The answer was in Terrell County's $15 million farming industry _ specifically, peanut farming, the county's top crop. And so The Peanut Plantin' and Pickin' Phestival was scheduled for April 21. Georgia has other peanut festivals, but LeGate said Dawson's ``Phestival'' will feature bluegrass music as well as goobers. ``As far as I know,'' he said, ``nobody else does bluegrass with the peanut one way or another.'' Tom Riggs, host of the national radio show ``Cornbread Jamboree'' on the American Bluegrass Network, will host the festival.

A resident of Peoria, Ill., who heard about an adopt-a-whale program on the Oregon Coast offered to take one home. To his swimming pool. In a missive to the Lincoln City Chamber of Commerce, the letter writer noted that gray whales migrate past Lincoln City twice a year. Surely, he said, local business leaders would know how to obtain a whale. He wanted one swimming in his backyard. Gray whales grow to 45 feet in length and weigh up to 35 tons. Once Lincoln City officials determined the writer was sincere, they passed the letter to Bruce Mate of the Hatfield Marine Science Center. Mate, an associate professor of oceanography at Oregon State University and a specialist in marine mammals, wrote back to say the the adopt-a-whale program is intended to ``give people a sense of personal identity with specific whales and to fund biological research on these species.'' ``I'm delighted that some people are willing to translate that feeling into material contributions,'' Mate said, although it would be difficult literally to adopt a whale.

DOC.HEAD: Frenzied Fans Mob Michael Jackson During Appearance at Taj Mahal
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of frenzied fans mobbed Michael Jackson as the reclusive singer joined Donald Trump for a picture opportunity at Trump's glitzy new Taj Mahal Casino Resort. When Jackson rode an elevator down from the penthouse suite he checked into at the 1,250-room casino hotel Friday, his fans surged forward and tried to touch him. Jackson, dressed in a black hat, black top coat and pinkish-red shirt, grabbed his hat and bent down to the floor as security guards formed a human chain to push back the crowd. ``You've got somebody in a wheelchair here. Watch it,'' screamed one woman as the mob pushed its way through the crowded floor. Trump and Jackson walked to the floor of the casino, which opened to gamblers Monday. Then they went to the casino's Mark Etess Arena, only to cause another frenzy as they emerged 20 minutes later and headed for a nearby cafe. Once inside, the doors were locked and the few diners already there began fighting for Jackson's attention. Jackson left through a back entrance, leaving those who got his autograph or touched him bragging about the experience. ``I can't stress how nice he was,'' said Denise Campasano, 29, of West Babylon, N.Y., with whom Jackson posed for a picture.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Election Facts and Figures At-a-Glance
With PM-Greece-Election
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Greece and its parliamentary election Sunday: WHAT'S AT STAKE: The unicameral Parliament's 300 seats, with members to choose a new government to replace the one that fell in February. POLITICAL PARTIES: The largest of the 27 parties are New Democracy (conservative), led by Constantine Mitsotakis, Panhellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK), headed by Andreas Papandreou, and Coalition of the Left and Progress. PREVIOUS GOVERNMENTS: New Democracy between 1974-1981; PASOK between 1981-June 1989. New Democracy-Coalition alliance from July-November 1989, New Democracy-PASOK-Coalition administration November 1989 to February 1990. Prime Minister Xenophon Zolotas remains caretaker. RESULTS OF LAST ELECTION: The balloting Nov. 5, 1989, gave New Democracy, 46.19 percent for 148 seats, PASOK, 40.68 percent for 128 seats, Coalition of the Left and Progress, 10.97 percent for 21 seats. Independents won three seats. POPULATION: 10 million. Registered voters: 8,050,658. VOTING RULES: Polling stations: 16,584, open from sunup to sunset, or 7:01 a.m. to 7:54 p.m. (midnight EDT Saturday to 12:54 p.m.) Voting is compulsory in Greece for people between 18 and 70. First results expected three hours after polls close and final results Tuesday. ECONOMY: Greece has an inflation rate of about 17 percent and an estimated budget deficit of $15 billion. New Democracy wants to slash public spending and streamline the public sector. PASOK wants to improve public sector production but not cut spending. The Coalition wants more progressive tax reform. DEFENSE: New Democracy regards NATO membership and the U.S. military bases in Greece as crucial. PASOK says any future defense agreement with the United States should be put to a referendum. The Coalition wants to close the U.S. bases and pull Greece out of NATO.

DOC.HEAD: California Smog Agency Acts to Curb `Greenhouse Effect'
DOC.TEXT: Southern California officials have adopted what appears to be the nation's first comprehensive policy to stem global warming and the loss of ozone in the Earth's atmosphere. It was approved unanimously Friday by the governing board of the regional South Coast Air Quality Management District, the agency that last year adopted a sweeping anti-smog plan for the Los Angeles basin. Board member Harriet M. Wieder of Orange County alluded to the region's notoriety for the nation's worst smog, saying, ``Because of our situation here in Southern California, we should be a leader on this issue.'' Although Vermont has adopted a state policy on global warming, ``this is the first government I know of to adopt a regulatory program,'' said Curtis A. Moore, an environmental consultant based in McLean, Va. The measure proposes restrictions on carbon dioxide and certain industrial gases causing the destruction of the Earth's protective ozone layer. A four-page statement approved by the board directs the district's staff to draw up a series of rules and programs that address global warming and ozone problems. The major provisions will: _Require the recycling of chlorofluorocarbon gases, or CFCs, from air conditionsers and refrigerators that are serviced or discarded. Studies have linked CFCs, which are widely used as refrigerants, to the destruction of ozone in the Earth's outer atmosphere. _Phase out the use of CFCs and halon gases, other ozone-destroying compounds widely used in fire extinguishers, by Jan. 1, 1997. A three-year extension would be granted in certain circumstances. _Develop strategies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. The board asked its scientific advisory panel to study the feasibility of curbing carbon dioxide emissions 20 percent by 2000 and 40 percent by 2010. The district also would to support scientific research of chemicals that could be used as alternatives to CFCs. Scientists agree that concentrations of carbon dioxide have increased in the atmosphere over the past 150 years. Many argue the gas is raising the planet's temperature by trapping heat in the atmosphere, but data is inconclusive. Environmentalists urged the 12-member board to strengthen its policy by moving up compliance deadlines. ``It is vital for the district to adopt effective, technology-forcing policies to curb global warming and to halt depletion of the stratospheric ozone layer,'' said Veronica Kun of the Natural Resources Defense Council. Industry executives attacked the plan. ``We believe it is premature to implement a policy that so clearly assumes there is scientific certainty, especially when the cost to business, the community and society would be so large,'' said Ross Hopkins, a Lockheed executive who spoke on behalf of the California Manufacturers Association. Hopkins said the district was putting Southern California businesses at a competitive disadvantage since firms elsewhere would operate without the cost of compliance.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Greeted Warmly At Meeting; Jackson Blasts Bush Drug War
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson was the star speaker but Marion Barry nearly stole the show after he quietly slipped into an anti-drug meeting of the National Conference of Black Mayors. Jackson interrupted his own speech when he spotted the Washington, D.C., mayor entering the room Friday. ``Come on up, Mr. Mayor,'' he said, and a crowd of about 400 stood and applauded as Barry walked to the podium and sat at Jackson's right hand. After Jackson's speech, reporters and well-wishers swarmed Barry, who recently completed seven weeks of chemical dependency treatment after an arrest on cocaine charges. Barry said he saw no irony in his attending the anti-drug meeting and said his own problem with substance abuse should not be linked by the media to the proliferation of drugs in his home city. ``What about New York? David Dinkins has not had this kind of personal problem _ personal disease. What about Chicago or Miami, Florida?'' said Barry. Barry has admitted dependency on alcohol and tranquilizers but has skirted the issue of cocaine abuse. He was arrested Jan. 18 during an FBI sting operation and faces trial on five misdemeanor cocaine possession charges and three counts of lying to a grand jury about his drug involvement. ``America has a critical need to solve its problem,'' Barry said. ``I'm not going to be the focus of it. Not me.'' Barry also was asked about news reports that the Bush administration is preparing to issue a report that will declare its own year-old pilot anti-drug program in Washington a failure. ``I have not seen the report,'' said Barry. ``I think they're going to release it next week. But as Jesse Jackson indicated, the initial approach was wrong. ``It was like an exclusionary situation where you come down and you propose things for us without talking to us.'' Jackson's speech was a scathing indictment of Bush's war on drugs. He accused the administration not only of failing to get closely involved with state and local officials involved in the war, but also of providing too little money and failing to attack the root causes of drug abuse. Among those causes, he said, were poverty and unemployment. ``He'll declare a war with the resources and have you fight the war without resources _ voodoo politics,'' said Jackson, who also received a standing ovation from the crowd. Jackson also reiterated his call for government officials to develop a plan to make public and private pension funds available for investment in low-income housing and other programs aimed at eliminating poverty.

DOC.HEAD: Finance Ministers Gather for Key Economic, Monetary Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led about 6 a.m. EDT with meeting beginning.
DOC.TEXT: Top economic officials of the world's seven richest democracies are opening talks on the financial markets, which have been jittery over the unexpected fall of the Japanese yen. The talks were to begin today and include U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and finance ministers and central bank presidents from Britain, Canada, Japan, France, West Germany and Italy. The nations are known as the Group of Seven, or G-7. Japanese officials are expected to appeal for help in driving up the yen's value, but analysts doubted the other nations would be quick to come to their aid. Stephen King, an international economist at the London investment firm of James Capel and Co., predicted that ``neither the United States nor Germany would be willing to help out Japan that much.'' Moreover, David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI-McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass., said the yen's rise in recent days has taken ``a little bit of pressure off the G-7 meeting.'' The dollar had shot up against the yen in recent weeks, and it reached a three-year high earlier this week. Since then, the yen has strengthened some, which analysts say reflects the markets' uncertainty about the results of the finance meeting. Some analysts argued that the United States may agree to intervene more heavily in the currency markets to try to prop up the yen. Governments buy and sell currencies in the markets to try to alter the value of a currency. But they ruled out any move by the United States to trim interest rates at Tokyo's request. Lower U.S. interest rates would tend to give a lift to the Japanese currency, but American officials fear they would fuel inflationary pressures at home. The G-7 nations have been trying to coordinate economic policies since a campaign in September 1985 to push the dollar lower as a way of reducing the U.S. trade deficits. In February 1987, the Reagan administration decided the dollar was weak enough. In the so-called Louvre accord, the major economies pledged to work to support the dollar at the levels of that time. Analysts disagree about whether the countries are still sticking to their coordination promises. ``There is still some coordination, but it's not as good as it was,'' said Wyss. He said it was easier for the governments to act together when their economies were on par. But he said the U.S. economy has slowed while those in Europe continue to expand. The ministers' agenda also was to be taken up by the dramatic events that have unfolded in Eastern Europe since they met in September. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel and Karl Otto Poehl, the president of the West German central bank, were expected to offer details on plans to form an economic and monetary union this summer with East Germany. The Bonn government has become embroiled in a controversy over the conversion rate for exchange of the East German currency to the West German mark. The central bank, known as the Bundesbank, has recommended a 2-to-1 rate. That would give East Germans one West German mark for every two units of their currency, except for small savings' accounts, which would be traded in at a higher rate. East Germans have complained that the proposed rate would effectively cut in half their wages, pensions and other savings.

DOC.HEAD: President Supports Growing Campaign to Reform Electoral System
DOC.TEXT: President Chaim Herzog has given his support to a growing public campaign to reform the electoral system, which has put minor political parties in the role of kingmakers and deadlocked the government. By Friday, at least 70,000 Israelis had signed petitions demanding changes such as direct election of the prime minister and legislators. Voters now cast ballots for party slates. Reformers say the current method does not make legislators accountable to voters. They also say the system of giving any party with 1 percent of the vote a seat in parliament gives small parties too much leverage. A wide range of political, religious and student organizations urged members to attend a protest rally in Tel Aviv today. On Friday, more than 20 people were on a hunger strike outside the parliament building. In a statement released Friday, Herzog said he ``welcomed the actions'' of the protesters, but urged them to end the fast so they would not endanger their health. ``The president is for changing the electoral system,'' said Herzog's spokesman, Giora Pordes. The protests came as the left-leaning Labor Party tried to form a ruling coalition, and the rival right-wing Likud bloc moved to torpedo Labor's efforts. The two parties have been stalemated since the government collapsed March 15. Labor leader Shimon Peres announced this week that he put together a majority in the 120-seat parliament, or Knesset, but would not identify his backers. Israel radio reported that Labor signed a deal with Likud defector Avraham Sharir, a former tourism minister. Critics have accused Labor and Likud of using offers of government money and political jobs to entice small ultra-Orthodox parties to join their side and allow the formation of a government. On Friday, Labor reportedly tried to persuade four wavering Sharir allies to abandon Likud. Peres has offered one of them, Economics Minister Yitzhak Modai, the Finance Ministry in a Labor government, the radio said. Modai sought offers from Peres after several Likud leaders refused his demands for a $2.5 million bank guarantee to back up the party's promise to make him a Likud Cabinet minister. The public campaign against backroom deals with smaller parties began March 28 when two army reserve officers began a hunger strike in front of parliament. More than 20 people have joined the strike. The hunger strikers have collected more than 25,000 signatures, in addition to 40,000 gathered by the Association of Americans and Canadians in Israel, and 5,000 sent to the president by university students from Haifa and Jerusalem. ``The momentum is enormous,'' said political science professor Ehud Sprinzak, the campaign's organizer in Jerusalem. ``We are trying to galvanize it into a huge political movement.'' In addition to Herzog, other prominent Israelis spoke out for reform Friday, including Natan Sharansky, a former Soviet dissident and activist for Soviet Jewish immigration. Former President Jimmy Carter said Friday he believed peace prospects would be greatest under a Labor-led government. ``My last preference would be another (Labor-Likud) National Unity Government, which I think reaches the lowest common denominator of inactivity and stalemate,'' Carter said during a visit to Stockholm. Likud and Labor have ruled jointly since the 1984 election ended in a stalemate. Also Friday, three small left-wing parties courted by Peres demanded that a Labor government lift some of the harsh measures imposed by the army to suppress the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising.

DOC.HEAD: In Poor Louisiana Parish, Fight Over Segregation Takes New Turn
DOC.TEXT: A 37-year fight to desegregate schools in impoverished St. Helena Parish supposedly ended last year when blacks and whites began attending classes under the same roof. But when white school board members fired the black superintendent, it showed the fight was far from over. The firing, which apparently was decided at a closed meeting and never publicly explained, led Superintendent Perry Spears to take his firing to court in Baton Rouge, where the federal judge who has overseen the parish's desegragation once more will take up charges of racism. It led students and teachers to boycott classes, and created a sense of disbelief in activists who thought their efforts to integrate schools in this severely depressed rural parish were over and done with. ``If I wasn't in this situation, I'd find it hard to believe,'' said Spears, who is scheduled to leave office June 30 after the school board ignored his request for a new contract and hired a white to replace him. ``The school board doesn't intend to do what the court tells them,'' said John Hall, one of the original plaintiffs in the desegregation suit. U.S. District Judge John Parker has scheduled a hearing for April 19 to hear complaints that Spears' removal was racially motivated. The school board's four white members, who already had made their decision to oust Spears, announced his replacement at a Jan. 2 meeting where they outnumbered the two black board members who wanted to keep him. ``It came as a total shock,'' Spears said. Willie George Lee, one of the black board members, said he knew nothing about the move until it was put on the agenda at the last minute. ``I think it's unjust,'' Lee said. ``I think he has done an excellent job. Spears, who has worked in the district for 27 years and has been superintendent for five years, won a state court order to stay on the job through the end of the school year. Myrtie Wofford, a white former elementary principal, was hired to replace him. After the board refused to explain its reasons for replacing Spears, about half of the district's teachers stayed out and about 70 percent of the district's 2,000 students boycotted classes for a week in February. The school district is about 70 percent black. Desegregation efforts began in the 1952, when a lawsuit was filed after the district just south of the Mississippi border refused to build a new school for blacks. In January 1989, the school board closed four of the district's dilapidated school buildings and consolidated all classes into three buildings. Parker approved the move, although it apparently was motivated as much by the lack of parish funds to keep all the schools open as by the integration order. Parker had described the district's schools as ``not fit for a doghouse.'' The St. Helena Parish system is ranked as one of Louisiana's poorest; about 95 percent of its financial support coming from the state. Some elementary school students attend classes in converted mobile homes. One school had to be closed because the district could not afford the $100,000 needed to remove loose asbestos. Attorney Robert Williams, who is representing the plaintiffs in the desegregation case, said he wants to find out if Spears' dismissal is the result of racial blacklash. ``If this man is carrying out court orders and being retaliated against, we want the court to do something about it. I don't know if that's the case,'' Williams said. Williams added: ``In December, this guy is the greatest thing since ice cream. In January, you replace him without advertising. No one is saying what happened. He was replaced by somebody they obviously had interviewed. Where did you interview her? It obviously was a secret proceeding. The position was never declared vacant. It was open and gone in one bold stroke.'' Spears said two white board members told him they were pressured, apparently by whites who did not approve of sending their children to school with blacks. ``Both said I'd done a good job, but they just couldn't vote for me,'' he said. Robert Easley, one of the white board members, said he felt it was time for a change at the helm. ``For five years, everything had been in turmoil and everything had been going for him. We were last on the state test and the system had just collapsed,'' Easley said. ``As far as racism on my part, no sir,'' he said. Easley said he was not involved in any interviews for Spears' replacement. Wofford deferred comment to the board's attorney, Clifford Speed, who said the allegations involving Spears' replacement took place before he began representing the district in March. Consolidation of the schools has saved the district money and enabled schools to offer a wider curriculum, Spears said. In addition, a breakfast program has been started in the district for the first time, he said. But Easley said public support was lacking for the school system and was demonstrated last fall when a bond issue was overwhelmingly defeated.

DOC.HEAD: Clubby Nature of Japan's Business Frustrates Some Foreigners
With PM-US-Japan Trade, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. businessmen trying to penetrate Japan's market often express frustration at the clubby nature of much of this country's business, and the trade reforms Japan will undertake are meant to promote competition. Japan and the United States announced an agreement on the reforms Thursday. The government issued a report Friday outlining its plans to change the deep-seated business practices that contribute to the United States' $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. It said the Fair Trade Commission will subject the country's corporate groups, known as ``keiretsu,'' to audits every two years. Companies within such a group own each other's stock and buy products and services from each other, excluding foreign companies or raising their costs. The report said the audits will look at supplier-customer transactions, financing arrangements and personal ties. The commission is to publish its findings and ``take steps, including stricter enforcement of the Anti-Monopoly Act, to address anti-competitive and exclusionary practices,'' the report said. In addition, government powers to restrict foreign investment or technology imports on grounds they might adversely affect Japanese companies will be revised, the report said. ``Such restrictions are not needed on a general basis,'' the report said. The commission also promised to simplify procedures for corporate mergers and acquisitions. Foreigners complain that present rules hinder them from putting their money to work in Japan. The government said, however, there were sound economic reasons for forming corporate groups. In the latest issue of Economic Eye magazine, an analyst, Ryutaro Komiya, said the groups did not deserve the criticism they received. He said that while the sales of U.S. automaker General Motors are more than double those of Japan's No. 1 automaker, Toyota, ``its employees are 13 times more numerous.'' ``Toyota contracts out much of the work that GM handles in-house. Thus the Toyota group of subcontractors is akin to GM's internal divisions. It's not a question of good vs. bad business arrangements,'' Komiya said. He said that within a keiretsu, ``a firm will get no sympathy _ or sales _ from other group members with products that are more expensive or of lower quality than market standards.'' Another point of contention between the United States and Japan has been Japan's policies on retailing. The government protects small shops by requiring large stores to obtain the consent of their smaller neighbors before opening. The process can take 10 years. While refusing to abolish the law, the government promised revisions, including a shortening of this ``coordination processing period'' to less than 18 months. If problems persist, the government may decide in three years to exempt parts of Japan from the law, the report said. The supermarket chain Life Stores Co. said last week it was suing the government for the equivalent of $6.3 million on grounds it suffered losses from not being allowed to open a new branch. On Friday, Toshiaki Namiki, a spokesman for the company, said the promise of change would not lead the company to drop its suit. He said its aim was to attack the law, ``not to win compensation.'' The United States has argued that the reforms would help Japanese consumers, who pay some of the world's highest prices because of the complex distribution system and myriad government regulations. But some consumers see advantages in the small stores. Consumer groups have said cultural aspects and community relationships should also be taken into consideration.

DOC.HEAD: Family Saving Clippings For Donor Baby
DOC.TEXT: A mother who gave birth so her leukemia-stricken daughter might be saved with the newborn's bone marrow said she wants a normal life for the baby despite its much-publicized prenatal existence. ``We've been saving all the articles from magazines and everything and, when she's old enough to understand, we'll give her the big scrapbooks,'' Mary Ayala said. ``She will know all about it.'' Mary, 43, delivered Marissa Eve at the Queen of the Valley Hospital, but it does not bring an automatic reprieve for her daughter Anissa, 18, because the baby will not be ready to donate marrow for six months. Initial tests showed the newborn would be a compatible donor and it was a ``virtual, 100 percent certainty that Marissa's marrow cells will be a match for Anissa,'' said Charles Mathews, spokesman for City of Hope National Medical Center, where the transplant will be performed. The baby was in the headlines since the Ayalas revealed eight weeks ago that they had conceived her as a last resort to save the life of Anissa. The Ayalas took the step of having another child after waiting for almost two years for the National Marrow Donor Program to find a suitable donor. But Friday, Mary Ayala said her first thought was for the baby. ``We haven't even bothered to ask about the transplant or talked to City of Hope yet,'' she said. ``I'm going to stay home and take care of my baby.'' Anissa said at a news conference she would love her newborn sister regardless of whether the baby can save her life. ``I'm just really glad she's here,'' Anissa said. ``I love my little sister.'' Mary Ayala said: ``If I had it to do again, now that it's all over, I don't think I would change anything. I'm happy everything has gone the way it has.'' Leukemia, a cancer of white blood cells, typically is treated by killing blood-producing cells with chemotherapy or radiation. Marrow from a matching donor, usually a sibling, is then transplanted into the leukemia patient so the healthy stem cells can produce healthy blood cells. Dr. Rudolf Brutoco said Anissa could still face a crisis if her disease advances. ``We're keeping our fingers crossed she stays healthy,'' he said. The baby was delivered Tuesday by Caesarean section without complications. The baby was handed to the father, Abe Ayala, who held her as the mother gave her a kiss, doctors said.

DOC.HEAD: Insect Repellent Pulled from Market
DOC.TEXT: S.C. Johnson and Son Inc. said it was voluntarily withdrawing its Deep Woods OFF! insect repellent from retail stores because test animals developed tumors in response to an ingredient. The withdrawal Friday affects about 150,000 cases of aerosol and pump containers and boxes of towelettes, Johnson spokesman David Coronna said. A company statement called the withdrawal precautionary, saying it was ``not aware of any reports of adverse human health effects.'' The action does not involve other Johnson repellents. The company said an ingredient that repels biting flies, R-11 or 2 butylene tetrahydro-2-furaldehyde, showed ``adverse effects to some laboratory animals which were fed high levels of R-11'' in preliminary research. Preliminary data in one test showed laboratory mice developed a non-malignant tumor, said Roger Grothaus, vice president of scientific support and government affairs for Johnson. Grothaus said R-11 has been used in Deep Woods OFF! for 17 years and as a repellent ingredient by other companies for many years. The chemical was being tested for a recertification requirement. Coronna had no estimate of the cost of the withdrawal. He said there was no immediate decision on whether to provide refunds to customers. The company said it was providing a toll-free telephone number, 1-800-558-5252, for customer questions starting Monday.
