DOC.HEAD: Dutch Police Release Suspect In Rembrandt Vandalism Incident
DOC.TEXT: Dutch police released the jobless and distraught man arrested for spraying acid onto Rembrandt's ``The Night Watch'' on condition he seek psychiatric help, police said today. The 31-year-old suspect, released late Friday, may still face a maximimum one-year prison term if convicted of vandalizing the Netherlands' most famous painting in the Rijksmuseum here, police spokesman Klaas Wilting said. The man was freed shortly after an interview with prosecutors, who decided to let him go provided he talk to a psychiatrist, Wilting said. It was not immediately clear how psychiatric counseling could be imposed as a condition for his release. The suspect, a resident of The Hague, has not been identified, in line with Dutch police practice. The man, described by police on Friday as ``confused,'' was arrested by museum guards immediately after he sprayed acid on the huge 1642 Rembrandt. Guards immediately applied a neutralizing agent on the painting. Damage to the work was minimal, since the acid apparently failed to eat through the thick layer of veneer protecting the delicate paint, museum officials said. Wilting said the suspect could only be prosecuted for vandalism ``even if it was a very expensive painting.'' That charge carries a one-year maximum prison term. It was the third attack this century on ``The Night Watch,'' the Dutch master's most vandalized work. In 1975, a disturbed schoolmaster made 13 slashes in work with a knife he had stolen from a restaurant minutes earlier. The man later committed suicide in a mental asylum. During World War I, an umemployed shoemaker slashed the painting to protest his inability to find work.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Statehood to Cost 10 Percent of Puerto Rico's Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Gaining statehood could cause Puerto Rico to lose up to 100,000 of the 900,000 jobs on the island, according to a government study. The study, released Thursday by the Congressional Budget Office, addressed the elimination of tax benefits aimed at stimulating investment in the island, The New York Times reported in today's editions. Private U.S. investment, which now makes up half the island's $22 billion private investment, would drop 73 percent in a Puerto Rican state, the study said. Statehood would spell the end of an estimated $2 billion a year in tax benefits designed to encourage investment. The island, which currently has an $82 million ceiling on federal money for social programs, would gain an additional $3.6 billion in Federal spending by the year 2000. But the net effect of statehood would be a 4.3 percent drop in the island's gross product by the decade's end, the report said. The study is sure to have an impact on the decades-long debate over statehood, independence or continued commonwealth status for the island. Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon and other opponents of statehood, who fear voters would be attracted to statehood by the promise of additional social programs paid for by Washington, hailed the report. ``My position has always been that the future of Puerto Rico cannot be decided by how much the people would receive in social legislation,'' Colon said in the Times. Supporters of statehood or independence maintain that the report failed to take into account certain intangibles, such as the fact that doubt about the island already has dampened investment, said former Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo. An independent Puerto Rico would lose federal revenue, but might be able to maintain investment through incentives to foreign businesses, the report said. Congress commissioned the study from the CBO, its research arm, to give it direction while it considers a bill to allow a 1991 referendum on Puerto Rico's political future. Puerto Rican currently has a 16 percent jobless rate.

DOC.HEAD: Battle Plan Formed to Kill Millions of Crickets in Rural Nevada
DOC.TEXT: The state has declared war on a breed of crickets that can grow to the size of mice and bite people who interfere with their ravenous feeding. The Mormon crickets, which can reach two inches in length, are hatching across 700,000 acres in five rural counties in the state's largest infestation since the 1930s. Near Winnemucca, 150 miles northeast of Reno, 100 crickets have been counted per square foot. ``They're in the canyons right now and our goal is to kill them before they reach the valleys and the towns where they can do some real damage,'' Robert Gronowski, director of the Nevada Department of Agriculture's plant industry program, said Friday. ``If we stop them in the mountains I think we've got the problem licked. But we couldn't wipe out the entire population no matter what we did,'' Gronowski said. Once on the march, the crickets will leave barren land in their wake, eating the bark off trees and even dining on each other if food is scarce. They will bite people if disturbed. ``Once they start marching it becomes much tougher to stop them,'' Gronowski said. ``But right now they're still young and aren't really on the move so we've got an opportunity to do something to control them.'' Mormon crickets, which actually are relatives of grasshoppers and katydids, got their name from an infestation in Utah in the 1800s that ended when sea gulls from Salt Lake City reportedly flew over the land and ate the insects. The battle plan worked out by state and U.S. agriculture officials begins Tuesday with spreading a poison-laced bran and oil mixture on egg beds at the mouths of canyons where the insects are hatching. The insecticide isn't harmful to larger animals or people, according to Gronowski. ``Someone would have to eat a lot of it to even get sick.'' Aerial spraying will begin April 23 in infested rural areas where there aren't any rivers to get polluted by the insecticide. The program is expected to cost $25,000 to $80,000, which will be picked up by the federal government because the infestation is on Bureau of Land Management property, Gronowski said. ``We'll keep the baiting and spraying programs going until the crickets start laying eggs about July 15,'' he explained. The insects die after laying their eggs. ``That should be the end of the problem but there's no way to tell if they'll come back like this next year or in 10 years. We'll just have to wait and see,'' he said. If the program doesn't keep the insects out of crops and towns, Gronowski said authorities might have to get private ranchers and farmers involved in killing them. Agricultural officials say they believe this year's large infestation occurred because three years of drought allowed large egg beds to accumulate and there were no extremes of heat or cold to kill them.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``For the first time, Japan has committed to removing a broad array of structural barriers that constrain trade and impede imports.'' _ President Bush, praising a trade agreement with Japan.

``This has the possibility of being a tragedy of large proportions. We do expect the number of dead to rise.'' _ Assistant Fire Chief John Reed in Miami Beach, as authorities searched a residential hotel where at least three residents died in a fire.

``America has a critical need to solve its problem. I'm not going to be the focus of it. Not me.'' _ Washington Mayor Marion Barry, discussing drug abuse after an anti-drug meeting of the National Conference of Black Mayors.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Says He Met Secretly With Top Israeli Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lede to CORRECT that Arafat said he's had secret contacts with Israeli leaders sted secret meetings; pickup 2nd graf pvs, `But later...'
DOC.TEXT: PLO chairman Yasser Arafat said he has had secret contacts with Israeli leaders to discuss Middle East peace and the Palestinian uprising in Isaraeli-occupied lands. But later Friday, an Israeli U.N. official in New York ``categorically'' denied any such contacts. The Israeli government has refused to negotiate the Palestinian question directly with the PLO, which it considers a terrorist organization. Arafat's remarks on Italy's state-owned RAI television were broadcast hours after the Palestinian leader met for the third time in eight years with Pope John Paul II. Asked whether he had clandestine contact with Israel, Arafat replied, ``Yes, there is. There are many contacts between the Palestinian and Israeli leadership.'' He said former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin ``sent an emissary with a message for me.'' He said Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir ``also did so.'' Yuval Rotem, spokesman for the Israeli U.N. mission in New York, denied Arafat's statement. He said Arafat may have referred to talks Israeli leaders held last summer with Palestinians to advance an Israeli peace plan. ``Arafat and the PLO is a non-starter to any negotiations,'' Rotem said. He said Arafat made the latest claim because ``he's looking for legitimacy from the Israelis.'' There have been rumors of contact between Israeli and Palestine Liberation Organization leaders but they had not been independently confirmed. Israel says the PLO is bent on destruction of the Jewish state. Shamir dismissed Science Minister Ezer Weitzman from Israel's inner Cabinet last December for having contacts with the PLO. The Shamir coalition government collapsed March 15 in a dispute over a U.S.-backed proposal that calls for preliminary meetings with Palestinians to discuss proposed elections in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Labor Party backed the plan but it was opposed by Likud, its coalition partner, led by Shamir. Arafat said the messages he had received from the Israeli leaders regarded ``the intefadeh, some aspects of the peace initiative, messages that illustrate their point of view about them.'' Intefadeh is the Arab name for the Palestinian revolt that began in December 1987 against Israeli rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 875 Palestinians and 43 Israelis have died in uprising violence. Asked what Israel wanted, Arafat said: ``With whom are they going to make peace? With phantoms? With me.'' He compared Israeli leaders to ostriches for refusing to deal officially with the PLO. ``They put their heads in the sand refusing to face reality,'' he said in comments translated into Italian. ``They don't want to walk in the direction of history. Some of them think they can hide the sun with a finger.'' Earlier Friday, the pope urged the Palestinian leader to pursue dialogue. Israel criticized the meeting, as it did the two previous encounters between the pope and Arafat in 1982 and 1988. Arafat, on a European trip aimed at increasing pressure on Israel to negotiate, said Thursday he was willing to meet Israeli Labor leader Shimon Peres to advance the peace process if the politician succeeds in his effort to form a government. Arafat said he and the pope discussed the Palestinian question ``from all angles, and ways and means of establishing a just, comprehensive peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Civil Jury Ban Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: A Superior Court judge said Vermont's cost-cutting ban on civil jury trials is unconstitutional because it subjects a fundamental civil right to ``a price tag.'' But the ruling by Superior Court Judge Frank Mahady only applies to the case of a widow seeking a $15,000 payment from her late husband's insurance company. The civil jury trial moratorium will remain in effect in all other state courts unless judges there make similar rulings, said John Evers, the Middlebury attorney representing the widow. Jerome F. O'Neill, president of the Vermont Trial Lawyers Association, said he hopes other judges soon will follow Mahady's lead. ``I certainly expect it will have significant precedential value in any future case,'' O'Neill said Friday. ``Challenges are pending around the state and I expect you'll be hearing about them in the near future.'' The lawyers association has filed a class-action lawsuit to overturn the ban, saying it violates the constitutional right to a speedy trial. That lawsuit is pending in Vermont Supreme Court. The widow's suit, which began in 1985, was scheduled to go to a civil jury trial earlier this year. But the state Supreme Court postponed all civil jury trials from Jan. 22 through June 30 because of cuts in the judiciary's budget. The courts were ordered by the Legislature to make about $300,000 in cuts this fiscal year, which ends June 30, to help avert a state budget deficit. The moratorium is expected to save about $75,000. In his ruling, Mahady said the Seventh Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and several sections of the Vermont Constitution guarantee a citizen's right to a trial by jury, both in criminal and civil matters. ``No government official, no branch of government in our free society dare subject such a right, so honored by our people for centuries, to a price tag,'' Mahady said. ``Placed in the admittedly awkward position of being required to resolve a conflict between an administrative order of its Supreme Court and the clear mandate of the Constitution, this Court, with great respect for the Supreme Court, will stand fast by the Constitution.'' Thomas Lehner, Vermont court administrator and clerk of the Vermont Supreme Court, could not be reached for comment Friday. Although the specific impact of this ban is not known, court officials have said about 50 cases go to jury verdict and another 300-500 cases are called in for jury drawing during a typical six-month period.

DOC.HEAD: Finance Ministers Gather for Key Economic, Monetary Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with meeting beginning, quotes from Japanese, German officials; pickup 7th graf pvs, `Some analysts...'
DOC.TEXT: Economics officials of the seven leading industrial powers met today to discuss the turmoil in Japan's financial markets, but they appeared unlikely to do much to prop up the yen currency. ``There's no reason to unnecessarily dramatize developments in Japan,'' said a senior West German finance official, who spoke to reporters before the start of daylong talks at the French Finance Ministry. The gathering of the so-called Group of Seven _ Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Japan, Italy and the United States _ was the first formal session of the year. The West German official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the yen's recent weakness did not pose a danger to the international economy. ``I don't see any reason to consider the Japanese situation a medium-term destabilizing factor in the world economy,'' he said. But Japanese officials, obviously worried about their once-mighty currency, were expected to appeal to U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and the other finance chiefs for help. A Japanese official accompanying the finance minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, said the industrialized nations believe the decline in yen was a problem for all. The official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the dollar has not strengthened significantly but rather the value of the yen has fallen. ``That's where the difficulty lies,'' he told Japanese reporters. The value of the dollar reached a three-year high earlier in the week. The yen has since firmed some, reflecting, according to analysts, uncertainty about the outcome of the finance ministers' meeting. Brady and Hashimoto were among the string of finance ministers and central bank presidents who arrived by car at the modern glass-and-steel building housing the French Finance Ministry on the eastern edge of Paris. The officials' talks were expected to end by early evening. It was uncertain whether they would issue a statement at the conclusion. In advance of the meeting, analysts said they doubted the United States and the others would be quick to come to the aid of the Tokyo government. Stephen King, an international economist at the London investment firm of James Capel and Co., predicted that ``neither the United States nor Germany would be willing to help out Japan that much.'' Moreover, David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI-McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass., said the yen's rise in recent days has taken ``a little bit of pressure off the G-7 meeting.'' Some analysts argued that the United States may agree to intervene more heavily in the currency markets to try to prop up the yen. Governments buy and sell currencies in the markets to try to alter the value of a currency. But they ruled out any move by the United States to trim interest rates at Tokyo's request. Lower U.S. interest rates would tend to give a lift to the Japanese currency, but American officials fear they would fuel inflationary pressures at home. The G-7 nations have been trying to coordinate economic policies since a campaign in September 1985 to push the dollar lower as a way of reducing the U.S. trade deficits. In February 1987, the Reagan administration decided the dollar was weak enough. In the so-called Louvre accord, the major economies pledged to work to support the dollar at the levels of that time. Analysts disagree about whether the countries are still sticking to their coordination promises. ``There is still some coordination, but it's not as good as it was,'' said Wyss. He said it was easier for the governments to act together when their economies were on par. But he said the U.S. economy has slowed while those in Europe continue to expand. The ministers' agenda also was to be taken up by the dramatic events that have unfolded in Eastern Europe since they met in September. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel and Karl Otto Poehl, the president of the West German central bank, were expected to offer details on plans to form an economic and monetary union this summer with East Germany. The Bonn government has become embroiled in a controversy over the conversion rate for exchange of the East German currency to the West German mark. The central bank, known as the Bundesbank, has recommended a 2-to-1 rate. That would give East Germans one West German mark for every two units of their currency, except for small savings' accounts, which would be traded in at a higher rate. East Germans have complained that the proposed rate would effectively cut in half their wages, pensions and other savings.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $3.5 Million in Largest `Vanity Publisher' Case
DOC.TEXT: Even though ``The Sex Life Of A Football Referee'' and ``Dogs I Have Known'' didn't make Book-of-the-Month Club, they still deserved to be promoted. That's the finding of a jury, which on Friday awarded $3.5 million in a 13-year-old lawsuit charging one of the nation's largest ``vanity'' publishers with fraud and deception. The $11 million class action suit represents thousands of authors who have paid up to $8,000 to have their book manuscripts published by New York-based Vantage Press since 1971. ``Vantage operates a sham operation rife with fraud and phantom editors,'' said Arthur J. Jacobs, attorney for the authors. But Laurence Shanahan, a lawyer for the publisher, said, ``Vantage did exactly what it promised these authors,'' by publishing their works and advertising them in mailings and small trade publications. Vantage publishes about 400 books a year. The civil suit claimed Vantage Press _ which advertises ``A well-known publisher is searching for manuscripts worthy of book publication'' _ made no effort to sell or promote its authors. The plaintiffs note that Vantage has no sales representatives, produces very limited print runs (150 to 3,000 copies), and maintains no listing of old titles kept in print. Titles published by the company include ``Traffic My Way,'' the reminiscences of a parking meter man; ``A Guide to the Bathrooms of the World: Toilets''; and ``Daddy Was An Undertaker,'' which starts off: ``There's always someone dead in our house.'' The $3.5 million will be divided among 2,200 authors once the court stipulates how much the plaintiffs' attorney should receive, The New York Times reported. The trial was held before state Supreme Court Justice Carmen Ciparick. In 1958, the Federal Trade Commission issued an order that barred Vantage from claiming, among other things, that it printed only manuscripts of merit and that it aggressively promoted its books.

DOC.HEAD: Polls Indicate Old Results in New Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that New Democracy Deputy Tzannis Tzannetakis was premier when Papandreou was indicted sted Mitsotakis, SUB 9th graf pvs, `With Mitsotakis...' Pickup 10th graf pvs, `In February...'
DOC.TEXT: Greece could end up with another coalition government after voters go to the polls Sunday, and that could mean a continued impasse over how to deal with growing economic problems. Temporary coalitions have run the country since the scandal-ridden socialists were ousted last year after eight years in power. Opinion polls indicate than no one party will gain a majority in the balloting for the 300-seat unicameral Parliament, the third election in less than a year. That would mean that one of Greece's small parties could have a pivotal role in forming the next government. With 17 percent inflation and a $15 billion budget deficit, the European Community says Greece is in danger of bankruptcy. The economic problems, spurred by the lack of government cohesion, has led to frustration and violence. Leftist terrorists have called for an election boycott and have set off scores of bombs. Conservatives and Socialists have clashed. Constantine Mitsotakis' conservative New Democracy party thinks it has the best chance of winning the necessary 151 seats for an absolute majority. In November's elections, it won 148 seats, two more than it received in the June vote, which knocked Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and his Panhellenic Socialist Movement party from power. The conservatives and the small Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress teamed up after the June vote. With New Democracy Deputy Tzannis Tzannetakis as premier, the alliance presided over the indictment of Papandreou and some of his ministers on charges of involvement in financial scandals and illegal wiretapping of political opponents. A trial date has not been set. In February, another alliance of the conservatives, socialists and communists collapsed after it was unable to confront economic problems or stem a resurgence of urban terrorism. Prime Minister Xenophon Zolotas, 86, a former governor of the Bank of Greece, remains in charge until a new government is chosen. If no party wins a majority in the elections, parties with one or two seats in parliament could wield considerable influence. ``I see all parties falling slightly,'' said pollster Panayote Dimitras. ``But the Coalition (Communists) could fall a little more because of protest votes that may go to the Environmentalist-Alternative party or blank ballots.'' He said that if the environmental party, which won one seat in the last election, gains one or two more seats, ``they could also become the key to power.'' The 71-year-old Papandreou, whose party finished a close second in November, does not have a specific platform but has promised stability and progress. Mitsotakis, also 71, has promised to increase private investment as a way to create 100,000 jobs. He ended his campaign Friday with a rally that drew tens of thousands in Athens. ``These elections are not between left and right,'' Mitsotakis told supporters. ``The real choice is between progress and regression.'' Conservatives and socialists disagree over U.S. military bases in Greece. New Democracy wants the bases and NATO membership, saying they are essential for defense. The socialists say any future bases agreement should be put to a referendum. Communist leaders offered nothing new in their party platform, but repeated their pledge to protect workers' rights.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter, Police Dogs Deployed In Bid To End Weeklong Siege
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with prison official explaining strategy to end uprising. Pickup 9th pvs, `Prisoner Derek...'
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter flew low over Strangeways Prison early today to disturb the sleep of rebellious inmates, and barking dogs, shouting guards and spotlights were also used to wear down a weeklong siege. Prison governor Brendan O'Friel told reporters that fewer than 25 prisoners remained inside the prison, which was heavily damaged in a riot that broke out at a chapel service on Sunday. ``We have been using a certain amount of noise tactics to reduce the, in our view, unauthorized access of prisoners to the media,'' O'Friel said. ``We have continued to put pressure on the prisoners in other ways.'' But he said authorities still hoped to negotiate an end to the impasse. Earlier, lines of shouting prison officers beating nightsticks on riot shields and accompanied by barking guard dogs marched into the building where the defiant inmates are holed up behind barricades. Inmates appeared on the roof, and one was heard chanting: ``We won, we won, you lost.'' A flickering strobe light played repeatedly over the roof of the prison in the northern city of Manchester. On Friday, prison authorities used blaring rock music and a wailing helicopter siren to drown out inmates shouting from the rooftop to reporters outside the prison's perimeter wall. The Home Office said two more prisoners surrendered Friday. Prisoner Derek White, 46, died in North Manchester Hospital on Tuesday of injuries he suffered at the hands of other inmates when the riot began. White had been in Strangeways awaiting trial on charges of indecently assaulting three children. Child molesters, convicted policemen, and some other groups are regarded with particular loathing by other prison inmates. White's death was the only confirmed fatality resulting from the riot. But speculation that at least four other prisoners were killed by fellow inmates on Sunday increased when a lawyer for 40 prisoners who surrendered said Friday that several reported witnessing killings. Lawyers for other prisoners had heard similar tales, the attorney, Frank Sinclair, said. The reports cannot be checked until staff have access to the entire prison. Strangeways housed prisoners of all categories, from extremely dangerous to low risk. Strangeways Prison, which was built in 1868 to house 970 male prisoners, had 1,648 when the riot there broke out during a service in the prison chapel. On Thursday, prisoner Paul Taylor, 28, a self-professed leader of the rampage, shouted through a makeshift bullhorn to a TV crew perched on a roof opposite the prison. He said he had grabbed the chaplain's microphone during the service as a prelude to a planned sit-in to protest conditions in the overcrowded jail. He said he had not meant to start a riot. When Taylor started shouting through the bullhorn Friday, the authorities set up a counterblast of noise. In a separate incident 80 miles southeast of Manchester, 36 inmates at Glen Parva center for young offenders at Leicester surrendered to guards before dawn today. The prisoners had held the guards at bay more than seven hours, the Home Office said. It said the protest at the Glen Parva center began Friday night when 60 inmates overpowered a guard. He was taken to a hospital with a dislocated shoulder. Twenty-four of the 60 surrendered later Friday night, and the other 36 held out until early today. Glen Parva houses 770 young male offenders ages 16 to 20. The Home Office said the cause of the disturbance was being investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Rebels Kill Afghan Troops at Fake Surrender Ceremony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with rebel commanders calling the ambush a victory, more details on how attack occurred.
DOC.TEXT: Moslem guerrillas said today that they dealt a major blow to the Afghan government when they turned a surrender ceremony for 10,000 guerrillas into a surprise attack. Najibullah Lefrey, information minister of the self-proclaimed rebel government-in-exile, said Friday's guerrilla attack in Herat Province was a setback to President Najib's claims that tens of thousands of rebel fighters are changing sides and embracing his Soviet-backed government. Jamiat-i-Islami, considered the most effective of the seven Pakistan-based fighting forces, claimed the surprise attack on the Herat plains was planned five months ago to trap government forces. It apparently was intended to avenge a similar deadly trick by government forces 11 years ago. The guerrillas had invited Afghan officials to what they said would be the surrender of 10,000 rebels, but instead opened fire on their hosts, setting off a gun battle that left many dead on both sides. Western diplomats in Pakistan said on condition of anonymity that they had reports that up to five Afghan generals were killed or wounded in the 15-minute gun battle and in hand-to-hand combat with knives and pistols. They also said civilians, including children, died in the fighting on the plains outside Herat, 400 miles west of the Afghan capital of Kabul. Government-run Kabul radio said at least a dozen people were killed, including Lt. Gen. Jalal Razaminda, who is also deputy security minister, a second unidentified general, civilians and nine guerrillas. An official rebel news agency, MIDIA, claimed that six generals, 25 Communist Party members and several top government bureaucrats were killed in the attack. The agency said 100 others were injured. The guerrillas lured government troops into the ambush saying they would surrender their weapons and support the national reconcilation policy of Soviet-backed President Najib. The government uses the term ``national reconcilation'' to signify agreement by local guerrilla groups to switch sides and either stop fighting or help the Marxist government in the war it has fought with rebels since seizing power in a 1978 coup. The government says tens of thousands of rebels have laid down their weapons in the past year. Diplomats based in Kabul and a small group of foreign journalists were flown to Herat for the ceremony and dove for cover during the intense, close-range battle, Kabul radio said. The radio said 2,200 armed guerrillas and 8,000 unarmed rebels had gathered on the plains about 25 miles from the city of Herat for the surrender ceremony. The guerrillas _ with weapons ranging from side arms to recoilless cannons, missiles and rocket launchers _ opened fired at the government officials and soldiers. Western diplomats and rebel leaders said the guerrillas fired the first shot when the provincial governor, Fazle Haq Khaliq Yaar, embraced an unidentified guerrilla commander dressed in a white robe and turban. Yaar was reportedly wounded in the incident. The diplomats said the governor's guards immediately returned fire and the ceremony became a pitched battle, with massive exchanges of gunfire. The diplomats said the shooting stopped when two Afghan army tanks moved in with bursts of fire. An Afghan national TV cameraman was reported shot in the head and badly wounded in the fighting. ``In order to stop the propaganda show of the puppet regime, some mujahedeen (holy rebels) decided to give their lives to kill the people responsible for the show,'' Lefrey said. ``This attack shows that the puppet regime has just been launching a lot of propaganda about national reconciliation.'' ``No one is joining the regime. They just parade the militia for show and say they are mujahedeen,'' he said. Najib has organized thousands of Afghan villagers into milita forces to supplement his army. The rebels have been fighting for 12 years to topple successive communist governments in Afghanistan. They are supported by the United States, Saudi Arabia and other Arab states. After the last Soviet soldiers ended nine years of direct intervention in Afghanistan in February 1989, Western diplomats predicted Najib would fall within weeks or months. But the rebels has been partially paralyzed by bitter infighting and have failed to win any major battle. Najib emerged a formidable opponent, taking the political initiative with offers to end the fighting. Herat was the first region in Afghanistan to rise against the government in early 1979 before the Red Army stepped in to bolster the Marxist government. The Soviet Union withdrew its troops in February 1989 but still sends huge quantities of supplies and weapons to the Kabul government.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Rocket Carries U.S.-made Satellite into Space
DOC.TEXT: A Long March 3 rocket blasted into space today bearing a U.S.-made telecommunications satellite, marking China's debut into the international satellite launching business. Applause broke out in the launch control room after the rocket's flaming tail disappeared into the black skies over the Xichang Satellite Center in southwest China's Sichuan province. The launch, shown live on Chinese Central Television for the first time in China's 20-year-old satellite program, was delayed more than an hour because of bad weather. It finally took place at 9:30 p.m. (8:30 a.m. EDT) and appeared to go smoothly. China hopes the successful sendoff of the 2,750-pound AsiaSat satellite will attract more customers who face long waits for launches by Western Europe's Ariane consortium and private U.S. companies. China has put 26 satellites of its own in space, including at least five with Long March 3 rockets. But the official China Daily newspaper said that launching the AsiaSat and other foreign satellites would ``amaze the world.'' ``Most foreigners, and Chinese citizens too, think of China as the land of the bicycle,'' it wrote. ``They may have to adjust that image.'' The AsiaSat satellite was made by the U.S. Hughes Aircraft Co., and its launch was nearly blocked by a ban on weapons exports to China imposed after the June killing of pro-democracy protesters in Beijing. But in a conciliatory and controversial move, President Bush waived the ban for it and two other Hughes satellites being made for an Australian company. China is to launch them in 1991 and 1992. Sabotage of nearby communications lines also nearly disrupted the launch, according to a local radio report last month. It said two men were arrested for allegedly cutting, sabotaging or stealing communications lines between the launch site and the monitoring base 220 miles away in the provincial capital, Chengdu. The sabotage occurred from November 1988 through January, the report said, and no motive was given. The AsiaSat satellite is on its second trip into space. It was launched in 1984 as the Westar-6 but failed to reach its proper orbit. It was recovered by the U.S. space shuttle and sold to the Asia Satellite Telecommunications Co. Ltd., a Hong Kong-based consortium with Chinese, British and Hong Kong partners. Once in geostationary orbit _ always staying above the same spot on the earth's surface _ it will be used to transmit television, telephone and other communications signals to Asian countries. Burma and two Hong Kong companies have signed contracts to use it, and Thailand, Pakistan, South Korea, Nepal and other countries have signed letters of intent. It is estimated to have a 10-year lifespan.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle TV Camera Lens Replaced, Launch Still on Time
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5-6th grafs pvs, `Air Force...'., with 5 grafs to UPDATE with weather forecast less favorable, other detail. Picks up 7th graf, `Technicians discovered...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Shuttle-Skull
DOC.TEXT: NASA prepared its countdown today for launch of the shuttle Discovery after replacing a dirty television camera lens that will help in the deployment of the powerful Hubble Space Telescope. Countdown for Tuesday's liftoff was to begin at 3 p.m. EDT, an hour after the scheduled arrival of Discovery's five astronauts. The $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. It is to orbit 380 miles above Earth for 15 years, enabling astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years. Air Force weather forecasters today said they expect a 60 percent chance of favorable weather at launch time. The forecast was somewhat worse than Friday's predictions, which calculated the chance of good weather at 80 percent, because of the expectation of strong surface winds. But NASA test director Terry Willingham said launch preparations ``are proceeding smoothly.'' Overnight, technicians discovered four faulty connectors on one of the shuttle's three main engines. The cables were removed for repair or replacement, and the problem ``should be no impact at all on the schedule,'' Willingham said. The launch window for Tuesday extends for 2{ hours, beginning at 8:47 a.m. EDT. It is the longest period of opportunity for launch since the Challenger mission in 1986 that ended in tragedy, Willingham said. ``We want to give ourselves every opportunity to get this launch off in the first few days,'' Willingham said. Technicians discovered the spotty lens during a routine check Friday afternoon. They removed the television camera from the orbiter and replaced the lens within two hours. Mission specialist Steven A. Hawley will use the 50-foot-long robot arm to deploy the telescope on the second day of the five-day mission. A spot on the television camera lens might have hampered his view. Hawley said he has practiced deploying the 24,250-pound telescope dozens of times and is prepared for just about anything that might go wrong. ``I'm confident we can do it under almost any circumstance,'' he said. ``NASA's real good at what-ifs, and we've done a lot what-ifs. What if this part doesn't work? What if the arm fails completely?'' Mission specialists Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn Sullivan, veteran spacewalkers, will go out to help remove or fix the telescope, if necessary. NASA planned to stop charging the telescope's nickel-hydrogen batteries today.

DOC.HEAD: Sniper Wounds Seven in Australia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with man armed with two guns, shot at wedding party, wounding bridesmaid. Other details.
DOC.TEXT: A man firing a shotgun and a rifle randomly from his apartment building wounded seven people before police shot and arrested him, authorities said. The victims included a bridesmaid whose wedding party was driving past the building at the time, police said. ``He just turned his gun on anything that moved,'' said Ron Hayes, an ambulance official in this resort city on Australia's east coast. The 26-year-old man, armed with a high-powered rifle and a shotgun, began firing from his high-rise building, then came outside and continued shooting, officials said. The gunman was subdued by police, who wounded him in the arm, said spokesman Constable David Austin. The assailant, who was not identified, was undergoing surgery for a bullet wound and was expected to be charged later, Austin said. ``We are not, at this stage, prepared to release any further details,'' the spokesman said in a telephone interview. The gunman's victims included a 78-year-old woman who was hit by three bullets and hospitalized in serious condition, and a bridesmaid who was shot in the leg as she traveled in a car with other members of a wedding party. The nursing supervisor at a local hospital, who identified herself only as Sister Allen, said that aside from the elderly woman the six other victims were in stable condition, she said. In addition to those wounded, a woman was treated for shock. The nursing supervisor confirmed the gunman was hospitalized.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Deliberations Resume For Sixth Day
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 5 grafs new with deliberations resuming; pick up 6th graf, There are ...
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial began a sixth day of deliberations today in the coverup case against the former national security adviser. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene decided Friday to have the jury meet for a full day today. The panel of eight women and four men began considering the five criminal charges against Poindexter on Monday. The 12 were sequestered Tuesday, after news organizations contacted two members of the panel. The jury last sent a note to the judge on Thursday. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. Each count carries a maximum five-year prison term and $250,000 fine on conviction. There are approximately 100 exhibits in the Poindexter case. The prosecution presented 10 witnesses in 7{ days of testimony. The defense called 15 witnesses in 5{ days. Deliberations took 12 days before a verdict was reached in the trial last year of Poindexter's aide, Oliver North. There were 12 criminal charges against North and he was convicted on three of them. More than 250 exhibits were introduced during eight weeks of testimony in the North trial. Poindexter allegedly covered up North's military assistance to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels and the U.S. role in a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. North testified that he balked at meeting with members of the House intelligence committee, but that Poindexter sent him anyway. North said he lied to the lawmakers by denying he was giving military advice to the Contras but insisted it was his own idea to lie, not Poindexter's. The former National Security Council aide testified that he saw Poindexter tear up a presidential document that ratified the Nov. 25, 1985, CIA-assisted shipment of Hawk missiles from Israel to Iran. The document, called a finding, depicted the United States as being involved in an arms-for-hostages swap, something Reagan had said he would never do. Reagan was the main witness for the defense, giving about eight hours of videotaped testimony that was shown to the jury. The former president said he didn't think Poindexter made any false statements to Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Northern Ireland Starts Alternative Prison
DOC.TEXT: In the computer studies room at Maghaberry Prison, a small, clerkish man taps away at a Braille typewriter, preparing a text for the blind. Bobby Bates was one of the ``Shankill Butchers,'' a Protestant murder squad whose throat-cutting atrocities against Roman Catholics exceeded even Northern Ireland's savage standards. Thirteen years into a life sentence for 10 murders, with a history of violent behavior behind bars, 42-year-old ``Basher'' Bates comes across as a changed man. He works and eats alongside Catholic prisoners. He has discovered Christ. He makes no excuses for his crimes. The new Bobby Bates is a product of Maghaberry Prison, which opened in 1986 as an alternative lockup for inmates who want to leave the ``paramilitary'' milieu, learn a skill and one day return to a peaceful life outside prison. Left behind in the older Maze Prison outside Belfast are the truly committed, still segregating themselves into Republican (Catholic) and Loyalist (Protestant) cellblocks, still refusing to work or do anything else that could be read as acknowledging that their offenses were criminal, not political. Simply by choosing Maghaberry instead of the Maze, a prisoner tacitly signals he is removing himself from the battleground and rehabilitation can begin. Maghaberry is part of the quiet transformation of Northern Ireland's prison system in the decade since the Maze seethed with protest and 10 inmates, led by Bobby Sands of the Irish Republican Army, captured world attention by fasting to death. The government has always seen self-imposed segregation as a perpetuation of the conflict between Republicans fighting to rid Northern Ireland of British rule, and Loyalists fighting to maintain the union with Britain. Attempts to force integration have invariably met resistance. Indeed, the one jail where tension persists is Belfast Prison, where about 650 pre-trial inmates are demanding segregation. Several Belfast guards have been beaten in recent months and four have been fired, prosecuted or suspended since 1983 for mistreating prisoners. A mass breakout was foiled in October. Since Maghaberry opened, 164 Maze prisoners have gone there by choice. Now, two years after it became fully operational, it has about 275 prisoners and 520 are in the Maze. Had Bobby Bates not moved to Maghaberry, he probably would have stayed in jail for the rest of his life as recommended by the judge. Now he may stand a chance of freedom in the next decade. The Prison Service felt confident enough to invite four foreign journalists to visit Maghaberry and the Maze last month and chat in private with prisoners. The only condition was that no prison officials be identified, because they are targets for assassination. ``I think the government is anxious to get the prisoners out as much as anybody else,'' said the Rev. Denis Faul, a Catholic priest and human rights campaigner in close contact with prison authorities and prisoners' families. ``There are very many people in prison, both from the Protestant and the Catholic side, who would not normally be in prison ... for any type of crime other than a politically motivated crime,'' he said in an interview. Nearly 2,800 people have been killed in Northern Ireland since sectarian violence began in August 1969. The violence has declined in recent years. The number of security offenders sentenced, once forecast to reach 3,000, is about 800. Many were jailed 10 years ago or more, and the government has been persuaded that at least some can be freed without risk. Well-behaved prisoners with release dates are eligible for a week's furlough at summer and Christmas. Some prisoners incarcerated in Britain have been moved to Northern Ireland to be nearer their families. Most prisoners on fixed sentences can expect one-half off if they behave, as opposed to one-third in Britain. Four prisoners were learning bricklaying in a Maghaberry workshop. One, an IRA man serving life for killing a soldier, said he left the Maze ``because I didn't fancy that environment anymore.'' He was 34, had served 14 years and expected to be released in 1992. He went home last summer and at Christmas. ``I met people my age who are married with kids, settled down,'' he said. ``The amount of people I didn't know! It was like there was a gulf between myself and my family.'' Did he have regrets? ``It was something you got caught up in and you thought it was worth it ... but in retrospect, you wouldn't have done it.'' Working beside him was a Loyalist doing life for aiding and abetting a murder. He had a wife and four children. ``All those years lost,'' he remarked. ``A life completely wasted.'' No such sentiments are expressed at the Maze, a maximum-security sprawl of H-shaped cellblocks. Republicans and Loyalists, locked in separate uprights of each H, never meet or work. They have their own gyms, exercise yards, billiard tables and libraries. Why not move to Maghaberry? ``Because it's saying, `Forget your Republicanism and become part of a criminal system,''' an IRA lifer said. ``But we are not criminal prisoners. We are political prisoners.'' IRA supporters argue that the journalists' visit is a propaganda exercise, that abuses do occur in Belfast Prison and at police interrogation centers. They maintain Britain has no right to be in Ireland at all, let alone to jail people who see themselves as freedom fighters. ``We say Northern Ireland as a concept is illegal and should never have been set up,'' said a Maze Republican, on whose cell wall hung portraits of Che Guevara and Jesus Christ. Conversation kept moving back to 1983, when 38 prisoners escaped from the Maze in a mass breakout and half were recaptured immediately. One told a reporter of being beaten and set upon by dogs. The Prison Service doesn't deny the abuses but says they happened in the heat of the immediate aftermath of the breakout, and that the violence was mutual, leaving one prison officer dead and several injured. It insists abuses could not happen now. Compensation was paid to 19 prisoners who alleged being assaulted, but no prison official was ever disciplined for the 1983 incidents. Last month, an Irish court ruled against extraditing two Maze escapees, believing they might face reprisals. Faul said there had been ``no serious incident of brutality since 1983'' in any of Northern Ireland's four prisons. ``By and large, allowing for the difficulty of imprisoning large numbers of men and so on, conditions have been excellent,'' Faul said. He supported the Irish court decision, and said: ``The British can only blame themselves. If they had put the prison officers on trial or had dismissed them, and could show that to the court, then the prisoners would have been sent back.'' In Faul's view, whatever improvements are made in the lives of Northern Ireland's Catholic minority are undermined by ``the non-accountability of the security forces _ British army, police, prison officers _ for killing and ill-treating persons.'' This, he said ``is one of the major problems that's keeping the IRA in existence.''

DOC.HEAD: 20 Killed in South African Violence; ANC Schedules Talks with Government
DOC.TEXT: Black factions battled police and each other in fighting that left 20 people dead, including two infants, police reported today. Also today, the African National Congress and South Africa's government announced that they would hold their first discussions on the country's political future in Cape Town on May 2. The meeting, originally scheduled for Wednesday, was postponed by the ANC to protest the police shooting of protesters in a black township on March 26. In today's violence, police said they fired shotguns at a crowd in Kokosi township southwest of Johannesburg after firebombs and stones were thrown at a police vehicle, injuring one policeman. Police said ``a 32-year-old woman was wounded, and regrettably, a child which she had been carrying was fatally injured'' by the gunfire. In Natal province, where supporters of the ANC have been battling members of the Zulu-based Inkatha movement, 19 people were reported killed. A police report said 14 people were killed there today and Friday night, including an infant, three women and 10 men. The report also said that five bodies were discovered in Natal Thursday by the local KwaZulu homeland police. Police reported that activists fired automatic weapons at police separating black groups in Natal, but no casualties were reported. Police have been accused of favoring Inkatha in the fighting that has taken 86 lives in less than two weeks. President F.W. de Klerk last week ordered extra police units and soldiers into northern Natal to halt the political feuding, slayings, clashes, ambushes and looting that has killed about 4,000 people since 1986. ANC leader Nelson Mandela, 71, is scheduled to arrive in Lusaka, Zambia's capital, on Sunday for a three-day visit to discuss the township violence and plan for his meeting with de Klerk, the ANC said. Lusaka has been the headquarters of the ANC since the anti-apartheid group was outlawed 30 years ago. De Klerk invited ANC leaders to preliminary talks as a step toward formal power-sharing negotiations. He said he wants to negotiate a new constitution that will give power to the black majority of 28 million, but provide the nation's 5 million whites a veto over major policy decisions. The ANC has repeatedly demanded majority rule. Mandela was freed last month after 27 years of imprisonment for anti-government activities. The ANC and other anti-apartheid groups also were legalized as a prelude to political negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Get Left-over Food and Smelly Shoes
DOC.TEXT: Eight gunmen who ambushed an armored car and carried off several duffel bags of booty left their victims laughing about the loss of leftovers and a pair of old shoes. The armored car had just delivered money to three branches of Metrobank on Friday and was empty, except for the personal belongings and breakfast leftovers stuffed inside the bags, police Sgt. Wilfredo Ramos said. The robbers, wearing combat fatigues and armed with automatic rifles, used their jeep to pull over the armored car in suburban Malabon and began firing at the van's four tires, Ramos said. The armored car's security escorts surrendered their two shotguns before opening rear doors to allow the robbers to scoop up several duffel bags. The robbers fled quickly, apparently without checking the bags. Police were surprised to find the guards laughing when they arrived. Among the personal items reported missing was ``a smelly, worn-out pair of shoes,'' Ramos said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
College Student Acquitted By Reason Of Insanity In Death Of Baby
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs.
DOC.TEXT: A college student accused of stuffing her newborn son in a dormitory toilet was found innocent of murder by reason of insanity today by jurors who at one point had declared themselves deadlocked. Claire Hilary Moritt fell into the arms of her defense attorney and exclaimed, ``I knew in my gut I wasn't guilty,'' after the acquittal was read. Family and friends burst into applause and tears. ``I thank God and everybody who helped me get through this,'' the tall, slim 18-year-old defendant said. ``I love you all.'' Hillsborough Circuit Judge Richard Lazzara said he did not believe hospitalization was necessary in light of the insanity finding but said Ms. Moritt should remain under psychiatric care. The Hillsborough Community College student from Hollywood was charged with first-degree murder in the Oct. 23 drowning of her newborn, 6-pound, 9-ounce boy. If convicted of that charge, she would automatically have been sent to prison for life with the possibility of parole only after 25 years. Dormitory roommates heard a baby's cries before finding Ms. Moritt in the bathroom covered in blood and rushed her to the hospital. When they returned to dorm to clean up, they found the baby stuffed headfirst in the toilet and covered with bloody towels and sheets. Defense attorneys argued that Ms. Moritt was temporarily insane, suffering from a dissociative disorder that left her with no memory of being pregnant or even giving birth. Nine psychiatrists and psychologists backed up that defense during the trial, but prosecutors blasted it all as ``psychobabble.'' ``She's attempting to flee _ not physically but mentally _ from the scene of the crime,'' Assistant State Attorney Stephen Crawford told the jury in closing arguments. ``Don't let her do it.'' The Hillsborough Circuit Court jury declared itself deadlocked Friday after 16 hours of deliberations but reached agreement after another hour behind closed doors today. Ms. Moritt ignored the advice of her lawyer and stood before the judge late Friday night to say she wanted jurors to press on. ``I'm prepared to declare a mistrial. Do you want me to declare a mistrial?,'' Lazzara asked the woman. ``No,'' she said, bursting into tears. The judge gave her a chance to compose herself and come back, but her response was the same. Lazzara warned defense counsel that urging on the weary jury could be foolish for his client. ``I want to be careful not to hold this jury hostage. It could backfire on the defendant. I want you to know that,'' Lazzara told defense attorney B. Anderson Mitcham. Never in his 27-year legal practice had he advised his client to turn down a mistrial, Mitcham said, but he added that he was bound to follow the wishes of his client, her mother and father. Outside court, the defense attorney explained that the stress of the two-week trial was taking a toll on the defendant and her family. ``She was charged with first-degree murder, she was under the care of a psychiatrist, and consider the enormous sums of money they spent trying to defend this case,'' Mitcham said. Ms. Moritt reportedly rejected numerous plea deals for reduced sentences because she did not want to spend even one day in prison.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Dead, More Than 180 Missing As Ferry Capsizes in Burma
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with 30 bodies found, 186 people still missing, lowers number rescued to 25 sted 50.
DOC.TEXT: A ferry with about 240 people aboard capsized during gale-force winds on a river in southern Burma, killing 30. More than 180 people were reported missing and feared dead, official Rangoon radio said. The double-decker boat, the Sein San Pya, sank almost immediately when the storm struck Friday, the report said. The ferry was on a regular run on the Gyaing River from Moulmein east to Kyondo in southern Tenasserim province. Moulmein is about 100 miles southeast of the capital, Rangoon. The bodies of 25 women and five men were recovered, 25 people were rescued and 186 were missing and feared dead, the radio reported. An earlier broadcast had said that 50 people were saved.

DOC.HEAD: Ferry Fire Kills At Least 75; Arson Suspected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with about 490 aboard, 75 missing and presumed dead, no motive known for arson. Pickup 13th graf `Waldegren said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto OSL2,4,GOT1,LON2
DOC.TEXT: A suspicious fire swept through a ferry carrying about 490 people in the North Sea before dawn today, killing at least 75 people and leaving about 75 missing and presumed dead, authorities said. The manager of the Danish company that operated the American-owned ship, which was carrying Danish and Norwegian tourists, said he believed the tragedy was caused by arsonists who set two fires on separate decks. The dead were found in cabins and on the car deck, where many people were apparently sleeping in their vehicles on the overnight trip from Norway to Denmark aboard the 10,000-ton Scandinavian Star, officials said. ``There was a lot of smoke and flames. It looked rather horrible,'' helicopter pilot Nils Martinsson, who helped in the rescue, told Swedish radio. Firemen found 75 bodies on the burning vessel, said Elsebeth Roalso of the Coastal Rescue Center at Sola, Norway. Seventy-five people were missing and presumed dead, said Christer Waldegren, spokesman for the Swedish Sea Rescue Center at Goteborg. About 340 people were rescued and taken to ports and hospitals in Norway, Sweden and Denmark. More than 20 of them were injured. Passenger and crew lists were not immediately available, and this led to confusion about the numbers and identities of those on board, officials said. About 200 passengers were Norwegians and the rest were Danes, officials said. Most were young people, families and retirees on a weekend trip. Helicopters and boats rescued the survivors from the 465-foot ship and from life boats. Early news reports said passengers had jumped into the near-freezing waters, but that could not be confirmed. Aage Danielsen, a Norwegian rescue vessel captain, said the missing passengers were believed still on the ferry. The ship is owned by the Miami-based SeaEscape Ltd., registered in the Bahamas, and had Norwegian officers and a Portuguese crew. Officials at SeaEscape could not immediately be reached for comment in Miami. Ole Hansen, managing director of Vognmandstruten, the Danish shipping company that operated the ferry, was quoted on Danish radio as saying he was virtually certain the blaze was the result of arson. Hansen said two separate fires broke out on the ship, the first at about 2:30 a.m. Officials gave no immediate details on how the fires may have started or what would have motivated someone to set fires that would have endangered them too. A blaze aboard the ship in 1988 was blamed on a leaky oil pipe. Waldegren said the blaze was under control but still burning 12 hours later. He said the ferry was being towed to Lysekil, Sweden, 140 miles southeast of Oslo. The fires broke out in the aft section of the ferry as it sailed in the Skagerrak strait from Oslo to the Fredrikshavn in Denmark. The captain reported the first fire as the ferry was about 40 miles south of the Norwegian Ferder Island in the outer Oslo fiord, or just west of the Swedish Vaeder islands. The crew quickly extinguished the fire, then discovered a larger blaze one deck below, reports said. ``When we came, there was a strong fire in the aft and strong smoke developing, and then only 30 to 45 minutes later it started burning also on the port side,'' Martinsson said. Rescued passengers said they heard no fire alarm but were awakened by the smell of smoke. Rescuers equipped with smoke-breathing apparatus searched the ferry for possible survivors, according to the coastal rescue center at Sola, near Stavanger, 180 miles west of Oslo. Bettina Kold, 20, a Danish employee in a retail shop on the Scandinavian Star, was quoted by NTB as saying her alarm clock woke her more than two hours after the fire began. She said she could not escape through smoke-filled corridors and was unable to break open her cabin window. She waited 90 minutes until a rescuer helped her out. Nearby vessels responded to the ferry's distress call. Soviet and West German freighters helped Norwegian and Swedish vessels pull survivors from lifeboats and ferry them to ports in Sweden, Norway and Denmark. Two tugs poured water into the Scandinavian Star. Soeren Kamp Knudsen, the Frederikshavn police chief, told Danish radio that police would investigate a possible link to previous ferry fires in Scandinavian waters. Earlier fires include one on the ferry Holger Danske near Oslo in September 1988 in which no one was killed. In February 1989, two crew members were injured in a fire on the King of Scandinavia, between Copenhagen and Oslo. NTB said the Scandinavian Star had been chartered for one week on the Oslo-Fredrikshavn route by the Danish company Vognmannsruten. A fire aboard the ship occurred in March 1988 off Cancun, Mexico, and was caused by leaking oil in the engine room. No one was injured. The U.S. National Transportation Safety board concluded that blaze was caused by inadequate maintenance, and it said the ship's crew lacked training in firefighting procedures.

DOC.HEAD: Speaker, 40 Pounds Lighter, Rarely Throws Weight Around
DOC.TEXT: After 10 months as speaker of the House, Tom Foley's most noticed accomplishment may be a remarkable 40-pound weight loss. Shedding the pounds, and with it any comparison to former speaker Tip O'Neill, came more quickly and apparently with greater ease than his first major legislative victory: passage of a child care bill. Foley made the bill one of his top priorities the day he became speaker last June, but he let it drag on and turn into a test of his mettle. This year he set an end-of-March deadline, and met it. ``I would say the first quarterly report of the Foley leadership is going to be a positive one, if for no other reason than the passage of this bill,'' a top lieutenant, Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md., said after the House passed the measure late last month. The bill provides tax credits and other assistance to parents for child care. Pushing through a clean air bill and campaign reform will pose similar tests this year. When Foley became speaker last June after Jim Wright of Texas resigned because of an ethics investigation, he was warmly greeted as a conciliator with the added quality of television presence. He and his fellow Democratic leaders offered a more modern face for the congressional majority to counter the Republican White House's media savvy. Any real measurement of his performance at this point is premature, House colleagues and outside observers say. The initial grades are mixed at best. His ability to win legislation has shown promise, but his unwillingness to lead or even join in a partisan charge against the Bush administration is rated a disappointment by many. Foley shrugs off such criticism, saying, ``We're unwilling to simply be an opposition party.'' Instead of making up his mind and convincing others to join him, he prods others toward consensus and then hops aboard. ``The question mark about Foley is whether he's tough enough to knock the heads when he has to, to make things happen,'' said Norman Ornstein, congressional scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative think tank. Some of Foley's fellow House Democrats say he has shown that toughness. ``What happened in child care is pretty instructive of what's going to happen the rest of the year,'' said Rep. Martin Frost, D-Texas, a former ally of Wright who has become a deputy whip under Foley. In the child care battle, Foley stood aside while Democratic committee chairmen fought their own turf battles, then imposed a deadline to force a resolution. Confident he had the votes, Foley and his leadership team used the House rules to limit debate and thereby block any Republican amendments. Once they decided on the final bill and made it public, Democrats were able to win its passage within 48 hours. ``This was the first time I have seen Foley deliberately use the muscle of the majority to drive something in an unfair way,'' said House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga. Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., complains that Foley has brought a return to ``back-room'' dealing in which it ``takes months for the Democrats to decide what their own position is.'' Edwards, chairman of the Republican Policy Committee, said that struggling with Foley ``is like fighting cotton candy.'' Foley's first months as speaker were otherwise without significant accomplishment _ except for passage of a big pay raise for Congress itself, done with the quiet agreement of Republicans. Although Democrats have a 258-176 majority, Foley was unable to stop House passage of President Bush's proposed cut in the capital gains tax last year. Foley also has been unable to forge a leadership position on a Social Security payroll tax cut proposed by Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y. Similarly, he has declined suggestions that the savings-and-loan bailout be made a partisan issue. ``Just heating this matter up when there is already some misunderstanding about it may not be in the best public interest, even though it might be somebody's view of a clever political ploy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hotel an Oasis of Opposites
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Minutes after Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir swept out of the Grand Hotel with his bodyguards in tow, a robed Arab leader was whisked into the suite Shamir had just vacated. It's a revolving door at the hotel, an oasis of opposites in Washington's diplomatic and political whirl. Democrats hold fund-raisers there. Republicans, too. AT&T stays there, as does MCI. And for $2,500 a night, intransigent foes from the Middle East also call the Grand home. You won't see Greta Garbo strolling languidly through the lobby, as she did in the hotel's namesake movie. But on a recent March morning, singer Janet Jackson went bouncing past the reception desk trailed by an entourage laden with luggage. Jackson wasn't the only celebrity. Guillermo Ford, Panama's vice president, was holding court in the lobby; Raphael Calderon, the president-elect of Costa Rica, was on a pre-inaugural visit to Washington; and Morocco's top military generals were in town. ``The lobby looked like a parking lot for bodyguards,'' said Samir Darwich, the Lebanese-born, French-educated manager. Arabic and Spanish drowned out English. The presidential suite, where kings and presidents stay, is vast. A grand piano graces the living room, a jacuzzi dominates the bathroom and the beds are truly king sized. Darwich says clients are drawn to the 260-room hotel by its European elegance, multilingual staff and unobtrusive service. But for some of his guests, security is the paramount consideration. ``We have proven we have the toughest, most sophisticated security in town,'' he said. Plainclothes guards, their identity often unknown to the hotel staff, mingle with the guests. It can get crowded, because visiting dignitaries also are protected by the U.S. Secret Service. ``We tell our security to use their brain, not their muscles,'' Darwich said. There has never been a clash between the guests or the guards, although a few close calls have pumped some adrenalin. There was the time former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres changed course and decided to shake hands with guests in the lobby on his way out, rather than use the side door to leave the hotel. Several Arab officials were in the lobby and the security agents were ``freaking out,'' said one witness. Several months ago, Israel's Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin was coming to town and asked to stay at the Grand. Rabin was not deterred after being told that a PLO official, Khaled al-Hassan, also was staying there, a source said. If the Palestinian is concerned, let him move out, Rabin reportedly said. In the end, al-Hassan stayed on the 5th floor, Rabin on the 9th. ``The hotel people did all they could to make sure they wouldn't bump into each other,'' said the source. The hotel staff is used to unexpected events. On a Sunday evening two years ago, Darwich got a frantic call from the State Department's protocol office: King Juan Carlos of Spain was stranded in Washington during a refueling stop because of mechanical trouble with his jet. ``We had 30 minutes to prepare to receive the king and his entourage of 70 people. They were all hungry,'' Darwich said. The pianist became a busboy, one of the owners turned into a waiter and Darwich carried suitcases. Darwich, a practicing Moslem, does not talk politics with his guests. Nor do the Lebanese owners, whose chain includes four hotels in Saudi Arabia and one in Switzerland. ``It's pure business for us,'' Darwich said. ``I don't care what nationality, religion, color or race, he is. As long as a guest pays the bill, he's my boss.''

DOC.HEAD: Public Mood in Cuba Is Hard To Assess
An AP Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Did the Americans play into Fidel Castro's hands by starting TV broadcasts to Cuba, giving him a credible new complaint about U.S. imperialism, or has jamming the telecasts increased hostility among his people? Judging public opinion in a relatively closed country like Cuba is a highly speculative undertaking. Cubans would like a more varied TV menu, but no one knows for sure what they think of the Voice of America operation, known as TV Marti. For that matter, estimates of support for the revolution itself after 31 years differ wildly. Like Radio Marti, another Voice of America venture, TV Marti's purpose is to provide balanced news and entertainment to a country where the Bush administration says both are in short supply. There is broad disagreement about how many listeners Radio Marti has after five years. One dissident described the audience as ``massive,'' but officials call it trifling. There are no reliable polls of public sentiment in Cuba. Some people wonder whether Castro is as oblivious to the public mood as were the Eastern European leaders ousted by popular uprisings last year. Cuban officials insist they have mechanisms that ensure people an opportunity to complain publicly without fear. In the Regla section of Havana last Monday, local leaders heard dozens of complaints from hundreds of citizens. Gripes were aired about the transportation system and the uneven distribution of goods to neighborhood stores. Similar meetings were held this past week all over the island. How durable is the revolution? Can Castro make viable a system that is being reviled in other places that tried it? A leader of the Young Communist League on Tuesday night predicted, somewhat extravagantly, that his group would still be functioning in 28,000 years. Two days later, a leader of a human rights group predicted, no less extravagantly, that popular discontent resulting from economic hardship will bring Castro down in less than a year. Whatever the truth, Castro is going all out to use the TV Marti issue to rally support. There is little doubt many Cubans agree with him that the broadcasts, which began March 27, violate national sovereignty. TV Marti, Castro says, is a ``gross instrument of subversion.'' Naming the station after the hero of Cuba's independence struggle, he says, is like an American naming a house of prostitution for George Washington. Boredom is a constant companion for many Cubans, however. They are intensely curious about what kind of programming TV Marti would bring and are disappointed by the successful jamming effort. The question is, how many are in each camp? The only known instance of a test, albeit limited, of public sentiment occurred in an east Havana neighborhood a year ago. The results were not encouraging for the government. A human rights activist, Roberto Bahamonde, ran for a municipal assembly seat as a proponent of a free press, free speech and free enterprise _ heretical views in Marxist Cuba. He lost 60-30, but there were 59 abstentions in the show-of-hands vote. Presumably, many who abstained were closet Bahamonde supporters who felt voting for him openly could lead to charges of disloyalty. The establishment candidate, Gerardo Aldama, won slightly more than 40 percent of the vote, virtually the same as President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua in his losing re-election campaign in February. Bahamonde was arrested two weeks after election night and won't be free until July. The government says his detention is based on participation in illegal meetings and on economic crimes rather than his political stands.
