Survivors and rescuers told stories of confusion during one of Scandinavia's worst sea disasters. Passengers trying to reach the open decks lost their way in narrow, smoky corridors and died there. Some were asphyxiated in their cabins. Tom Brokopp, a doctor at Uddevalla hospital, near Lysekil, quoted several passengers as saying alarms didn't work and crew members had trouble understanding each other. ``It was chaotic,'' Neilsen said. ``It was clear that the crew was not trained for this kind of situation.'' News reports said the Bahamian-registered ferry had a mixed Portuguese and Filipino crew, with Norwegian officers, and that the crew had joined the vessel within the past two weeks. When the fire broke out, some passengers were still awake but many were asleep in cabins. ``We woke up in the middle of the night. I heard a noise outside. I went out of the cabin and saw thick, black smoke,'' said Danish passenger Leo Odeland, an Oslo resident traveling with his wife and two daughters. ``Nothing happened when I pushed the fire alarm. I hadn't heard the alarm go off. At another place where there was supposed to be an alarm, nothing was there.'' Odeland said the crew was ``apparently new and untrained.'' ``It was hard to get the lifeboat into the water, and then the motor didn't start,'' he said, adding that the lifeboat drifted away and a Soviet freighter picked them up. Bettina Kold, 20, a Danish employee in the ferry's duty-free shop, said her alarm clock woke her at 4:45 a.m. According to rescuers, the Scandinavian Star radioed a distress call at 2:30 a.m. Kold said she smelled smoke but heard no fire alarm. She found it impossible to enter the smoke-filled corridor and waited in her cabin for 90 minutes until a rescuer arrived. ``There were plenty of people aboard, and I guess they all tried to leave at the same time,'' said Norwegian fireman Sven-Johan Svenson. ``In the heavy smoke, it would be easy to take a wrong turn. People would panic in those narrow corridors. ``Some of those who got left behind and died just didn't find their way out.'' ``Neither the fire alarm nor the loudspeaker worked,`` said passenger Elisabeth Skeiro.

DOC.HEAD: Newsweek Poll: Keep Gorby As Our Friend
DOC.TEXT: Fifty-nine percent of Americans believe it's more important to maintain good relations with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev than to recognize an independent Lithuania, according to a poll released Saturday. The poll, reported in the April 16 issue of Newsweek, also found that 66 percent of Americans questioned approved of President Bush's handling of the situation in Eastern Europe. Some Democrats accuse the president of failing to exert leadership as the industrial democracies struggle to respond to and shape change in the region. Bush received an 18 percent disapproval rating on Eastern Europe. The poll was based on 601 telephone interviews conducted by The Gallup Organization on April 5 and 6. The margin of error is 5 percent. Bush's approval rating on Eastern European issues has remained nearly constant for several months. In November 1989, he received the backing of 63 percent, Newsweek said. In December 1989, it was 68 percent. On the Lithuanian question, 27 percent felt the United States should recognize an independent country to pressure Gorbachev into doing the same. But 59 percent said keeping good relations with the Soviet leader was more important, and 14 percent had no opinion. Americans were divided on whether countries in Eastern Europe should receive more U.S. financial aid than those in Latin America. Twenty-eight percent wanted more money for Eastern Europe, 27 percent backed Latin America, and 26 percent said there should be no change in foreign aid policy. Nineteen percent said they didn't know.

DOC.HEAD: Firebombs Damages President's Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with university president saying he doesn't believe attack related to campus controversy over treatment of minorities. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Three firebombs tossed early Saturday into the office of the president of Wesleyan University caused minor damage and shook school officials. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack. Wesleyan officials said the South College building was unoccupied when three crudely made Molotov cocktails crashed through the window of President William M. Chace's first-floor office. There were no reports of injuries. The minor explosion and fire damaged a carpet and furniture, but was limited to a seven-foot area near the window, said university spokesman Bobby Wayne Clark. A security guard heard glass breaking and saw man running from the area about 4 a.m., but was unable to catch him, Clark said. Chace said he didn't believe the bombing was related to recent student unrest over allegations the administration of the exclusive liberal arts school is insensitive to minority students and faculty. This winter, 60 students took over the administrative offices to protest what they said is a lack of support for minorities on campus.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Poindexter, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf ``John Poindexter xxx to include potential Poindexter sentence; SUBS 4th graf, ``Robert McFarlane xxx to insert material on McFarlane, Secord, _Robert McFarlane,; SUBS 8TH GRAF, ``Albert Hakim xxx to CORRECT forego to forgo; adds 1 graf with Clines facing trial
DOC.TEXT: Here is the legal status of key figures in the Iran-Contra affair: _John Poindexter, former national security adviser, found guilty at a jury trial April 7 of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements in connection with Reagan administration assistance to the Contras and a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Sentencing has been set for June 11. He faces a maximum of 25 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines. _Oliver North, former National Security Council aide, found guilty at a jury trial May 4 of three felonies _ aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress, destroying official documents and accepting an illegal gratuity _ and sentenced to two years probation, fined $150,000 and ordered to perform 1,200 hours of community service. He is appealing the conviction, the fine and probation while serving the community service in an anti-drug program. _Robert McFarlane, former national security adviser, pleaded guilty to four misdemeanors of withholding information from Congress by denying that the NSC staff was soliciting support for the Contras' military activities and helping move supplies to the rebels and denying that he knew anything about third-country financing of the Contras. Was placed on two years' probation, fined $20,000 and sentenced to 200 hours of community service. _Richard Secord, a retired Air Force major general, pleaded guilty Nov. 8 to lying to congressional investigators when he said he wasn't aware of any money that went to the benefit of North from the maze of companies known as ``the Enterprise,'' which Secord had used in the Iran-Contra affair. Secord on Jan. 24 was sentenced to two years probation. _Carl ``Spitz'' Channell, pleaded guilty to using his non-profit National Endowment for the Preservation of Liberty to raise more than $2 million to buy weapons for the Nicaraguan rebels. Sentenced to two years probation for conspiring to defraud the Treasury of taxes due on the money raised with North's assistance. _Richard Miller, head of a Washington public relations company, pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the Internal Revenue Service of taxes on contributions used to supply military aid to the Nicaraguan Contras. Sentenced to two years probation. _Albert Hakim, Iranian-born businessman who with Secord ran ``the Enterprise,'' pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor of aiding and abetting in supplementing North's income by paying for a security fence at North's home. Hakim was fined $5,000 and sentenced to two years probation Feb. 1. He agreed to forgo his claims on more than $7 million in profits from the Reagan administration's Iran arms sales. Also, a company he set up, Lake Resources, pleaded guilty to theft of government property in connection with Iran arms sale money diverted from the U.S. government. The judge ordered that company be dissolved. _Joseph Fernandez, former CIA station chief in Costa Rica, charged with obstruction and making false statements in connection with his assistance to North's Contra resupply network. The judge in the case said the charges must be dismissed due to the attorney general's ban on the use of classified material Fernandez needs for his defense. Iran-Contra prosecutors are appealing. _Former CIA agent Thomas Clines, indicted for allegedly failing to report some of his income to the Internal Revenue Service that he received for working for North's Contra resupply network. Clines, a business partner of Secord and Hakim, has pleaded innocent and is scheduled to go on trial May 14 in U.S. District Court in Baltimore. Clines located a European arms dealer as a source of weapons for the Contras and helped arrange for shipping and lined up crews to transport the supplies to the rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Cold in South; Snow in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: A cold snap in the South on Saturday set record lows in several cities, and snow fell in the Northeast. The coldest temperatures on record for so late in the season were set at Evansville, Ind., 23 degrees, and across the Ohio River in nearby Paducah, Ky., 24 degrees. Rain showers were scattered across Delaware, Maryland and southern New Jersey. Rain also fell from south-central Idaho into northern Utah. Snow showers lingered over the northern section of lower Michigan in the morning Saturday. Snow also fell across New York state, western and southern Pennsylvania, and southeastern New England, the National Weather Service said. Chatham, Mass., had 2 inches of snow, and Johnstown, Pa., had 1 inch. Snow in New York City postponed an exhibition baseball game at Shea Stadium between the crosstown rivals, the Mets and Yankees. ``It's not really that odd. People think, `Oh, it's snowing in April.' It's just a little unusual,'' said meteorologist Gene Salerno. ``Now, if this was July ...'' Unseasonable cold was expected to reach into the Southeast late Saturday. Frost and freeze warnings were posted over northern Alabama, northern and central Georgia, the mountains and foothills of South Carolina and all of North Carolina except the coastline. Record breaking cold also was expected overnight Saturday in east central Tennessee. Showers were forecast across the mid-section of the Rockies on Sunday. The low for the nation Saturday was 8 degrees at Brookings, S.D. Temperatures dipped to 29 degrees in Hot Springs and Fort Smith, Ark., breaking their records for April 7. Records also were broken at Huntsville, Ala., 29; Jackson, Miss., 31; Mena, Ark., 31.; and Springfield, Mo., 25.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Breaks Out at Dartmoor Prison; Strangeways Standoff Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with prison governor reporting small number of injuries, prisoners having control of wing, advanced warning of disturbance; picks up 4th graf pvs, ``One of...
DOC.TEXT: Rioting broke out at Dartmoor Prison in southwest England Saturday with some injuries reported, as authorities in northern England negotiated with fewer than 25 inmates who continued their weeklong uprising. The Home Office said prisoners in Dartmoor's D Wing _ which houses 100 inmates _ refused to return to their cells. Dartmoor prison governor John May, speaking to journalists outside the prison, said a small number of people were injured. But he gave no details. He said 103 prisoners were believed to have taken control of one wing and about five hooded prisoners were on the roof. Prisoners also had control of the roof of another wing. May said prison officers had received intelligence there would be trouble this weekend, but he did not say what measures were taken to prevent it. Prison Officers' Association head John Bartell said a search of the prison had turned up a hoard of weapons and some prisoners had been transferred. Extra staff was brought in from nearby prisons to restore order, and police were standing by on the perimeter, a prison spokeswoman said. No escapes were reported and the seized wing had been sealed off, she said. One of Britain's most famous prisons, Dartmoor was opened in 1809 to house French prisoners from the Napoleonic Wars and is located near Princetown in the remote and rugged moorland of Devonshire, 160 miles southwest of London. As many as 120 inmates were involved in the Dartmoor disturbance, Prison Officers' Association chairman John Bartell said. The Devon fire brigade and ambulance service said they were standing by at the prison. At Strangeways Prison near Manchester, where more than 1,500 prisoners rioted April 1, the number still on the loose was reduced to fewer than 25, prison governor Brendan O'Friel said. Three more surrendered Saturday afternoon. A helicopter hovered over the Victorian prison early in the morning to disturb the sleep of rebellious inmates, and barking dogs, shouting guards and powerful spotlights were also deployed to wear down inmates after the weeklong siege. ``We have been using a certain amount of noise tactics to reduce the, in our view, unauthorized access of prisoners to the media,'' O'Friel said. ``We have continued to put pressure on the prisoners in other ways.'' But he said authorities still hoped to negotiate an end to the impasse. Strangeways had been one of the most crowded prisons in England. It was heavily damaged in a riot that broke out at a chapel service April 1. The prison, which was built in 1868 to house 970 male prisoners, had 1,648 when the riot there broke out during a service in the prison chapel.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Storm Manila Jail, Free Officer Accused in Coup
DOC.TEXT: Masked rebel soldiers stormed the Manila city jail Sunday during a birthday party for a warden and freed an officer accused of helping to lead December's failed coup, police said. In a statement to reporters, the Young Officers' Union, a shadowy group linked to the failed coup, took responsibility for the jailbreak. Four other inmates held for common crimes were also freed along with Lt. Col. Billy Bibit in the predawn raid, police said. Hours earlier, military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa had warned that mutineers would try to free some of the more than 2,200 officers and enlisted men held in connection with the Dec. 1-9 failed coup. Police Sgt. Florentino Bagallon said jailers had ordered beer from a nearby restaurant for a birthday celebration for deputy warden Capt. Manuel Roxas. When they opened the compound gate to allow the delivery man inside, about 15 masked gunmen forced their way in, disarmed the guards and then pried open Bibit's cell with a metal bar. Bibit and the others fled in two cars and a van, Bagallon said. At about the same time, armed men attacked the police station next to the jail in a hail of gunfire, disarmed policemen and cut telephone lines from the building. The gunmen fled with three pistols seized from the guards. Police said the rebels arrived in a stolen dump truck, which they abandoned after the raid. Police said they were preparing negligence charges against at least two jail guards. The guards refused to talk with police Superintendent Col. Ernesto Diokno until they had conferred with a lawyer. Bibit, intelligence chief of the customs bureau, was arrested in January for allegedly raiding the customs armory to provide weapons during the coup attempt, in which 113 people were killed and more than 600 wounded. It was the sixth and bloodiest attempt to topple President Corazon Aquino since she took office in the 1986 ``people power'' revolution that ousted the late President Ferdinand Marcos. Bibit was described as a member of the core group that planned and led the coup attempt. Bagallon said Bibit had been detailed to the customs bureau but was still on active duty in the military. Bibit was the only alleged coup participant among the Manila jail's 300 inmates, police said. Others in the conspiracy are detained at military stockades, where there have been complaints about lax security. Detainees include about 300 officers. On Saturday, de Villa told reporters that renegade former Lt. Col. Gregorio Honasan, a leader of the December coup attempt, had been sending word to jailed comrades that his followers would try to free them. De Villa dismissed Honasan's message as an attempt ``to prevent the collapse of morale'' among the prisoners. Honasan also led a coup attempt in August 1987. He was arrested the following December but escaped in April 1988 from a prison ship in Manila Bay with the help of his guards. In November 1988, the commander of the Communist rebel army, Romulo Kintanar, escaped from a military stockade along with his wife during a birthday party for his jailer.

DOC.HEAD: Unassuming Indiana Teen-ager Taught America About AIDS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 1 graf after 21st graf, `Sen. Edward...,' to update with visits from Jesse Jackson, Farm Aid singers.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY24
DOC.TEXT: Ryan White, the pale, gaunt teen-ager who won a lengthy legal battle to attend public school, learned a hard lesson about fear but taught the public a more important lesson about his deadly disease, AIDS. ``This kid is unbelievably important to us,'' Surgeon General Antonia Novello said in a telephone interview last week from Washington. ``He's the kid who was able to communicate with adults as well as children. He's a spokesperson for the whole AIDS crisis,'' Novello said. ``He was able to fight alone the stigmatization of the disease.'' White was hospitalized March 29 with an AIDS-related respiratory infection at Riley Hospital for Children, where he remained sedated in critical but stable condition on a ventilator Saturday. ``We look for optimistic trends,'' his physician, Dr. Martin Kleiman, said Saturday. ``We have not seen enough change to change his status.'' White contracted AIDS in 1984 at age 13 from a blood-clotting agent used to treat his hemophilia. ``He's shown us the disease is purely a disease and has no social implications,'' Kleiman said last week. White gained national attention in 1985 after he was barred from attending Western Middle School near Kokomo because of his AIDS. His family sued. The case was in and out of courts, other families petitioned to keep White out of school, but White finally won. ``Personally, I would rather have given it up a long time ago,'' White's mother, Jeanne, said during the court battle. ``It would have been a lot easier on me and a lot easier on the rest of the family. ``But, believe it or not, Ryan has always really loved school. (Ryan's sister) Andrea says, `Boy, I wish it would be me that could stay home.' But this is what Ryan wants to do, and I want what he wants.'' Mrs. White moved her family to Cicero, about 20 miles from their home, saying they did not want to stay where they were unwanted. White said at the time that he did not want to die in Kokomo or to be buried there. They were welcomed by the new community and the school system. The battle provided the impetus for the first revision of Indiana's communicable disease law since its original draft in 1948, and gave many Americans a person with AIDS to identify with. ``He's young, white and middle-class,'' said Eric Engstrom, executive director of the National AIDS Network. ``Many people could see themselves in Ryan. Ryan understood that and worked to educate people and raise awareness. He's been an incredible catalyst for acknowledgement of the AIDS crisis.'' Dr. Woodrow Myers, state health commissioner during White's battle to attend school and now health commissioner for New York City, said White answered a call for leadership. ``America saw in living color what it's like to be the victim of unnecessary, unwarranted fear,'' Myers said. ``It also saw someone who endured that struggle with bravery and with his head held high and with a spirit of determination that I've found rare.'' A national educational and fund-raising program to fight misconceptions about children carrying the AIDS virus was named in White's honor. ``I came face to face with death at 13 years old'' but decided ``to live a normal life,'' he testified before the White House AIDS Commission. He was on the cover of People magazine. His story was dramatized in an ABC television movie, ``The Ryan White Story,'' in which he played a cameo role. While White was unconcious in his hospital bed last week, thousands of people called the hospital to offer support. President Bush planted a tree during a ceremony here while visiting the city on a political trip, and dedicated the tree to White, saying, ``Let it be Ryan's tree.'' Singer Elton John kept a vigil with the family and distributed $500 worth of toys to other patients. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., called Mrs. White after a Senate committee unanimously approved his bill providing $600 million in emergency funds for AIDS care. ``This one's for you, Ryan,'' Kennedy said. The Rev. Jesse Jackson visited White Saturday, accompanied by singers Willie Nelson and Kris Kristofferson, who were in Indianapolis for the Farm Aid IV benefit concert. Other calls have come from Vice President Dan Quayle and entertainers Michael Jackson, Phil Donahue, Carol Burnett and Lionel Richie. The Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta said 125,000 AIDS cases had been reported through February and 76,031 people had died from complications related to the disease. The CDC estimated 1 million people in the U.S. carry the virus. What makes Ryan White special? ``Through him we learned that education of the public is possible,'' Novello said. ``And for everyone out there who learns to hate, someone out there learns to care because of Ryan.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The family has asked that donations and cards be sent to the Ryan White Fund, P.O. Box 40, Noblesville, Ind. 46060.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed, Six Wounded During Prison Search in Tijuana
DOC.TEXT: A surprise search for weapons and drugs triggered rioting at a prison Saturday that left one inmate dead and six people wounded, authorities said. Inmates threw rocks and bottles as about 200 law enforcement officials concluded the search at La Mesa state penitentiary, said district attorney Jorge Mario de Regules. Some inmates fired guns, he said. It was unclear where the inmates got the weapons, or who fired the shots that killed one inmate and wounded two police officers, he said. Officers fired their weapons into the air in an effort to restore order, he said, and the violence was quelled in an hour. ``It was not a full-blown riot but it sure seemed like one,'' said de Regules, who took part in the search. All six of the wounded were taken to hospitals, but none were in grave condition, the district attorney said. Handguns, knives, marijuana, cocaine and heroin were confiscated during the search. The prison has about 2,000 inmates, including 200 women inmates and children of some prisoners.

DOC.HEAD: Macho or Not _ Officers Can Wear Earrings
DOC.TEXT: Earrings probably won't become de rigueur among the ranks of Portland's Finest, but policemen wishing to adorn their ears with dainty pieces of precious metal may now do so. The city attorney's office has advised the police to allow male officers to wear earrings after a policeman filed a labor grievance recently. The office got involved because of a grievance filed by an officer whose name is being withheld, said Stan Peters, president of the Portland Police Association said. The grievance challenged rules on proper attire that specified female officers must wear small, non-dangling earrings, but didn't really address the question of ear decorations for males. Police officials say they'll follow the city attorney's advice, but they don't have to like it. ``I don't think the public is prepared to see a male police officer wear an earring,'' said Capt. Wayne Inman. ``But I do see a shift in public attitudes to allow police officers to mirror society's dress code.''

DOC.HEAD: List Of Notable Marine Fire Disasters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Herald of Free Enterprise capsizing off Belgium in 1987
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Ferry Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of notable marine disasters involving fire since 1850: _ Sept. 23, 1858: 471 killed when fire destroys German steamer Austria in North Atlantic. _ Oct. 27, 1869: 200 killed when steamer Stonewall burns on Mississippi River below Cairo, Ill. _ Nov. 15, 1887: 400 killed when British steamer Wah Yeung burns at sea. _ June 15, 1904: 1,030 killed when excursion steamer General Slocum burns in East River, New York City. _ Sept. 17, 1949: 130 killed when Canadian Great Lakes Cruiser Noronic burns at Toronto dock. _ Nov. 13, 1965: 90 killed when Panamanian-registered cruise ship Yarmouth Castle burns and sinks off Nassau, Bahamas. _ July 29, 1967: 134 killed when U.S. aircraft carrier Forrestal catches fire off North Vietnam. _ Sept. 26, 1974: More than 200 killed when Soviet destroyer burns and sinks in Black Sea. _ Dec. 25, 1976: About 100 killed when Egyptian liner Patria catches fire and sinks in Red Sea. _ Jan. 27, 1981: 580 killed when Indonesian passenger ship Tamponas II catches fire and sinks in Java sea. _ May 25, 1983: 357 killed when Nile steamer 10th of Ramadan catches fire and sinks in L. Nassar. _ March 6, 1987: 189 killed when car ferry Herald of Free Enterprise capsizes off Belgian port of Zeebrugge.

DOC.HEAD: Drug To Go On Toxics List
DOC.TEXT: California will require aspirin makers to warn women against taking the drug in the late stages of pregnancy, a state science panel has decided. The panel on Friday classified aspirin a ``reproductive toxin'' under Proposition 65, the landmark toxics initiative law that requires public warnings for substances that pose a risk of cancer or birth defects. The warnings _ probably on aspirin labels _ must appear within one year after a substance is formally listed in keeping with the panel's decision. In making its recommendation, the panel rejected a $500,000 report prepared by the aspirin industry. That report said it found no evidence that aspirin taken in the last three months of pregnancy could cause excessive bleeding during delivery and other pregnancy complications. The panel unanimously ruled that such risks have been shown, based on studies involving high aspirin dosage. But panel members also acknowledged recent studies that aspirin in very low doses _ half a tablet or less _ may relieve certain medical problems suffered by pregnant women. They said the aspirin warning should be qualified to advise women against taking aspirin in the last three months of pregnancy ``... unless directed to do so by your doctor.'' Aspirin products have carried a general warning label since 1982 and certain over-the-counter aspirin substitutes also carry a label that reads: ``It is especially important not to use aspirin during the last three months of pregnancy unless specifically directed to do so by your doctor because it may cause problems in the unborn child or complications during delivery.'' Proposition 65 mandates public warnings but does not dictate warning labels on specific products. However, a spokesman for the aspirin industry said a warning label seemed likely in about a year. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration notified state authorities last week that it planned to require a new warning on over-the-counter aspirin products similar to the warning under review by the Proposition 65 panel. But science panel members said they saw no point in waiting for federal action. Aspirin industry representatives said the FDA was pushed into action by Proposition 65, which has served as a model for toxics legislation across the country.

DOC.HEAD: Ferry Sinks in Burma, 30 Dead, 186 Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to ADD details, background on past ferry disasters; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A river ferry capsized and sank during a fierce storm in the south, killing at least 30 people, government radio reported Saturday. It said 186 were missing and believed drowned. The double-decker ferry Sein San Pya overturned in gale-force winds Friday afternoon with 241 people aboard, Rangoon Radio said. The bodies of 25 women and five men, including two Buddhist monks, were recovered, but 186 people were still missing, the radio said. It said 25 people were rescued. An earlier broadcast said 50 people were saved. That report said some of the dead were children and that all those missing were presumed drowned. Among the people aboard the vessel were 12 crewmembers and 10 security policemen, the report said. The ferry was making a regular run on the Gyaing river from the town of Moulmein, about 100 miles southeast of Rangoon, to the town of Kyondo in the southern province of Tenasserim, the report said. It sank about 12:30 p.m., the report said. The vessel went down almost immediately as the storm struck, the broadcast said. It gave no other details. Ferry accidents in southern Burma have claimed many lives in recent years. In May 1987, an aging vessel with 400 people aboard overturned and sank in the Rangoon River. Reports at the time said that 283 people were rescued, but no official death toll was announced. In October 1989, 60 people were reported missing and believed dead after a double-decker ferry with 170 passengers aboard sank in a storm near Rangoon. Safety standards are often very lax in this southeast Asian nation.

DOC.HEAD: Attacks by Leftist Guerrillas in Colombia Leave 19 Dead
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels Saturday stormed into two southern towns, robbing banks, looting stores and fighting battles with government forces that left 19 people dead, authorities said. Police said 13 rebels and six police officers were killed during the attacks by a total of about 150 rebels. Five of the officers where shot and killed when members of the National Liberation Army and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia attacked a police station in the town of Sibundoy, 322 miles south of Bogota, said police spokesman Col. Guillermo Ramirez. Another policeman died in fighting in the nearby town of San Francisco, Ramirez said. Rebels in both towns were looting stores and robbing banks when they were surprised by army troops in several helicopter gunships, Ramirez said in a live radio interview. He gave no other details of the fighting. The National Liberation Army has become the most active and most violent of five leftist guerrilla groups in Colombia. It is headed by a former Catholic priest, Manuel Perez. Authorities say the group regularly attacks army and police patrols. It has blown up the country's main oil pipeline dozens of times in the last three years. In March, the leftist group April 19 Movement laid down its weapons and signed a peace treaty with President Virgilio Barco's government. However, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and the National Liberation Army have continued attacking police and military targets. The National Liberation Army has said it will never negotiate peace with the government.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands of Israelis Call for Election Reform
LaserPhoto TLV2
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Israelis rallied Saturday demanding electoral reform in a movement spurred by public anger over political wheeling-and-dealing in a bid to form a new government. Demonstrators who gathered in Tel Aviv's central Kings of Israel square carried Israeli flags and wore stickers criticizing both major political parties, Likud and Labor. The stickers read ``Are you sick and tired?'' and ``Horsetraders in the market are more decent.'' Israel television said tens of thousands protested in front of City Hall, while Israel Army Radio estimated the crowd at 250,000. One city official estimated it at more than 120,000. Police refused to give estimates. The protest was called after Labor Party leader Shimon Peres announced that he had formed a coalition that included a ultra-Orthodox religious party and a defector from the right-wing Likud bloc of caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Labor is a left-of-center party. Peres informed President Chaim Herzog on Wednesday he had put together a potential governing coalition. The announcement came two weeks after he was assigned to try to form a new government. Shamir lost a no-confidence vote March 15 in a crisis triggered by a dispute over U.S. conditions for holding Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. Peres forced the showdown with Shamir, who was reluctant to accept the U.S. proposals on forming a Palestinian delegation. The protest campaign was initiated by a group of mayors and the Constitution for Israel Organization, which seeks to revamp the political system. It also won the support of President Herzog. Uriel Reichman, a law professor who heads the group, told Israel radio reformers wanted direct election of the prime minister and one half of the 120 parliament members as well as a bill of rights. ``Now, we are no longer lobbying. We are no longer asking. Now, we are demanding that the change will come and right away,'' said Reichman, who called the political maneuverings of the two major parties a betrayal of trust. Critics have accused both Labor and Likud of offering government money and political jobs to entice small religious factions and encourage individual members of parliament to switch sides. Peres reportedly gave $3.5 million to religious institutions affiliated with parties that he hoped would support his bid for power hours before he left the finance minister's post last month. At the same time, Shamir's Likud raised $2.5 million from party contributors as a guarantee to underwrite its promise of a cabinet post for Yitzhak Modai, a Likud ally who was threatening to defect to Labor.

DOC.HEAD: C&P Telephone Suspended in Long-Running Contract Competition With A&T
DOC.TEXT: The Chesapeake & Potomac Telephone Company and its parent company have been suspended from signing new contracts with the federal government on grounds C&P sales people made false statements about whether the kind of telephones they proposed to install for the Treasury Department were already in wide use. Treasury officials said the statements were made during recent negotiations over a disputed contract in which American Telephone & Telegraph Co. is competing with C&P and, by extension, its parent Bell Atlantic Corp. The agency invoked a federal law that allows any agency to hold up contract awards from any other federal agency pending resolution of the dispute. In fiscal 1989, 585 individuals or companies were suspended from receiving new contracts under the regulations Treasury applied to C&P and Bell Atlantic. The current ruling does not affect federal contracts already signed by C&P and Bell Atlantic, including one under which C&P is to begin switching on a private phone network for federal offices in the Washington area, a job that is estimated to be worth about $220 million to $280 million over 10 years. However, it would put on hold C&P's pending bid for a major Defense Department telephone contract known as Tempo. The claims center on whether telephones C&P proposes to use on the Treasury job are available commercially. Federal contracting procedures normally require that items bought by the government be market-tested so it is not saddled with new, unproven equipment. In a statement issued Friday in response to the Treasury action, Bell Atlantic officials called the suspension ``an abuse of authority and a subversion of the government's own bidding process.'' The company accused low-level employees at the Treasury of trying to award AT&T contract worth about $90 million to provide a 20,000-line telephone system for 16 Treasury locations in the district. Twice since 1987, Treasury has awarded the contract in question to AT&T only to have C&P win appeals to the General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals. ``C&P will not be harassed out of this competition,'' Tony Murray, Bell Atlantic federal systems division vice president, said Friday. The company said it will challenge the Treasury's move. AT&T has not commented on the latest development. C&P provides local telephone service to the metropolitan Washington area and is owned by Bell Atlantic, a Philadelphia-based regional telephone company.

DOC.HEAD: Gun That Teddy Roosevelt Carried Up San Juan Hill Stolen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to correct date to 1898 sted 1989.
DOC.TEXT: The pistol Teddy Roosevelt carried in his charge up San Juan Hill has been stolen, officials said Saturday. The .45-caliber Colt revolver was discovered missing from Sagamore Hill, the Long Island home of the nation's 26th president, which is run as a museum by the National Park Service. Chief Ranger Ray Bloomer, who is blind, noticed Saturday that the exhibit case that contained the gun was loose, and summoned a sighted Park Service investigator. Nothing else was missing from the case, which also contained Roosevelt's Rough Riders uniform, hat and gloves. It appeared someone forced open a door to the case Thursday or Friday, Bloomer said. Fifty to 100 visitors pass through on an average day. The pistol, now valued at $500,000, was given to Roosevelt after it was recovered from the battleship Maine, whose sinking in Havana Harbor in 1898 led to the United States' declaration of war against Spain. The gun's blued barrel is inscribed with the words, ``July 1, 1898, San Juan, carried and used by Col. Theodore Roosevelt,'' and ``From the sunken battleship MAINE.'' Roosevelt killed at least one enemy soldier with the gun during the charge up San Juan Hill that gave the U.S. Army control of the hills overlooking Havana and Roosevelt his reputation as a national hero, Bloomer said. The only other weapon he carried during the charge was his sword. The inscription should make it difficult to sell at its estimated value of $500,000, said Park Service spokeswoman Edie Shean-Hammond. Roosevelt became president after William McKinley was assassinated in 1901 and served until 1909.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Soviets Reject U.S. Missile Ban Plan
DOC.TEXT: The United States last month secretly proposed a ban on some land-based missiles with multiple nuclear warheads but the Soviet Union said the plan was too limited, according to a published report. The New York Times reported in its Sunday editions that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev responded to the proposal last week, complaining that it excluded submarine-based ballistic missiles. A letter containing Gorbachev's reply was delivered to President Bush Friday by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, the paper said, quoting administration officials it didn't name. The White House refused to confirm the offer or refusal, the Times said. The offer signals an attempt by Bush to put his stamp on arms reduction talks which thus far have followed proposals made during the Reagan Administration, the Times said. The rejection of the proposal caught the White House by surprise, the Times said, adding that Bush administration officials believe the Soviet Union's tougher position reflects a move by Soviet military officials to assert themselves. One unidentified White House official told the Times that Secretary of State James Baker III first presented the proposal to Shevardnadze last month in Namibia, where both were attending independence ceremonies. The proposal would ban mobile land-based missiles with multiple warheads, followed by the eventual elimination of all land-based missiles with multiple warheads. Administration officials said Moscow showed little interest in the first stage of the Bush plan, the Times reported. That first step, which could have been considered as part of the strategic arms treaty being negotiated this year, would have prevented the United States from deploying 10-warhead MX missiles on rail cars. It would have forced Moscow to remove its 10-warhead SS-24 missiles from railroad launchers and put them in stationary silos. The United States bases more of its ballistic missile warheads at sea, while the Soviet Union has most of its missiles on land.

DOC.HEAD: Naturalist Whose Bird Paintings Adorned Stamps Dies at 72
DOC.TEXT: Arthur B. Singer, a naturalist and painter whose watercolors of state birds were affixed to hundreds of thousands of letters mailed in the 1980s, died Saturday. He was 72. Singer died at his home in Jericho, on Long Island, of cancer of the esophagus. The stamp series bearing Singer's paintings is believed to have been the largest-selling special issue in the history of U.S. postage. The Postal Service issued the stamps featuring the birds and flowers of the 50 states in 1982. Singer, who graduated from the Cooper Union Art School in New York in 1939, received its Augustus St. Gaudens Medal in 1962 after 750 of his paintings appeared in ``Birds of the World,'' the first of many books he illustrated. Golden Press issued a new edition of the book in 1983. He received the Hal Borland Award from the National Audubon Society in 1985, on the 200th anniversary of Audubon's birth. Singer's youngest son, Alan, painted the wildflowers that appeared on the 1982 postage stamps. He also is survived by another son, Paul; his second wife, Dale Singer, and two grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: 17 Dead, 55 Wounded in Pakistani Street Battle
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen loyal to Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's party clashed with opposition supporters during a two-day shooting spree that left 17 people dead and 55 wounded, authorities said Saturday. Police moved in early in the day and arrested 30 people. Half belonged to Mrs. Bhutto's party, and half were from militant Altaf Hussein's Indian immigrant movement. Police said marauding gunmen killed three people late Saturday afternoon and wounded 10 more, bringing to death toll to 17 and the wounded to 55. The assailants began racing through this southern city's central district after sunset Friday, firing at bystanders, police said. The shooting ended around sunrise, but it broke out briefly late Saturday afternnon, police said. Police arrested four members of Ms. Bhutto's party after a wild car chase through the congested streets of Pakistan's largest city. Among those detained was the president of the party's student wing. Hussein blamed Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party for the killings. ``It is the PPP, with the patronage of the government, that has unleashed the terrorists ....'' said Hussein. He told a news conference he would start a hunger strike Sunday if his supporters are not released and the ``real murderers'' are not arrested. Karachi, once a peaceful, affluent city of 8 million, has become a battleground, with political parties and rival ethnic groups fighting pitched battles in alleyways. Kidnappings and torture are commonplace. Ms. Bhutto's left-of-center party and the Hussein's right-wing Mohajir Qami Movement are the main combatants in the political battle. The Indian movement once was an ally of Ms. Bhutto, but it withdrew its support in November when it committed its 14 National Assembly seats to her opposition. The opposition then called a no-confidence vote, which she narrowly survived. Ms. Bhutto's party governs the 237-seat National Assembly. More than 60 people have been gunned down in the last month in Karachi, according to police and relief organizations.

DOC.HEAD: ``The Buck Stops Here With Me,'' Convicted Admiral Once Told Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 5th graf, ``His wife xxx to delete reference to clerical garb
DOC.TEXT: Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter was regarded throughout his Navy career as the consummate military aide, a perfect man to carry out orders with a preciseness that bordered on brilliance. Yet he emerged as a national security adviser who would tell skeptical congressional committees investigating the Iran-Contra affair that ``the buck stops here with me'' with regard to the decision to divert to the Central American Contras money made from arms sales to Iran. A man once decorated for his efficiency in handling paperwork, Poindexter was convicted Saturday of felony charges that make the 53-year-old officer liable for a potential 25-year prison term. One of the charges: tearing up paperwork. When the jury decision was read _ indictment-by-indictment, guilty verdict-by-guilty verdict _ the career military man stood at attention before the bench, rocking forward every so slightly as the count was rendered. His wife, an Episcopal priest, sat stoically beside the chief defense lawyer's wife. Mrs. Poindexter remained still, showing no emotion until it was over. Then she inclined her head every so slightly on the other woman's shoulder an sighed quietly. Linda and John Poindexter, both from Indiana, were married in 1958, two days after he finished first in his class at the U.S. Naval Academy at Annapolis. He was also brigade commander, one of only about a half-dozen men this century to graduate No. 1 in both academics and leadership. For 20 years she devoted her time to raising the couple's five boys and, when they started to leave home, began studying for the ministry. Poindexter went on to earn a doctorate in nuclear physics and was on the Navy fast track in 1981 when he was tapped to become military aide to former President Reagan's first National Security Adviser, Richard V. Allen. When Allen was replaced by William P. Clark Jr., Poindexter stayed in the same role and subsequently was a deputy to NSC director Robert C. McFarlane. When McFarlane left, Poindexter moved into the top NSC job, and right into the Iran-Contra caldron that was already swirling _ much of it around Oliver North, a Marine lieutenant colonel with a natural flair for theatrics who was to emerge as a well known national figure, a hero to some and a big drawing card at conservative fund-raisers. By contrast, the jurors who were to convict Poindexter indicated in their responses to questions during jury selection that his name _ let alone details of the charges against him _ barely registered on their mental radar screens. Poindexter has declined to give interviews since being implicated publicly in the affair, but interviews with friends, colleagues, and some in Congress and elsewhere who are not necessarily fond of the admiral have painted an almost universal picture of a man more versed in the scientific and military pursuits than politics and public relations. In particular, it was said that he never masted the art of dealing with Congress, or with the press. As an NCS aide in 1985, he was credited within the inner circles of the White House with planning and supervising the bold midair interception of the plane carrying the hijackers of the Achille Lauro and diverting the plane to Italy. Although unknown to the public at the time, Reagan is reported to have said, ``I salute the admiral'' when he walked into the morning NSC briefing the next day. ``He wasn't the kind of officer who would do something without authority,'' Adm. Daniel J. Murphy, chief of staff to then-Vice President Bush from 1981 to 1985, said of Poindexter in an interview more than three years ago. Yet it was the same Poindexter who told an inquiring congressional panel: ``The buck stops here with me. I made the decision (to divert arms sale money to the Contras). I thought I had the authority to do it. I thought it was a good idea. I was convinced the president would, in the end, think it was a good idea. But I did not want him to be associated with the decision.''

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Talks to Saddam on Chemical Weapons
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt arrived on an unannounced visit Saturday and met with President Saddam Hussein to discuss the Iraqi leader's pledge to use chemical arms if attacked by Israel, officials said. Mubarak's visit apparently was intended to reduce tensions between Iraq and the United States, who have exchanged criticisms over Saddam's declaration Monday that his country possessed chemical weapons and would destroy ``half of Israel'' if attacked. The officials said the two leaders met privately soon after Mubarak's Egypt Air Boeing 747 landed in the late afternoon. After a banquet at the presidential palace honoring Mubarak, the two met again, joined by their senior aides. The banquet was iftar, the meal to break the dawn-to-dusk fast that devout Moslems practice during the month of Ramadan. Mubarak was accompanied by Foreign Minister Esmat Abdul Meguid, Information Minister Safwat al-Sharif and Foreign Undersecretary Osama Al-Baz. Sharif told Egyptian reporters that the talks, which touched on Arab and bilateral issues, were ``very cordial and were held in a positive atmosphere.'' But he disclosed no details. Before flying to Baghdad, Mubarak was quoted by the state-run Middle East News Agency as saying that Iraq had no plans to attack Israel, but was reacting to a campaign of pressure against it. ``The Iraqi president has no intention of going to war at all. Not with Israel and not with Iran,'' Mubarak said in remarks Friday. Iran and Iraq declared a truce in their eight-year war in 1988. Egyptain Embassy officials said Mubarak was to return to Cairo later Saturday. The United States and Iraq have also been at odds over the chemical weapons issue and also over a joint U.S-British intelligence operation that arrested five people in London for attempting to smuggle detonators for nuclear weapons to Iraq. Earlier Saturday, Saddam rejected a call by President Bush that Iraq rule out using chemical weapons, banned by a 1925 international agreement. In Washington, the State Department announced it had expelled an Iraqi diplomat at the United Nations because of his suspected role in a purported murder plot against two opponents of the Baghdad regime. The diplomat, who was not identified, was ousted for ``an abuse of his privileges of residence in the United States,'' department spokeswoman Anita Stockman said.

DOC.HEAD: Terrorist Groups Pleads for Release of Swiss Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The Palestinian guerrilla group of terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal on Saturday appealed for the release of two Swiss Red Cross hostages kidnapped in Lebanon. Police have said Abu Nidal's own group was the prime suspect in the abduction of the two Swiss workers in Sidon on Oct. 6, but the group has denied any responsibility. On Friday, the Council said preparations were under way to free at least three French and Belgian hostages it holds in response to an appeal from Libya leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi. Saturday's statement signed by Fatah-Revolutionary Council spokesman Mansour Hamdan said: ``In these moments when arrangements are under way to release some hostages and captives, I issue this brotherly appeal to the side that kidnapped Elio Erriquez and Emmanuel Christen, the two Swiss workers for one of the International Red Cross centers in Lebanon, ... to solve this problem.'' The typewritten Arabic-language statement said the group was ready ``to provide all the guarantees demanded by the kidnappers to solve this tragedy.'' The statement did not identify the kidnappers or say what guarantees might be involved. It said the offer was made ``in favor of the relationship between our (Palestinian) people and the Swiss people and government.'' Abu Nidal is backed by Libya and believed to be living in Tripoli, the Libyan capital. Erriquez, 23, and Christen, 33, are among 18 Western hostages held captive in Lebanon. Associated Press chief Middle East correspondent Terry Anderson is the longest held hostage. He was abducted on March 16, 1985. Erriquez and Christen were kidnapped outside the Red Cross orthopedic center in Sidon, where they helped fit artificial limbs for victims of Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan President-Elect Says Top Military Officers Must Go
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro says top Sandinista military officers must go once she takes office at the end of April. In the announcement Friday night, Mrs. Chamorro said among those to be retired are the nine Commanders of the Revolution, who led the leftist Sandinista Front for National Liberation to victory over dictator Anastasio Somoza in 1979. Among them are Gen. Humberto Ortega, the defense minister and brother of outgoing President Daniel Ortega, and Interior Minister Tomas Borge, who is in charge of the ruling Sandinistas' security police. ``I am certain (Gen. Ortega) will not form part of my government,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. ``He will not remain in the army either.'' Mrs. Chamorro also wants more than a dozen senior officers who played prominent roles in Sandinista affairs to step down. The announcement was made to La Prensa newspaper reporters, who briefly interviewed Mrs. Chamorro while she was visiting with Costa Rican President-elect Rafael Calderon Fournier. Mrs. Chamorro is publisher of La Prensa, which dogged the Sandinistas for years as the only opposition newspaper. Nicaragua's president-elect led the opposition to a landslide election victory Feb. 25. She is to take power April 25.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Issue Still Dominates Race
DOC.TEXT: Allegations of drug use continued to agitate the Democratic gubernatorial contenders on Saturday, as a new poll found Tuesday's runoff too close to call. The runoff pits state Attorney General Jim Mattox against state Treasurer Ann Richards. The winning Democrat will face Republican Clayton Williams in the general election. A poll for the Houston Chronicle and The Dallas Morning News showed Ms. Richards backed by 44 percent of Democrats who said they planned to vote Tuesday. Mattox had 38 percent, 16 percent were undecided and 3 percent didn't support either candidate, according to the poll published in the papers' Sunday editions. The poll of 759 Democrats was conducted last week by the Center for Public Policy at the University of Houston. It had a margin of error of 4 percentage points. Mattox, who made a political issue of Ms. Richards' refusal to answer questions about alleged drug use more than 10 years ago, on Saturday found himself again fending off allegations that he smoked marijuana in the 1970s. ``Jim Mattox has never used any kind of dangerous drug ever,'' the state attorney general said in Houston. A Houston lawyer and a former Dallas police officer told newspapers on Thursday they saw Mattox smoke marijuana on separate occasions in the 1970s. Then, on Friday, an Austin barber told TV stations that he smoked marijuana with Mattox in Dallas about 20 years ago. Mattox blamed the campaign staff of Ms. Richards, the state treasurer, for planting the allegations with news organizations. ``I believe it's totally fabricated by the Richards campaign,'' he said. Even if Ms. Richards didn't personally talk to those accusing him of using marijuana, Mattox said, ``She's absolutely responsible for what took place.'' Ms. Richards' press secretary, Monte Williams, denied Mattox's claim, and said no one in the Richards campaign knows the men making the accusations. ``We think on Tuesday that the voters are going to reject his negative campaigning,'' Williams said. Williams, the Republican nominee, on Saturday made an issue for the first time of the row over drugs. ``If those Democrats keep doing drugs, I'm going to teach them the joys of busting rocks _ both of them,'' Williams said in Dallas, making light of one of his commercials. But he added, ``I probably won't need to, as bad as they are whipping up on each other.'' Ms. Richards has repeatedly answered the question of drug use by saying she has not used a ``mood-altering'' drug since leaving a rehabilitation program for alcoholism 10 years ago. The issue has dominated the Democratic runoff, forced after Ms. Richards finished the March 13 primary with 39 percent of the vote, to Mattox' 37 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Band Takes Up Cause of American Farmers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: With AM-Farm Aid
DOC.TEXT: Gorky Park, a Soviet rock ``superband'' that plays to big crowds in its homeland but small clubs on its first American tour, appeared before 45,000 people Saturday at Farm Aid IV. ``We're not worried, we're just nervous a little bit,'' guitarist Ian Ianenkov said during a news conference before the show at the Hoosier Dome. Members of the four-man band also brainstormed about doing their own Farm Aid concert in the Soviet Union. ``We want to do the same kind of concert in Russia and invite everyone to play,'' lead guitarist Alexei Belov said. The band urged changes in U.S. agriculture policies, warning that American farms are becoming more like the huge farming cooperatives formed 70 years ago in the Soviet Union. ``First they chased all the farmers off the land and then they made big cooperatives, big state farms. It didn't work,'' said Belov. ``I don't think you would want in America for it to go like this.'' Gorky Park, whose members are culled from some of the most popular Soviet bands, regularly attract sellout crowds at home but have drawn mostly small, curious club crowds during the U.S. tour. The group, nurtured by Jon Bon Jovi and invited to Farm Aid by John Mellencamp, was among the few foreign performers in the all-star benefit's lineup.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Guilty on All Counts in Iran-Contra Coverup
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 9-15, ``The foreman xxx to include remarks from jury foreman; trims 6 grafs from end to tighten
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX8-9
DOC.TEXT: Former national security adviser John Poindexter was convicted Saturday of conspiracy, obstruction and lying to Congress in the Iran-Contra scandal, which marred the last two years of Ronald Reagan's presidency. A federal court jury found Poindexter guilty on all five felony charges against him. He could face up to 25 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines when he is sentenced June 11. Poindexter's lawyers said they would appeal. In reaching the verdict, jurors rejected Reagan's claim in videotaped testimony that no crimes were committed in his administration's secret arms sales to Iran and diversion of profits to help the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. ``President Reagan was wrong and incorrect,'' said prosecutor Dan Webb, noting the earlier conviction of Poindexter's former aide Oliver North. Poindexter, 53, had appeared confident as he walked into the courtroom shortly after noon on the sixth day of jury deliberations. He stood facing the jurors as the 25-year-old foreman, Wayne Mitchell, rose to his feet to read the verdicts. ``Guilty,'' Mitchell said as the clerk read each of the five criminal charges aloud. There was silence in the courtroom as the first verdict was returned and then a murmur as Mitchell continued to read guilty verdicts on each of the five counts. The foreman was quoted later as saying Reagan's testimony had little impact on the jurors' verdict. ``Mr. Reagan's testimony didn't play any more of an important role than any other testimony,'' Mitchell told Washington Post reporters in an interview at his apartment. ``Actually he didn't give much information.'' Mitchell said he viewed North's testimony, considered by prosecutors to be damaging to Poindexter, as coming from a witness who `was there trying to protect himself.'' ``To me, Oliver North was a soldier,'' Mitchell said. ``Of course, I didn't figure he would come in there and tell lies against his superiors. I saw he was there for protection of himself, rather than Mr. Poindexter.'' The jury foreman said of Poindexter: ``All in all, I think he was very dedicated. But guilty as charged.'' Did the jurors consider Reagan ultimately responsible for the Iran-Contra case? ``That's dynamite,'' Mitchell said. ``I would rather not answer that.'' Webb said the prosecution team would meet in the next two weeks to make a sentencing recommendation to U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene. Poindexter's conviction ``marks the end of a very difficult and very important trial in American history,'' he said. ``High men in government office who have the responsibility for the security of this nation ought not to be allowed to commit crimes to pursue their own self-interest,'' Webb said. Poindexter is the third top Reagan administration figure convicted in the scandal. The others, North and former national security adviser Robert McFarlane, have not served any jail time. North was convicted in a jury trial and McFarlane pleaded guilty. Poindexter was convicted of conspiring with North, businessman Richard Secord and others to conceal the truth about Iran-Contra from Congress. In an interview, Webb said the ``others'' included CIA Director William Casey and McFarlane. Along with North, Secord and Poindexter, ``those are clearly the people we established are the most deeply involved in this conspiracy,'' said Webb. Casey told the House intelligence committee on Nov. 21, 1986 that there had been no presidential finding approving the Hawks shipment, U.S. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., testified at the trial of Poindexter. Specifically, Poindexter was accused of covering up North's secret Contra resupply network and the U.S. role in a CIA-assisted shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran in November 1985. North's Contra military assistance operation took place during a congressional aid ban that required the CIA to withdraw military support for the rebel force. The Hawks shipment was ratified by a politically embarrassing presidential document that depicted the missile delivery as a swap of arms for hostages. Poindexter tore up the document Nov. 21, 1986, hours after telling Congress that Reagan hadn't approved the shipment. On Nov. 13, 1986, Reagan had told the nation in a televised address that ``we did not ... trade weapons'' for hostages. Poindexter said nothing as he left the U.S. Courthouse. A reporter asked whether he had any second thoughts about not taking the witness stand in his own defense. ``No second thoughts,'' responded Poindexter's wife, Linda, who was at her husband's side. ``We're naturally disappointed with the verdict in this case, but we're going to appeal it and we're going to keep fighting it as hard as we can,'' defense attorney Richard Beckler said. During the five-week trial, Poindexter's attorneys suggested that his actions were aimed at protecting the president. ``Even being charitable to Admiral Poindexter, he did it because he wanted to protect the political viability of Ronald Reagan, and I consider that to be self-interest,'' Webb said. ``People do not commit crimes to protect the public good.'' Webb said a decision on whether prosecutors will recommend that Poindexter be given jail time will be made in consultation with independent counsel Lawrence Walsh, whose office has been investigating the Iran-Contra scandal since December 1986. North's secret Contra operation was set up in 1984 as Congress was cutting off U.S. military aid to the rebel force. The CIA-assisted shipment of Hawk missiles was approved by Reagan after it actually took place. The approval came in a so-called ``finding'' signed by Reagan. The finding depicted the administration as trading arms for hostages, something Reagan had said he would never do. In addition to tearing up the finding, Poindexter deleted 5,000 computer messages in his final days on the job. His defense was that employees leaving the government were encouraged to purge their computer files. Prosecutors said he was trying to cover up his lies to Congress. Poindexter told Congress he didn't find out about the Hawks delivery until five weeks after it occurred and that he hadn't realized other U.S. officials might have known about the shipment ahead of time. Prosecutors said the misstatements were designed to avoid raising questions about the politically embarrassing finding. Beckler said the misstatements resulted from an imperfect memory and were not an attempt to cover up. Poindexter ``supposedly found out'' at the end of November about the Hawks shipment rather than in January and ``that is no big deal ... that is a five-week mistake,'' Beckler told the jury in final arguments. ``Considering all he had to do, it's not too bad that he only missed by five weeks.'' The national security adviser ``was the man in charge'' of the U.S. role in the Hawks shipment, responded Iran-Contra prosecutor Howard Pearl.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Body Found In Wreckage Of Miami Beach Hotel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with search called off for the day, authorities reducing number of residents unaccounted-for to 10. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A fourth body was found Saturday as authorities continued a top-to-bottom search of the wreckage of a hotel that was swept by fire as residents slept. Ten tenants were still unaccounted-for in the fire that hit the Fontana Hotel before dawn Friday. ``We believe there are more victims inside,'' said police Capt. Rocco DeLeo. ``What we are doing is getting details from relatives of people who we believe are missing and getting the physical characteristics of these persons.'' One hundred and one of the 102 rooms were rented out, but no one is sure exactly how many people were in the hotel at the time of the fire, said Olimpia Mihai, one of the Fontana's owner-managers. Estimates of the number of inhabitants has ranged up to 150; the registration records were burned in the fire. As federal, state and city teams launched a top-to-bottom search, a crane was brought in to help pick apart the gutted ruins of the hotel. Investigators broke off their search at sundown Saturday and planned to return Sunday morning with specially trained dogs to search for bodies, said Miami Beach police Detective Jim Hyde. With the cause still a mystery, U.S. Magistrate Linnea Johnson issued a search warrant at the request of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to preserve any evidence that might be needed later in court. The bureau conducts arson investigations. Mayor Alex Daoud said fire officials told him Friday that arson was strongly suspected, but Fire Chief Branaird Dorris said tenants had mentioned a water leak, which raised the possibility of an electrical short. ``Whenever you have a serious loss of life, and a substantial loss of property damage and money, a warrant is routine,'' Hyde said Saturday. U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, who donned a hard hat to inspect the three-story hotel, said the purpose of the warrant was to legally preserve any possible evidence. He played down the significance of his visit, saying: ``You shouldn't judge the importance of any particular investigation by what officials are there.'' Asked when the death toll would be known, Robert Creighton, ATF agent in charge of the Florida office, said: ``We may have that in two days. It all depends on what we find.'' Names of 14 residents who had not been seen since the fire were provided by surviving tenants. The four bodies found so far _ two women, a man and a fourth person whose sex wasn't immediately determined _ were tentatively assumed to be among the 14 missing, Hyde said. ``We're bringing our total of unaccounted-for people to ten,'' Hyde said. ``Again, this is an approximate `guesstimate' based on information we were given by residents of the hotel.'' Twenty-one hotel residents were taken to three area hospitals Friday, and five remained hospitalized in good condition Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Inquiry Demanded in Alleged Kidnapped of American Nun
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic delegation demanded an investigation into the alleged abduction, torture and sexual abuse by government agents of an American nun. ``The government has tried to hide the truth in this case,'' said Sister Francisco Wilhelm at a news conference on Friday. Some Guatemalan officials have alleged that the kidnapping of 31-year-old Sister Diana Mack Ortiz of Colorado was self-inflicted. ``This version of a hoax is ridiculous,'' said Sister Wilhelm. She cited a Nov. 8, 1989, report by an New Mexico medical group which said the nun had suffered second-degree burns. Sister Wilhelm, who was accompanied by Guatemalan and American church officials, said Sister Ortiz has returned to the Ursulina order headquarters in Maple Mount, Ky. Sister Ortiz was abducted Nov. 2, 1989, in Antigua, 30 miles west of the Guatemala City, and released later that day, Sister Wilhelm said. The Americans were is in Guatemala to press the government for an investigation. The members said they personally would ask President Vinicio Cerezo to form a commission to investigate the matter. ``We know and Gen. Carlos Morales, the security minister, has admitted that there are thousands of cases like Diana's in Guatemala,'' Sister Wilhelm said. ``By the grace of God she was freed.'' Pablo Sireff, an attorney for Sister Ortiz, said his client was abducted by uniformed officers and taken away in a police car. The church delegation said she was taken to Mixco, a small town outside Antigua, where she was sexually molested and burned. It said the nun was interrogated and shown photographs of people to identify. However, it had no explanation for any reason the nun would be abducted.

DOC.HEAD: Brother and Sister of Landlord Say He's Ruining Business
DOC.TEXT: The owner of the building that housed an illegal social club where 87 people were killed in a fire has been accused in lawsuits by his brother and sister of ruining the family real estate business. The Daily News and The New York Times reported in their Sunday editions that the siblings of Alex DiLorenzo III accuse him of making speculative commodities investments, buying failing businesses and acquired buildings in need of repairs. Alex DiLorenzo last week surrendered to authorities on 43 arrest warrants for outstanding building code violations, including one violation at the Happy Land social club in the Bronx, where the fire occurred last month. The other 42 concerned citations at various Manhattan properties. DiLorenzo's brother, Marc, and sister, Lisa, sued to wrest control of two family partnerships which have about 250 holdings valued in court papers at as much as $1.2 billion, the Times said. At the family's request, the pending case has been sealed. In one decision before the sealing, Manhattan state Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer credited Alex DiLorenzo with increasing the success of the family business. Baer in December rejected Marc DiLorenzo's motion to have Alex removed as head of the business. Among the non-real estate transactions questioned in the lawsuit, the News said, was Alex DiLorenzo's involvement in a firm that began to sell frozen cow embryos and bull semen to Third World countries. Five brokers who have worked with the DiLorenzo family said Alex failed to follow his late father's pattern of buying established, expensive properties, the Times said. The DiLorenzo business was left in trust to the three children when their father died in 1975. Alex DiLorenzo administered the trust. Several years ago, Marc DiLorenzo, under terms allowed in the trust, asked that the partnership be broken into three equal parts and distributed. Alex DiLorenzo refused and his siblings sued.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Center, Director Indicted In Mapplethorpe Photo Exhibit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, ```There is ...', to UPDATE with center planning to seek federal court order; pick up 5th graf pvs, `The Hamilton ...'. SUBS 10th graf pvs, `About 650 ...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with record opening-day crowd, quote; pick up 11th graf pvs, `Although police ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CS5,6
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury indicted an arts center and its director on obscenity charges Saturday for an exhibit of the late Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs, including some with partly nude children or homosexual acts. Despite the indictment, the controversial photos will remain in the exhibit, said Dennis Barrie, director of the Contemporary Arts Center. ``The show will continue,'' Barrie said of the exhibit, which prompted debate last year in Congress over federal funding for the arts when Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., objected to some of the photos. ``There is simply nothing wrong with this exhibition,'' Barrie said. ``It's an important exhibition. It's important that it be seen here.'' Attorneys for the center planned to ask U.S. District Judge Carl Rubin for a temporary restraining order Sunday barring the Hamilton County prosecutor, the county sheriff and the Cincinnati police chief from closing the show, center spokeswoman Amy Banister said Saturday night. The Hamilton County grand jury indicted the arts center and Barrie on two misdemeanor counts each of pandering obscenity and illegally using a minor in nudity-oriented material after jurors viewed the exhibition anonymously among the crowd Saturday. The grand jury concluded that seven of the 175 photographs are obscene. The indictment touched off an emotional rally Saturday afternoon by patrons who were ordered out of the center while police videotaped the display under protection of a search warrant. ``The whole world is watching. The whole world is laughing,'' several hundred patrons chanted while they waited outside the center. The crowd also gave Nazi salutes and shouted ``Sieg Heil'' to officers videotaping the show. The show was reopened after police finished their videotaping in about 45 minutes. No arrests were made. About 650 people saw the exhibit before it was closed for the videotaping at midday; in all, more than 3,000 people paid $5 each on Saturday to view the exhibit, easily breaking the center's attendance record for an opening day, Ms. Banister said. The center's largest previous opening-day crowd was 1,000 in late 1988 for a show on computers and art, she said. Although police didn't confiscate any of the photographs Saturday, Hamilton County Prosecutor Arthur Ney suggested further action would be taken next week unless the pictures in question are voluntarily removed. He said no action would be taken until Monday or Tuesday. ``There's always a possibility that each day this continues could be an added criminal action or sanction,'' Ney told a hastily called news conference. ``I'm not saying there will be; I'm saying there could be.'' The arts center refused to admit people under 18 to the show unless they were accompanied by parents. The center also put the controversial photos in a separate display room. The exhibit opened to the public Saturday morning after an evening preview showing that attracted more than 4,000 members of the center. A demonstrator at a museum entrance Saturday held up a sign reading ``Censorship is obscene.'' At another entrance, a sign read, ``Stop pornography. Stop Perversion. Stop Mapplethorpe.'' Amateur photographer John Daniels praised the photos and said the controversy prompted him to attend the opening. ``It's embarrassing to be from Cincinnati with this kind of reaction and be seen as a backward, jerkwater town,'' Daniels said. ``I hope that the turnout demonstrates that Cincinnati really is enlightened.'' The University of Pennsylvania's Institute of Contemporary Art organized the exhibit in the fall of 1988. It drew large crowds in Philadelphia in December 1988 and in Chicago at the time of Mapplethorpe's March 1989 death from acquired immune deficiency syndrome at age 42. Last June, the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., canceled the exhibit. It drew large crowds at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, Conn., in late 1989. The show runs through May 26 in Cincinnati and closes its tour in Boston in August. The Washington exhibit prompted Congress to limit funds for the arts after Helms, R-N.C., declared the photographs obscene. Barrie could be sentenced to up to one year in jail if convicted on both charges. The maximum sentence for the arts center would be a $10,000 fine. Lawyers for the city and county told a municipal court judge on Friday that no decision had been made about whether the photos were obscene. Ney said Saturday he considers them personally offensive but that he would leave it to a jury to decide whether they are obscene. Cincinnati Police Chief Lawrence Whalen said residents should be content that the law has been followed in issuing the indictments. ``There are no raving Neanderthals running amok in the streets of Cincinnati,'' Whalen said.

DOC.HEAD: About 150 Dead in North Sea Ferry Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to ADD quote from firefighter; RECASTS lead; pickup graf 3 pvs `Dr. Tom...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos OSL2,4, GOT1, LON2, LaserColor OSL3
DOC.TEXT: A North Sea ferry with nearly 500 people aboard caught fire before dawn Saturday, suffocating many passengers who tried to flee down smoke-filled corridors. About 150 people were reported killed and at least 20 injured. The Danish owners of the car ferry said they strongly suspected arson. Some passengers said the boat's fire alarms didn't work and the crew seemed unprepared for the emergency. ``There were plenty of people aboard, and I guess they all tried to leave at the same time,'' said Norwegian firefighter Sven-Johan Svenson. ``Some of those who got left behind and died just didn't find their way out.'' Dr. Tom Brokopp, leader of a Swedish medical rescue team, told reporters at the Swedish port of Lysekil that 75 bodies were counted so far on the Scandinavian Star ferry and that 71 more were dead or missing. He said some missing were still in the ship and others were in the sea. However, assistant Oslo police commissioner Bjoern Gran told Norwegian radio that the deaths would total about 150. ``We have been in contact with Swedish police, and they say there were no more survivors on board,'' Gran said. In Oslo, Jan Erik Nermoen, representing the Danish VR-DANO Line that owns the ship, said 493 passengers and crew were on a manifest. The ferry caught fire early Saturday after leaving Oslo en route to the Danish port of Frederikshavn. Up to 340 people were reported rescued from lifeboats by helicopters and about seven nearby vessels in the Skagerrak Straits, 44 miles south of the Norwegian Ferder Island. More than 20 injured were taken to hospitals. The Swedish news agency TT said it was the worst ferry disaster in Scandinavian waters. The fire was the worst North Sea ship disaster since March 6, 1987, when a car ferry, the Herald of Free Enterprise, capsized off the Belgian port of Zeebrugge, killing 189 people. That accident was blamed on ship personnel who failed to close bow doors, allowing water to rush in. The Scandinavian Star, still burning and listing, was guided by tugs to a dock in Lysekil port on Sweden's west coast Saturday night, more than 18 hours after it caught fire. Much of the midships section on the upper decks was blackened. More than 100 bodies remained aboard, district Police Chief Roar Onso said, adding that they would not be removed before Sunday. He said it would take several days to investigate the cause of the fire. Most of the dead had apparently succumbed to smoke, and few were seriously burned, said Conny Englund, head of the Swedish Sea Rescue Center at Lysekil. Firemen who probed the blackened compartments of the 10,000-ton ferry said they found three passengers, alive and apparently uninjured, among the many bodies. ``We woke up in the middle of the night. I heard a noise outside. I went out of the cabin and saw thick, black smoke,'' said Danish passenger Leo Odeland, an Oslo resident traveling with his wife and two daughters. ``Nothing happened when I pushed the fire alarm. I hadn't heard the alarm go off. At another place where there was supposed to be an alarm, nothing was there.'' Odeland said the crew was ``apparently new and untrained.'' ``It was hard to get the lifeboat into the water and then the motor didn't start,'' he said, adding that the lifeboat drifted away and a Soviet freighter picked them up.
