Brokopp quoted several passengers as saying alarms didn't work and crew members had trouble understanding each other because they spoke different languages. ``It was chaotic,'' said passenger Eli Kvale Neilsen. ``It was clear that the crew was not trained for this kind of situation.'' Passenger and crew lists were not immediately available, rescue officials said, and this led to confusion about the numbers and identities of those aboard the Scandinavian Star. The crew was believed to be largely Portuguese, with Scandinavian officers. The Bahamian-registered ferry is owned by the Danish shipping company VR-DANO Line. SeaEscape Ltd of Miami sold the ship to VR-DANO last month, a SeaEscape spokeswoman said in a telephone interview from Miami. Danish radio quoted Ole Hansen, managing director of the Danish company, as saying he was virtually certain the fire had been deliberately set aboard the ferry. Hansen, speaking at a news conference in Copenhagen, insisted the vessel was safe, but he refused to discuss the reports that alarms had not worked on the ferry and that the crew was untrained. Company officials said two fires broke out on separate decks within 15 minutes. Crew members reportedly extinguished the first fire, then discovered a bigger blaze one deck below. Scandinavian news reports quoted survivors as saying the fire began on a low deck, beneath the ferry's water line and near the stern. Thick smoke spread upward, through the deck where passengers' cars were parked and through a higher deck where a casino and bars are located. Maritime and police officials in Sweden, Denmark, and Norway announced plans for a joint investigation. Gran told reporters that the inquiry would be based on the theory that the fire had been deliberately set. Anders Lindstrom, head of the Swedish Seafarers' Union, blamed the fire on on shipping companies who register ships under flags of convenience to escape regulations concerning crew hiring and safety. The Scandinavian Star's distress signal was sent about 2:30 a.m. (8:30 p.m. EDT Friday). News reports quoted survivors as saying the fire was already widespread at that time. Hansen denied a Swedish radio report that some passengers had slept in their cars, a practice that could contribute to safety hazards. The vessel has large doors at both ends to allow vehicles to drive on and off. Niel Bagger, deputy director of the Danish Marine Authority, told Danish TV that the Scandinavian Star started on the Oslo-Frederikshavn route last week, and that Danish authorities had not yet inspected the ferry. An engine-room fire broke out aboard the Scandinavian Star in March, 1988, as it sailed from Cozumel, Mexico, to Tampa, Fla. None of the 439 passengers, mostly Americans, was injured. The U.S. National Transportation Safety Board concluded that the ship's smoke-detectors apparently failed, an automatic fire-extinguishing system did not work and emergency generators didn't work for an hour after the fire. It also said the crew was poorly trained for firefighting.

DOC.HEAD: Basketball Coach Settles with N.C. State University
DOC.TEXT: North Carolina State University bought out the contract of basketball coach Jim Valvano for $212,000 on Saturday, ending a six-week fight by Valvano to keep his job. The university sought Valvano's ouster following reports that former players had accepted cash from school boosters and allegations of point-shaving on games. The point-shaving allegations are still under investigation. Valvano was never implicated in the allegations, but they followed a two-year probation imposed in 1989 by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which found players had improperly sold complimentary basketball shoes and tickets. Valvano, who led N.C. State to a 209-114 record and the 1983 championship during his 10-year tenure, also had been criticized for the lack of academic progress made by the players he recruited. ``There is no bitterness at all,'' Valvano said Saturday. ``There is nothing but joy in the last 10 years, even the last year and a half.'' Valvano maintained he likely would have prevailed in any lawsuit over his departure, but he said it was not in the best interest of the school to pursue legal action. ``I'm not trying to be a divisive force,'' he said. ``I'm trying to be part of the solution.'' Over the past five days, Valvano had tried to meet with the school's Board of Trustees but was turned down. On Friday, he proposed remaining for one more year for a salary of $1. That was turned down as well. Valvano settled for double his annual salary of $106,000. He had sought $500,000. Chancellor Larry K. Monteith said Valvano will also receive his regular salary through May 15, a total of $26,509.24. ``We wish him well in his future endeavors,'' Monteith said. ``We believe firmly that this settlement is in the best interest of our students, faculty, alumni and everyone associated with N.C. State University.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Astronaut Dies of Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: Ronald E. Evans, who was Apollo 17 command module pilot on man's last trip to the moon, died of a heart attack at his Arizona home Saturday. He was 56. The former astronaut died in his sleep and was found by his wife, Janet, his mother-in-law, Marge Pollom of Sun City, told the The Topeka Capital-Journal. Evans called his December 1972 flight to the moon in Apollo 17 ``the best experience I ever had in my life.'' He left the astronaut program in 1977 to become an officer with Western American Energy Corp. in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was in demand as a public speaker and traveled widely. Evans was born in St. Francis, Kan., and later lived in Topeka, Kan. He received a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from the University of Kansas in 1956, where he enrolled in the ROTC program, and a master's degree in aeronautical engineering from the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School in 1964. He was selected in 1963 for astronaut training and became an astronaut in 1966.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Court Rejects Appeal by Imprisoned Rights Activists
DOC.TEXT: The Cuban Supreme Court on Friday rejected an appeal by two human rights activists sentenced to prison for criticizing a drug trial that led to the execution of four military officers, a news report said. The Cuban news agency Prensa Latina said the court upheld the sentences handed down last November to Elizardo Sanchez Santa Cruz and Hiram Abi Cobas Nunez. Both were convicted of crimes against the state. ``The intention of the accused was to impair the prestige of and discredit the Cuban state and affect its relations with other nations by propagating false and tendentious news,'' Prensa Latina, monitored in Mexico City, quoted the Supreme Court as saying. Sanchez Santa Cruz received two years imprisonment and Cobas Nunez 18 months. Prensa Latina said the two wrote a ``joint communique'' criticizing the court martial that convicted 14 military officers of drug-trafficking, four of whom were executed in July. The statement said the court martial violated legal regulations and rights of the accused, Prensa Latina said. Maj. Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa, a war hero who fought with President Fidel Castro in Cuba's revolution, and three fellow officers were executed by firing squad in July for their involvement in the drug trafficking scandal. Also executed were Col. Antonio de la Guardia Font, Maj. Amado Pardo and Capt. Jorge Martinez. Ochoa had been a trusted aide to Castro, commanding Cuban forces in Ethiopia and Angola and heading a Cuban military mission to Nicaragua. The scandal stunned and embarrassed Castro and his communist government, which for years denied U.S. accusations that Cuba was being used to smuggle drugs into the United States. Another 10 officers were sentenced to prison terms, and the scandal led to a major shakeup of the armed forces, the Interior Ministry and the Cuba's state security force.

The United States and the Soviet Union head for a superpower summit in seven weeks still divided on major nuclear arms control issues but hoping that more talks next month will produce the ``hard decisions'' needed to weld agreement. Secretary of State James A. Baker III did use three days of meetings with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze this week to deliver repeated warnings of the consequences of employing Moscow's military weight to crush Lithuania's fervor for independence. And both nations took a new look at how a unified Germany will fit into the European community, making no effort to disguise fundamental differences on how that fit eventually will be made. Baker and Shevardnadze acted to lower expectations that President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev actually will be able to sign a treaty sharply reducing intercontinental nuclear weapons when they meet here beginning May 30.

Soldiers and police patrolled the city in trucks today to enforce a curfew confining people to their homes after security forces fired on protesters in the worst day of violence in the 7-week-old campaign for greater democracy. Security forces hurled tear gas and opened fire Friday after about 200,000 pro-democracy demonstrators set government buildings afire and put up burning barricades. The kingdom's official radio station said six people were killed and 107 were injured. However, one doctor said he saw soldiers carting 200 corpses from the city.

Authorities feared they would find more bodies as they searched the rubble of a residential hotel where fire killed at least three residents and forced others to jump from windows. Twenty were injured. Fire officials today reported at least 14 people missing after the pre-dawn fire Friday at the three-story, 102-room Fontana Hotel north of Miami Beach's trendy art deco district. They didn't know how many died in the fire. ``This has the possibility of being a tragedy of large proportions,'' said Assistant Fire Chief John Reed. ``We do expect the number of dead to rise.'' ``I know there are more people in there. There is an old man I know didn't get out. Oh God, this is unreal,'' said Lynda Holloway, 41, who lived at the residential hotel about a year.

A moderate earthquake rattled the San Francisco Bay area during an exhibition baseball rematch between the teams that were about to start a World Series game at Candlestick Park when last year's killer quake struck. The temblor, measuring 4.5 on the Richter scale, capped an afteroon-long swarm of seismic activity that jangled nerves and tossed merchandise from store shelves but caused no major damage or injuries. The quake struck at 7:39 p.m., just one minute after the game between the Oakland Athletics and the San Francisco Giants got under way at Candlestick. ``In the press box everybody sort of sat up and said, `No, that didn't happen. Did someone jump hard?''' said Bob Egelko, an Associated Press reporter covering the game. ``It looked like the players hesitated.''

President Bush is praising Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu for exhibiting political courage in championing a major trade agreement, but warning that the true test will come in implementation of the pact. Bush lauded Kaifu for the success he achieved in the month since the two leaders met in California to discuss trade tensions arising from this country's huge $49 billion deficit with Japan. ``For the first time, Japan has committed to removing a broad array of structural barriers that constrain trade and impede imports,'' Bush said in an appearance Friday before the American Society of Newspaper Editors. But he said actual results would be what counted.

A screening of the photographs of the late Robert Mapplethorpe turned into the social event of the year for a museum threatened with prosecution by police who claim the photos are obscene. Close to 6,000 people lined up Friday night and filed through the Contemporary Arts Center to see the exhibit, which includes nine homoerotic or sadomasochistic photos among the 175 on display. ``This crowd says a lot about the people of Cincinnati and their desire to express their freedoms,'' said museum director Dennis Barrie. ``I think it is a vindication of the exhibit.'' Earlier Friday, Hamilton County Municipal Judge Edward Donnellon dismissed a lawsuit in which the private museum had sought a summary judgment deeming the exhibit art, not obscenity.

President Bush says he will sign an executive order that he earlier promised _ and in fact claimed to have issued _ protecting Chinese students from deportation. Aides said Bush will release the order, probably early next week, incorporating provisions of an informal directive he had issued on dealing with Chinese who feared for their safety if sent home when their visas expired. Many had supported the now-suppressed democracy movement. The president said his order also will ``extend the deferral of enforced departure for Chinese nationals, which is currently scheduled to expire on June 5 of this year, through Jan. 1, 1994.'' Reacting to criticism that he has failed to issue the executive order he promised last year, Bush said Friday: ``I did say I was going to have an executive order. What we had was an executive directive from the president'' that had ``precisely the same legal effect as an executive order.''

Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. says the Internal Revenue Service is firmly committed to safeguarding taxpayers' rights, but critics say the word has not filtered down to some agents in the field. David Keating, executive vice president of the National Taxpayers Union, told a Senate Finance subcommittee Friday that the situation could get worse as budget shortages increase pressure on the IRS to boost collections. ``As marching orders filter through the bureaucracy, each management layer tends to rewrite the orders stronger, to ensure that the field troops fully understand the new mission,'' Keating said. ``The result may well be that IRS employees could take a much tougher stand with taxpayers, causing more violations of the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.''

It's known by NASA as the ``Phantom Head,'' a human skull filled with sensors to measure the dose of space radiation that astronauts receive. The skull goes into space aboard the shuttle Discovery for the third and probably last time Tuesday. Its keeper in orbit, astronaut Kathryn Sullivan, hopes the trip will put an end to all jokes about the ``phantom passenger.'' ``It's not a passenger. It's a device, actually a very sophisticated one and one that has considerable potential to provide some very significant data to all of the people within NASA who are trying to measure crew health,'' she said. The head is crammed with instruments that bring its weight to more than 20 pounds, and covered with a black plastic material simulating human skin. It contains as many as 600 tiny measuring devices called dosimeters.

DOC.HEAD: Avi-Abed, Simha, Jill: Tragedy Where Identity Was Everything
DOC.TEXT: Simha Vaknin's boyfriend, a tall, handsome man, was known to everyone in her town of Pardes Hanna as Avi Levy, a Jew from Zicharon Yaacov, five miles away. In Zicharon Yaacov, where he had lived for 20 years, ``Avi'' was Abed al-Tiar, a member of the town's only Arab family. Tiar wanted to be a Jew, and when his masquerade was exposed last month, his hopes of escaping the limitations of being Arab in Israel collapsed. Police said he fatally shot Simha and Jill Eden, a Jewish woman from his own village who had rejected him, then took his own life. The case illuminates the element of identity that has exacerbated the decades-long political conflict between Arab and Jew. Intermarriages are not accepted by either community. There are only a few hundred in Israel, a nation of 3.5 million Jews and 810,000 Arabs. Yochanan Peres, a sociology professor at Tel Aviv University, said the taboo against marrying outside the group is so strong that the few violators are put in ``a suicidal situation.'' Abed al-Tiar seemed able to overcome the obstacles if anyone could. Residents of Zicharon Yaacov describe the 23-year-old farm worker as appearing Jewish in every way _ education, dress, flawless Hebrew, sense of humor and friendships. They say he was happy and well-liked, and for most of his life stayed out of trouble. Then, two years ago, Tiar fell in love with Jill Eden, a 30-year-old beautician in his hometown. She was friendly, but did not reciprocate romantic interest, and he began to press her. Yitzhak Zur, police commander of the town in northern Israel, said Tiar wrote love letters to Ms. Eden and painted messages on a wall near her house. He began threatening her a year ago, and Ms. Eden complained to the police. Tiar was convicted of harassment and released on probation. A few months later, Tiar met Simha Vaknin, 20, who worked at a boarding school for retarded children in Pardes Hanna. He introduced himself as Avi Levy, a name as common in Hebrew as John Smith in English. ``He would be here from first thing in the morning,'' said Simha's brother, Yaacov. ``We knew him as a Jew in everything; he never gave a single sign that would give him away.'' Her brother said Simha never considered the possibility that ``Avi'' was not Jewish until the beginning of March, when she spoke to his older sister and detected a slight Arab accent. Tiar allayed her doubts by showing her a forged army identity card. While they sat in his car a week later, a policeman stopped for a routine check of their identity cards. Police said they arrested Tiar for possessing a counterfeit card and told Simha his true identity. ``She decided from that moment to break it off,'' her brother said. ``She told him very politely that he had lied to her this whole time and she didn't want to continue their relationship.'' If she had known ``Avi'' was an Arab, Simha never would have become involved with him, Yaacov said. ``We're not interested in relationships like that,'' the brother said. ``It's not natural. It's not healthy.'' A few days later, Tiar arrived at the school where Simha worked. Zur, the Zicharon Yaacov police commander, said the young man persuaded her to get into his car, drove to the outskirts of Pardes Hanna and shot her to death. Tiar then drove to Zicharon Yaacov and came upon Jill Eden leaving work, followed her home and shot her to death as she was entering her apartment, Zur said. That evening, in the orchard where he worked, Tiar wrote a suicide note in Hebrew on a cardboard box and shot himself in the head. Police would not disclose the note's contents, but the daily Maariv quoted it as saying: ``They wouldn't let me live as Jew.'' ``He told me he wanted to be a Jew,'' said Shai Zukerman, the dead man's employer. ``He was born an Arab, but among the Arabs he was a Jew, and among the Jews he was an Arab.''

DOC.HEAD: Fears of Dry Weather Send Cocoa Prices Higher
DOC.TEXT: Since last fall, the price of cocoa has risen $300 a ton off the 14-year low of $900, despite six consecutive seasons of surplus production and record inventories. Analysts say there are several reasons for the upsurge, including a concern the West African crop areas _ primarily the Ivory Coast, Nigeria and Cameroon _ have received only a quarter of their normal rainfall in the past two months. There also has been some warming of the central Pacific Ocean off the coasts of Chile and Peru, a phenomenon that in the past has caused dry spells and droughts in the cocoa growing areas of Brazil and in West Africa. Political unrest in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, also is providing a boost to prices. The cocoa market has been further boosted by a concern over the availabilty of cocoa to processors, says Sandra Kaul, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. Ms. Kaul noted the activity in the market is taking place in between two crops _ the main crop harvest takes place between September and January and supplies have been sold out. The secondary harvest begins next month. Because so little cocoa is available, producers have been less inclined to protect themselves in the futures market, where they could sell cocoa contracts and lock in prices now. Ms. Kaul added that against the background of concern about the weather and political stability, the International Cocoa Agreement has been extended for another two years, eliminating the prospect that the agreement's 250,000 ton buffer stock of cocoa beans will be released into the market. Judy Ganes, an analyst with Merrill Lynch in New York, said the bullish cocoa market was somewhat of a surprise because most traders had a bearish expectation of a soft market after years of oversupply. One analyst, who asked not to be identified, said the technical nature of the price rise is an indication traders are finding a way to construe any bit of information about the crop as bullish. ``Certainly if it rains in West Africa or any of the (other) cocoa growing regions, it's (the price surge) over,'' Ms. Ganes said.
DOC.HEAD: Precious metals
DOC.TEXT: Gold and silver futures settled into a narrow trading range during the week as Saudi Arabian investors who bailed out the market during the previous week's trading were returning. However, the continued strength of the dollar weighed on prices.
DOC.HEAD: Energy
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures rose early in the week on expectations that the midweek American Petroleum Institute inventory report would show substantial declines in gasoline stocks, indicating rising demand. But the report showed larger-than-expected U.S supplies of crude oil and heating oil, but a smaller-than-expected gasoline supply.
DOC.HEAD: Livestock and pork
DOC.TEXT: Cattle and pork futures were mixed, with pork rising sharply early in the week following a government report indicating lagging hog production this year. However, lower cash prices adversely affected pork future prices. Increased supplies of fed cattle weighed on livestock futures, but prices were helped by light sales and higher prices for steers.
DOC.HEAD: Grains and soybeans
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were mixed in the aftermath of U.S. Agriculture Department reports that farmers would increase corn production this year, while soybean production would be cut back. Soybean prices, after surging early in the week, came under pressure because of slack export demand. Fears of a weekend freeze in the winter wheat crop area gave some support to wheat futures.

DOC.BYLINE: Corporate Profits: Down Now, Better Later? ^By CHET CURRIER
DOC.TEXT: Stock-market investors are bracing for a new round of negative earnings news over the next few weeks as corporations post results for the first quarter of 1990. But if the suspicions of some analysts prove correct, the gloomy mood that has prevailed in the earnings outlook for most of the past year could begin to brighten in the months ahead. Their hopes are based, to a great degree, on recent signs that business activity is slowly pulling out of its recent slowdown, apparently having staved off a full-scale recession. ``It is more likely than not that we are passing the low point in corporate profits,'' asserts Michael Sherman, investment strategist at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. In the last half of 1989, by Sherman's reckoning, operating earnings for the companies that make up Standard & Poor's 500-stock composite index showed an average decline of 4 percent. Shearson estimates that the quarter ended March 31 will see a 5.7 percent drop from the like period last year, to be followed by a 2 percent shortfall in the second quarter. But after that, the firm projects small gains in the third quarter, perhaps quickly expanding to record levels as 1990 comes to a close. If they follow such a script, profits could finish the year with a small net gain over 1989. ``Corporate America has not thrown in the towel on 1990,'' says Stephen Roach, economist at the investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley & Co. ``That's a bold assertion, to say the least, but one that draws ample support from what is shaping up to be a pleasant surprise on corporate profits. ``We have long maintained that a resilient American consumer will provide solid support to the U.S. economy in 1990. And now it seems as if the business sector will follow suit.'' The prospective timing of any upswing in profits is the subject of much disagreement. ``An earnings pickup will be delayed 'til late 1990,'' argues Thomas Doerflinger at PaineWebber Inc. But for next year he projects a 13 percent improvement from 1990 levels. ``This forecast implies that the Fed will successfully engineer an anti-inflationary `soft landing,''' he says. Despite such upbeat thoughts, the stock market managed only a mixed showing in the past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 9.91 to 2,717.12. The New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped .07 to 186.78; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 4.64 to 430.90, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down .74 at 361.01. Volume on the Big Board averaged 143.97 million shares a day, against 132.31 million the week before. For the immediate future, one point of particular concern for many analysts is earnings in the banking industry. Entangled as they are in many of the debt problems the economy is grappling with _ ranging from junk bonds and Third World loans to real estate _ the banks now face what looks like a long period of exacting scrutiny by federal regulators looking into their lending practices. ``We suspect that the President, the Treasury and the Federal Reserve are going to have something to say about how this process unfolds,'' observed Sherman. ``In the end, it is healthy that the office (of the Controller of the Currency) is forcing banks to tighten up their lending standards. ``However, the economic repercussions of these actions should be controlled, and will be controlled, before they do major damage to the total economy.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for weekend editions April 7-8

DOC.HEAD: Which Way Are Oil Prices Heading?
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices are weakening, a decline traced to rising OPEC production, seasonal slack demand and the notable absence of any jolting events such as the Exxon Valdez spill that helped traumatize the market last year. Nonetheless it appears unlikely that prices will fall dramatically, and some analysts say the market is much more stable than at any time in the recent past. If these trends persist, motorists shouldn't see any sudden price changes in gasoline as the summer driving season begins. Others, however, contend that the oil market in general is much more vulnerable to disruptions now, partly because of the growing integration of the world economy and some politically unstable hotspots. If, for example, Soviet oilworkers went on strike, or chemical warfare broke out in the Middle East, or another major spill fouled the U.S. coast, the psychological impact could give the oil market a serious case of nerves and force prices up sharply. Most of the oil-price decline this past week was attributed to new evidence that suggests the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is aggressively producing oil in what has been a slack demand period, between winter and summer, when most refiners curtail operations. OPEC accounts for a growing chunk of world production and has doubled its market share in the United States over the past four years, from about 12 percent to nearly 25 percent. The price of West Texas Intermediate, the primary grade of U.S. crude and a widely followed market barometer, finished the past week at $19.15 per 42-gallon barrel, down more than $1 a barrel from a week earlier and down about $4 from the beginning of this year. Wholesale gasoline prices also dropped sharply. But some strategists believe these declines won't last long. ``Right now it's perceived there isn't going to be a crash in prices,'' said Kevin Lindemer, associate director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass. ``We can expect a little bit of price weakness, but I think this is something that's typical for this time of the year.'' It remains unclear why OPEC production is so intense. Oil intelligence references that track the cartel's output estimate the 13 members are producing about 23.5 million barrels a day, which is about the highest level in eight years. If that persists, a serious price decline would seem inevitable. At the same time, however, much of that oil is getting soaked up by industrialized areas of the world. Moreover, potential markets that nobody thought existed a year ago _ the most notable example is Eastern Europe _ could provide new sources of demand for OPEC oil. Edward N. Krapels, president of Energy Security Analysis, a Washington-based research concern that tracks prices worldwide, said there's another wrinkle in the world oil equation _ the difference between low-sulphur ``sweet'' crudes such as West Texas Intermediate, and the higher-sulphur ``sour'' grades that span much of what OPEC sells. The sour crudes are plentiful but require intense refining to produce high-quality gasoline, while sweet crudes are much cheaper to process. This is important because U.S. oil companies play a major role in refining sour crudes and could use their leverage to hold down prices charged by producers. ``We think West Texas Intermediate will stabilize at about $19 to $20 a barrel, but unfortunately for exporters, high-sulphur oil will fall further,'' Krapels said, predicting less than $15 a barrel for Dubai, a standard Middle East crude. ``So it's kind of a bifurcated view,'' he said. ``You expect the price of the dirty stuff to be lower than the clean stuff. The refiners are in a very strong negotiating position.'' In other business and economic news this past week: _The government-directed savings & loan salvation effort took several dramatic turns. Most notable were the record 30-year prison sentence imposed on a failed Texas thrift's former executive convicted of fraud; a congressional auditor prediction that the bailout cost could hit $500 billion if the economy falters, more than triple the amount the White House forecast last year; and Senate approval of labor lawyer Timothy Ryan as top S&L regulator, nullifying a court decision that had threatened to derail the entire rescue effort. _Japan and the United States agreed on a broad economic pact designed to make it easier for foreigners to do business in Japan and make American industry more competitive. The pact was hailed as a major event in relations between the world's two largest economies, but it remains unclear whether and when its effects will be felt. _The long battle for control of United Airlines appeared to be near an end. Directors of parent company UAL Corp. agreed to a $4.38 billion takeover offer from employees, about $2.4 billion less than a debt-financed acquisition proposal that collapsed a half year ago. _General Motors Corp. named Robert Stempel as chairman and chief executive to succeed Roger Smith when he retires in August. The appointment of Stempel to take the helm of the nation's biggest industrial company was expected, and many believe he will play a more aggressive role in GM's car design and development than Smith, who was widely criticized because of his accounting background.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for weekend editions April 7-8
